A World War II veteran had to end his regular visits to the Pacific Battleship Center - Battleship USS Iowa due to health reasons, so Chief Selects from the Fleet Anti-Submarine Warfare Training Center honored Ernest Thompson in a touching an emotional tribute in front of his home in Gardena. 

They sang the U.S. Navy's march song, "Anchors Aweigh," in the middle of his residential street as Thompson stood on his porch and saluted, the now-viral video shows. 

The remarkable thing, according to a spokesman for the USS Iowa Museum, is that Thompson had a fall earlier this year and had not been able to walk or stand since then.

After the song concluded, the chief selects went up to the veteran one-by-one to shake his hand. Thompson's grandson called it, "one of the best days of his life."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/MGR9C

On the last day of the Indiana State Fair, a group of State Police troopers patrolling the fairgrounds in a golf cart had a little fun, busting out their own rendition of "Summer Nights" from the film "Grease." 

The video, which was first uploaded by one of the troopers to Vimeo on Sunday, has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/jvaoI

Contest: We're giving away two tickets plus VIP passes to see Kool & The Gang's Keepin' The Funk Alive Tour, courtesy of our partners at AEG Live. Watch the KTLA 5 Morning News on Tuesday for you chance to win.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Several life-sized statues of a naked Donald Trump popped up around the U.S. Thursday morning, including one on Hollywood Boulevard in Los Feliz. 

The group behind the artwork showcased the GOP presidential nominee in the buff in order to present him in the most humiliating way possible, according to The Washington Post. 

A spokesman for the group told the newspaper they do not believe the statues will be up for long. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/6CJ3s
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Three men have been arrested in connection with the close-range fatal shooting of a 24-year-old man who was sitting in his parked car at gas station in Buena Park last month, police announced this morning. 

Investigators released this surveillance video showing the moments before Maher Yousef was shot in the head in the hopes that it would lead to arrests in the case. 

Police say Yousef was likely targeted because he worked at check-cashing business, and that the armed men demanded money from him before the fatal shooting. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/uTFK0

Dozens of big rigs have packed the Pilot Travel Center as the 15 Freeway remains closed through Hesperia Wednesday morning due to the Blue Cut Fire.

No estimate has been given on when the freeway would reopen.

The fire has burned an unknown number of homes and businesses, including the landmark Summit Inn Restaurant in Oak Hills. Evacuation orders were in place for more than 80,000 people.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/yK3mF

EMS workers in Connecticut came to the aid of a squirrel that was frantically jumping around the agency's driveway trying to free its trapped head from a yogurt cup. 

"This was in our own driveway, it just worked out ... that the crews happened to be here," Enfield EMS Chief Gary Wiemokly said. "We don't go looking for animals in distress, and we really do not have an animal response team."  

The yogurt cup was eventually removed, and the squirrel quickly scurried away. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/K3zTM

Update: Gov. Jerry Brown has declared a state of emergency in the fast-moving Blue Cut Fire that has exploded to 15,000 acres and forced more than 82,000 people out of their homes since it broke out Tuesday morning in the Cajon Pass, officials said.

The blaze comes amid a heat wave and as firefighters are battling six large wildfires elsewhere in California. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/NxQwA

"I'm going to write my name, and do my ABC's and 123's," an excited Marcelle Coleman said as he headed to an elementary school classroom for his first day of school. 

Marcelle was among the hundreds of thousands of LAUSD students who headed back to school Tuesday morning as the new term kicked off. 

The little boy was accompanied by his 4-year-old sister, who -- although wearing a backpack -- wasn't quite old enough to start with her older brother, and seemed a tad disappointed about that. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/NLwI1

Rudy Giuliani, who was the mayor of New York City during the 9/11 terror attacks, said Monday that the U.S. did not face "any successful radical Islamic terrorist attacks" before President Obama took office in 2008.

Guiliani made the comments during a Donald Trump rally, moments after referencing Mike Pence's visit to ground zero. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/xqgAm

Dramatic video captured the last-minute rescue of a woman trapped in her sinking car amid rising floodwaters in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, over the weekend. 

Unable to break one of the car's windows, a rescuer jumped into the water and managed to rip open the top of the convertible and pull the woman to safety. 

The rescuer even went back and saved a dog that was also trapped in the car. 

The historic flooding has left at least 5 people dead and waters were expected to continue to rise on Monday. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/pw29e

Aerial drone footage out of Louisiana shows just how bad the widespread flooding is in Lafayette. Vehicles and homes can be seen partially submerged as waters continue to rise.

The governor has called it a "truly historic event" and deployed the Louisiana National Guard. At least three people have died as a result of the flooding. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/lOvgJ

When a suspected car thief started twerking in front of a Florida judge his dance drew laughs among many in the courtroom, but Judge Catherine M. Pooler was not amused. 

Calvin Lloyd Griffith, 30, broke out with the dance during a bond hearing after he allegedly took a car from a Miami high school earlier in the day. 

Pooler set his bond at $18,500. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/YHIa5

Thanks to the kindness of strangers, a single mother and her children have been reunited with the pets they had to surrender at an animal shelter in Carson after fleeing their abusive home.

The family could only afford a small apartment where pets were not allowed.

After watching the heartbroken family leave their pets behind, the shelter shared their story on Facebook and thousands of people responded.

Last week, they were reunited with their pets who are now being fostered by a volunteer until the family can find a home that allows animals.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/0vkR6

Grainy surveillance video shows a mother saving her 14-month-old from a would-be kidnapper after the strange woman tried to unbuckle the toddler from a stroller on a Glendale sidewalk.

It was one of two similar attempted kidnappings that occurred less than a mile apart and within a half-hour Wednesday.

The attempted kidnapper said something like "you're so cute" while approaching both young children, a Glendale police sergeant said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/TkZR3

Donald J. Trump's suggestion that "Second Amendment people" could do something about Hillary Clinton's possible selection of Supreme Court justices raised alarms Tuesday.

The GOP candidate's ambiguous comments in Wilmington, North Carolina, led observers to question whether he was threatening his opponent's life or calling for increased political activity.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/xlDNt

A man accidentally lit himself on fire when he attempted to start a blaze outside a business in Kentucky, and the incident was caught on a surveillance camera. 

The video was released Monday by the Madisonville Police Department, which is asking for the public's help to locate the arsonist. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/nlD6I

Metal security bars nearly kept a woman trapped inside her burning Vermont Knolls neighborhood home Tuesday morning. 

As smoke and fire were filling the home, rescuers managed to use a saw to cut the bars away in time for two officers and a firefighter to pull the woman out of the window. 

"It's just a team effort. We're just fortunate that she's OK and that she made it," one of the officers said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/KGsz6

Video posted on Facebook of a mouse running through the produce section of a market in Covina triggered an investigation by the Health Department on Monday.

Shopper Alejandro Rivera told KTLA he spotted a mouse running across the vegetable counter and shot video of the rodent.

Rivera said he alerted a security guard who called over his supervisor and they grabbed the mouse, put it in a bag and disappeared with it.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Xpd18

Update: The California Highway Patrol pursued a white Lexus sedan in connection with a possible carjacking on Monday afternoon, taking the driver into custody after he surrendered in a Pico Rivera parking lot. Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/SBYTu

Dramatic footage shot near the Pilot Fire shows the intense flames firefighters are facing as they work to contain the out-of-control wildfire. 

The blaze has charred 4,500 acres since it erupted near Silverwood Lake early Sunday afternoon, and is five percent contained. 

No structures have been lost, but evacuation orders and road closures remain in effect, officials say. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/br6Jg

A "rapidly growing" fire burning east of Silverwood Lake in the San Bernardino Mountains has grown to 1,000 acres within a few hours, authorities say. 

The so-called Pilot Fire is burning in a sparsely populated area north of Crestline, but some evacuations have been ordered and portions of two local highways have been closed. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/YfxJd

A woman was caught on camera beating a man on the Metro Blue Line in Long Beach and now the Sheriff's Department is investigating. 

 The man allegedly yelled racist remarks at the woman, prompting the attack.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/n8UFD

An Ohio state trooper is seen being thrown into the air during a traffic stop in dashcam video that captured the crash on the side of a highway.

Sgt. Jim Smith had pulled over a driver when he was hit by a second vehicle. He sustained minor injuries and is expected to make a full recovery.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/dZbfn

In one of nine dramatic videos released by the Chicago police oversight board Friday, an officer shoots multiple times at Paul O'Neal, an unarmed 18-year-old who was killed by a gunshot to his back.

After a chase and crash involving a suspected stolen car, O'Neal was fired on and ran behind a home, where he was handcuffed face down as he lay bleeding onto the ground. 

The fatal shot was not recorded because the officer's bodycam wasn't working, police say. The shooting has prompted a lawsuit, and three officers have been relieved of their police powers.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/VfCek

At a Donald J. Trump rally in Maine Thursday, a group of protesters stood up and silently held up pocket copies of the U.S. Constitution. They drew boos and jeers from the crowd and were quickly escorted out.

The protesters' actions comes a week after Khizr Khan held up a copy of the Constitution at the Democratic National Convention, questioning whether Trump had read it and saying he would gladly loan his copy to the GOP candidate.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/ke5tV

Update: Flames are seen leaping into the air after a backhoe struck a 4-inch gas line in the Woodland Hills area Wednesday afternoon.

Homes have been evacuated. The Los Angeles FD and Southern California Gas Company (SoCalGas) are responding.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/oYElm

It's not unusual for bears to cool off in backyard swimming pools on a hot day, but these two cubs found an outdoor planter to be much more comfortable. 

This video, submitted by Sainty Wang and Carlos Chavez, was shot from behind a sliding glass door as an adult bear was also photographed in the yard. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/zoKtg

A military mom was loudly booed when she asked GOP vice presidential nominee Mike Pence a question that was critical of Donald Trump at a campaign event in Nevada.

The woman, named Catherine, pressed Pence on Trump's controversial feud with Khizr Khan, whose U.S. Army captain son was killed in Iraq in 2004.

"My son is currently serving in the U.S. Air Force ... Trump has disrespected our nation's armed forces and veterans, and his disrespect for Mr. Khan and his family is just an example of that," she said. "Will there ever be a point in time when you're able to look at Trump in the eye, and tell him enough is enough?"

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/47ecr

After telling the mother of a crying baby not to worry about the child interrupting his campaign stop in Ashburn, Virginia, Donald J. Trump apparently had a reversal of opinion when the baby began wailing again.

"Actually I was only kidding. You can get the baby out of here," Trump said Tuesday. "I think she really believed me that I love having a baby crying while I'm speaking."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/mysDf
Watch the KTLA 5 Morning News on Tuesday for your chance to win a pair of tickets to see the Tchaikovsky Spectacular with Fireworks on Aug. 6, thanks to our partners at the LA Phil.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Bystanders braved rushing flood waters in Maryland and linked arms to save a woman who became trapped in her car over the weekend.

"I will never forget that because that tells me what the people of Ellicott City are like. That tells me that's what people in Howard County are like," one man said after seeing the video.

The recent floods have devastated downtown Ellicott City, killing two people and destroying or damaging at least 25 buildings.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/x5cCd

A long pursuit that saw a driver lead authorities from Long Beach to San Diego County came to a wild finish Monday morning. 

Aerial video from Sky5 showed the driver continue to try to escape even after colliding with several vehicles, losing the back bumper of her car and driving through a front lawn. 

The driver was initially wanted for failure to yield. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/TkVzw

Rescuers held the head of a 13-year-old horse named "Cupcake" above water after the horse fell in a rural area near Denver Thursday. 

The dramatic rescue -- live-tweeted by South Metro Fire Rescue -- sparked a big reaction on social media, and soon #savingcupcake was trending nationally. 

After about two hours, rescuers were able to pull Cupcake out of the water and get her back on her feet. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/2wFX7

Update: Hillary Clinton made history Thursday by accepting her role as the first female nominee of a major political party at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia. 

"When there are no ceilings, the sky's the limit," she said during her acceptance speech. "So let's keep going, until every one of the 161 million women and girls across America has the opportunity she deserves."

Read KTLA's story here: on.ktla.com/rSubd #DemsInPhilly

Students taking a night photography class got incredibly lucky when the dark sky lit up from Utah to California Wednesday evening. The astonishing sight, which turned out to be the remnants of a Chinese rocket re-entering the atmosphere, prompted speculation across social media.

Studying with CreativeLive in the Alabama Hills in the Eastern Sierra, the students used a high-quality camera to capture this amazing video.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/DpfUV
link_name: CreativeLive Night Photography Class Captures 'Fireball Over C...

status_message:
"For my friend Hillary Clinton, I humbly accept my party's nomination to be vice president of the United States," Tim Kaine said during a prime-time adress at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/ZKr8V

"Trump says global warming is a hoax; I say Trump is a fraud. Trump says there's no drought in California; I say Trump lies." 

Gov. Jerry Brown had some tough words for Donald J. Trump during his speech at the Democratic National Convention, criticizing the Republican presidential nominee and the GOP over their denial of climate change. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/c2Oba
Watch live: Former President Bill Clinton is speaking now at the Democratic convention in Philadelphia. Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/8t2Ny #DemsInPhilly

This electrifying video captured the exact moment lightning hit the Empire State Building during a storm in Manhattan Monday.

The storm came during a heat wave that sent temperatures in New York soaring into the high 90s.

The Empire State Building is struck by lightning an average of 23 times per year, but it's rarely caught on camera.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/utDzQ

"Hillary Clinton will make an outstanding president and I am proud to stand with her tonight," Sen. Bernie Sanders told Democrats at the party's convention in Philadelphia on Monday night. Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/NY75w #DemsInPhilly

Video from Sky5 shows the Sand Fire continuing to rage on its fourth day burning east of Santa Clarita, where the wildfire has destroyed homes and forced some 20,000 residents to flee.

At least 52 square miles have burned. "Imagine that: 10,000 football fields a day," a fire incident commander said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/rgj5O

A satellite image released by NASA on Monday shows what a pair of massive California wildfires -- the Sand and Soberanes fires -- look like from space. 

The Sand Fire has charred some 52 square miles in the Santa Clarita area, destroying 18 homes and resulting in the evacuation of about 10,000 residences. 

To the north, the 15,000-acre Soberanes Fire has burned 20 homes to the ground near Big Sur and is just 5 percent contained. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/rgj5O
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Chilling surveillance video shows the moment a woman was dragged away by a tiger before her mother was mauled to death at a Beijing safari park.  

The 57-year-old woman rushed to help her daughter, who had been knocked down and dragged away by a tiger after stepping out of the white sedan. 

A second tiger attacked the older woman, killing her on the spot, authorities said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/VBRnD

A "major emergency fire" broke out in downtown L.A. after flames erupted at a pallet yard Saturday evening.

Los Angeles FD firefighters were in defensive mode on one structure and offensive mode on another they were trying to save.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/1dor0

Update: Cellphone video taken from Sylmar by KTLA viewer Michelle S shows smoke billowing above the 20,000-acre Sand Fire, which prompted the evacuation of 1,500 homes east of Santa Clarita.

Ash is raining down miles away, and smoke blotted out the sun for much of Saturday. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Yum10

The sun appeared to be a red color when it rose over the Santa Clarita Valley Saturday morning after a brush fire in the area exploded to 5,500 acres overnight. 

The raging Sand Fire has prompted mandatory evacuations for hundreds of residents and destroyed at least one structure, authorities say. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Yum10

Sky5 just captured this giant column of smoke coming from a fast-moving brush fire in the Santa Clarita area.

The blaze, dubbed the Sand Fire, has already burned 1,500 acres off the 14 Freeway. It is at 0 percent containment. 

Evacuations are in effect from Soledad Canyon to Agua Dulce Canyon Road.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/jhtJ0

Update: Video captured a gunman opening fire on a small group of people outside of a McDonald's restaurant at a shopping mall in Munich, Germany, on Friday. Six people have been reported killed and others wounded. 

The video below was posted to Facebook by user Felix Urbauer. 
 
Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/iMyIP

Donald Trump formally accepted the GOP's presidential nomination during his speech at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland tonight. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/JGMND #RNCinCLE

Firefighters worked quickly to rescue a trapped German shepherd after its head became stuck beneath a metal fence. 

As the dog whimpered and struggled, firefighters cut the metal bars to free the canine from the tight spot, dramatic video posted by the West Sacramento Fire Department showed. 

The German shepherd was uninjured, and "happy and healthy" following the incident, the department said. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/pMxAZ

In a moment she captured on GoPro video, a professional flutist who likes to play her instrument for whales got quite a surprise while paddleboarding off Half Moon Bay.

A juvenile humpback whale leapt out of the water right next to her, Viviana Guzman Flutist says.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/ioFBX

Sky5 captured the wild ending to a pursuit, in which a suspected car thief was tackled by a Los Angeles police officer in Hawthorne Wednesday night. 

The 25-minute chase ended at a Chevron station where the man got out of the car but remained near the open door while he talked to officers. 

He began to flee from authorities after he was apparently struck by a Taser from one of the officers. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/oY8n7

Ted Cruz withheld an endorsement of Donald Trump at the Republican National Convention, earning a chorus of boos from the floor and chants of "We want Trump."

"Don't stay in home in November," Cruz said toward the end of his speech. "Stand and speak and vote your conscience."

Cruz was upstaged by the GOP nominee himself, who suddenly walked in to the arena at the end of the Texas senator's address to join his family in a VIP area. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/IYhX8

Donald Trump's running mate Mike Pence accepted the vice presidential nomination during his speech at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland Wednesday night. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/S31QF #RNCinCLE

"You're on fire. You're on fire, stupid." 

A Cleveland police officer could be heard yelling those words at a protester after an American flag was set ablaze outside the Republican National Convention Wednesday afternoon. 

Multiple people have been arrested and two officers were injured as clashes broke out during the demonstration, which took place before the third night of the GOP convention. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/V9a7X

A purse snatcher dragged a 95-year-old woman several feet in an incident outside a Memphis shopping mall that was captured on surveillance video earlier this week. 

The elderly victim, who was walking with a cane as she approached one of the mall's shops on Monday, was unable to let go of her purse when a man nearby grabbed it and began to run away. 

The woman was hospitalized with non-critical injuries and police are searching for the thief. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/1KqTy

A 93-year-old woman in Rowland Heights was tricked into allowing three strangers into her home who ended up stealing all of her most valuable possessions, including her engagement ring and late husband's wedding band.

The thieves got into the home by saying they were relatives of the elderly woman's neighbor and one of them needed to use the bathroom. 

"These people, they're not human," the victim's son said. "That night she was crying. She wanted to end her life."

Anyone recognizing the robbers was asked to contact the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department's Walnut/Diamond Bar station at 909-595-2264.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/IKMEp
Donald Trump Jr., the son of 2016 GOP presidential nominee Donald Trump, addresses the Republican National Convention in Ohio. Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/iaYMB #RNCinCLE

Incredible video captured by Instagram user @peccheck shows flames leaping from a brush fire that broke out in the Hollywood Hills on Tuesday.

Some 200 firefighters responded to the 18-acre blaze, which sent smoke towering above the Cahuenga Pass.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/ZiXPk

A mourning mother rebuked Black Lives Matter at an LAPD news conference where a $50,000 reward was announced in the killing into her 21-year-old son.

"Black lives only matter to people when the law enforcement is involved," she said. "It's a black man that killed my kid, so how can people preach black lives matter?"

Gerrik Mykul Thomas was a nursing student who worked as a security guard. He was not a gang member, but he was shot dead in Hyde Park Jan. 25 after being asked where he was from.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/zoInb

Side-by-side comparisons of the transcripts show the text in Melania Trump's address following, nearly to the word, the would-be future first lady's own from the first night of the Democratic convention in Denver nearly eight years ago.

Donald Trump's campaign denied the plagiarism allegations Tuesday.

"To think that she would do something like that knowing how scrutinized her speech was going to be last night is just really absurd," Trump's campaign chairman said.

The father of Jamiel Shaw Jr., a standout Los Angeles High School football player who was fatally shot execution style by a gang member in the U.S. illegally, spoke Monday evening at the Republican convention in Ohio. 

Jamiel Shaw Sr. has been a vocal supporter of Donald J. Trump since 2015. Shaw was joined on stage by speakers Mary Ann Mendoza and Sabine Durden.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/pKZc2 #RNCinCLE

"There's no need to be fearful of something that's inanimate," said a man openly carrying a rifle near the site of the Republican National Convention in Cleveland, an Instagram video showed. "Nothing's going to happen because I'm not going to be doing anything stupid."

Meanwhile, the head of the city's largest police union called on Ohio's governor to temporarily suspend the state's open carry gun laws during the convention and following the fatal shooting of three law enforcement officers in Baton Rouge, Louisiana.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/b9rjQ

(Video credit: Matt Pearce/Los Angeles Times)

It pays to be nice at one Virginia coffee shop. Add a "please" and "hello" to your order, and that cup of coffee goes from $5 to $1.75.

CUPS Coffee & Tea employee Austin Simms told a local TV station that he wrote the sign as a joke.

"I decided because I need to solve all the injustices of the world to start charging more for people who didn't take the time to say hello and connect and realize we're all people behind the counter," Simms said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/9WYS1
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Niya Mann suffered tremendous heartbreak last weekend: her husband and both her young children were killed in a car crash on the 91 Freeway. 

She opened up Wednesday night about her grief during an emotional candlelight vigil held for Lavell Mann, a fitness trainer, and the couple's two children, 3-year-old Logan and 9-month-old Legend. 

"It's just tough knowing that I don't have my husband to talk to about my kids, or my kids to talk to about their father," Niya Mann said. "I have no one."

She said she is being carried through the tragedy by her faith, along with help from her family members and friends.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/MDAof

The Fresno Police Department released body-camera footage of officers fatally shooting Dylan Noble, an unarmed 19-year-old man.

Police Chief Jerry Dyer acknowledged that the footage is "extremely disturbing" to watch, but he said he hoped it would clarify what led officers to stop Noble and open fire.

The officers gave about 30 commands for Noble to show his hands or lay on the ground, the chief said. Noble was ultimately shot four times; the object in his hand was determined to be a 4-inch plastic container.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/xnCfq

"How'd you get in there, bear?" a sheriff's deputy asked a black bear that somehow trapped itself in a Subaru in Colorado.

Deputies responded after the car's 17-year-old owner called 911 when she woke up and saw the bear inside her vehicle, which had been left unlocked. The bear couldn't seem to free itself.

After about 20 minutes, the deputies got the station wagon's back hatch open and the bear scurried into the wild. The interior of the Subaru was pretty much destroyed. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/1hZNQ

A powerful photo from Tuesday's memorial for the five officers killed in Dallas captured mourning police holding hands during "The Battle Hymn of the Republic."

"The soul of our city was pierced when police officers were ambushed in a cowardly attack," Dallas Mayor Mike Rawlings told the crowd. "While we did nothing wrong, there is a reason this happened here, this place, this time in American history. This is our chance to lead and build a new model, for a community, for a city, for our country."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/FMxmP
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
The Los Angeles FD's North Hollywood station was quick to respond to the Dare to Dance Challenge in support of a nearly 3-year-old Corona girl with cerebral palsy who cannot walk on her own.

Finley Smallwood of Corona is a candidate for a potentially life-changing surgery, her parents say, and now they're raising money for the operation and awareness about her disorder with their dance challenge.

"All we ask is that people just dance for Finley," her mom said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/HmoOa

A powerful expression of support and empathy was caught on video outside an interfaith service in Dallas Friday afternoon.

As hundreds of community members left the service, an impromptu line began to form of people waiting to hug several officers with the Dallas Police Department who were on duty at the gathering.

In one instance, an officer can be seen wiping away a tear.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/O1yPr

Rappers The Game and Snoop Dogg led a unification march Friday morning to LAPD headquarters, where the graduation ceremony for its newest officers was being held. 

Snoop Dogg told KTLA in an interview that the point of the peaceful demonstration was to reintroduce police to members of the community it serves and to get a dialogue going. 

"The mission is to reintroduce our community to the LAPD... just to get some understanding and dialogue," he said. "We're the ones they're going to be dealing with, we're the ones that are going to be pulled over. â€¦ We're here on peace."

Watch KTLA's interview with Snoop Dogg and The Game here: http://ktlane.ws/29raxOo

"What if this happened to somebody in your family? How would you feel?" President Barack Obama said to those who question others' outraged responses to recent police shootings.

Most Americans think the shootings are a problem we should all care about, Obama said, addressing the deaths of Alton Sterling in Louisiana and Philando Castile in Minnesota.

"To be concerned â€¦ is not political correctness; it's just being American and wanting to live up to our best and highest ideals," the president said. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/TWEXK

Fire crews needed a rope to help pull a man out of a chimney at home in Hyde Park Thursday morning.

The man told authorities he hid in the chimney to get away from someone who was chasing him.

After the rescue, the man shook hands with firefighters and managed to climb down a ladder on his own. No arrests were made. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/29ncE5A

Seconds after this video ends, the man in the driver's seat was fatally shot in the head at close range.

Buena Park police released the video in hope of finding the three armed men who surrounded and tried to rob 24-year-old Maher Yousef at a gas station. 

The gunmen got away with nothing, and Yousef died at the hospital.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/lCx6Q

Two new litters of mountain lion kittens have been born in the eastern Santa Susana Mountains, and they're the stars of a new video released by the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area.

The five kittens â€” two females in one litter, and two males and another female in the other â€” have been ear-tagged. They're believed to have the same father, whose radio collar showed him visiting with the two mothers before they gave birth this spring.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Umeuw

"As a mother I have now been forced to raise a son, who is going to remember what happened to his father, that I can't take away from him," the mother of Alton Sterling's 15-year-old son said during a news conference Wednesday.

Sterling was fatally shot as he was pinned down by two officers outside a convenience store in Louisiana early Tuesday morning.

Sterling's son broke down in tears and had to be consoled at one point during the news conference.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/ipS1G

The man shown in this brief video clip is a "violent sexual predator" who attacked two women as they walked alone in the West Los Angeles area near Santa Monica, according to LAPD.

The attacker grabbed his victims, dragged them away, forced them to the ground and sexually assaulted them. One woman in her 20s was punched repeatedly to "quiet her," an LAPD captain said.

The captain urged people not to walk alone in the area until the man is caught.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/GdQxl

Barack Obama, America's dad-in-chief, sang "Happy Birthday" to his daughter Malia at a White House celebration.

Flanked by Kendrik Lamar and Janelle Monae, the president serenaded his eldest daughter on the Fourth of July, the birthday she shares with the United States.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/TqiOl

Motorcyclist Jon Carlo said that he was riding down Beverly Boulevard in Koreatown when he was struck by a car at Serrano Avenue.

Carlo urged the hit-and-run driver to turn himself in: "It just blows my mind that there are people out there who would just flee from an accident like that. I just don't understand how people can do that. ... He made a bad situation even worse for himself."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/3oPi7

A bald eagle that was supposed to fly from the top of Dodger Stadium to its handler on the field as part of the team's pregame festivities on the Fourth of July instead briefly gained its freedom.

Footage of the incident showed the majestic bird being circling the field multiple times before it apparently missed its handler and flew into the parking lot. 

An announcement was made midway during the game that the bald eagle was eventually caught. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/4qhkZ

#KeepDancingOrlando â€” that's the viral challenge to help the city heal being shared in the wake of the deadly shooting at the Pulse nightclub. 

From forensic investigators to motorcycle officers, the Orange County Sheriff's Office, Florida recently took up the challenge to the tune of Whitney Houston's "I Wanna Dance With Somebody," saying on Facebook: "Hundreds of OCSO employees came together as a unit, group or individually to demonstrate that we stand together united with our community and as Americans."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Dr50d

A state parks supervisor towed a dead dolphin across the sand in front of families at the beach in Ventura during Fourth of July weekend, and it was captured on video by a father who called the sight "disturbing."

Removing the dolphin from the crowded beach that way was the best solution to a "difficult situation," the harbormaster said. The practice will be reviewed to see "how we might make the relocation of deceased animals more agreeable to the public," a Harbor Patrol news release said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/8qUwu

It was a scary moment for eight passengers, mostly children, who were trapped about 100 feet in the air when their roller coaster stalled just before its first big drop. 

The riders were trapped atop Frontier City's Silver Bullet Coaster in Oklahoma City for more than an hour Wednesday before rescue crews finally got them all to safety. 

Most of the riders were between the ages of 7 and 15 years old. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/GzNZ9

A brazen thief was seen on video sneaking into a woman's car in West Los Angeles as she was pumping gas just a few feet away.

The thief, along with his apparent lookout and another person, got away with the victim's wallet but their actions were all captured on the Mobil station's surveillance video.

Anyone who recognizes the men seen in the video was asked to call police. A $5,000 reward is being offered in the case.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/08FoA

Los Angeles County transportation officials are using a scared straight approach to encourage rail safety.

In a new series of public safety announcements, the MTA warns about the danger of being decapitated, dismembered â€” or pulverized. Thankfully it uses a fleshed-out stick figure character to make its case.

Metro released the videos on Wednesday that show the gruesome reality â€” albeit in cartoon style â€” of being killed by a train.

The "Safetyville" campaign by Metro has received nearly 1 million views on Facebook, YouTube and Instagram combined.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/NEoPL

A police helicopter crew member hopped out of his aircraft and tackled a burglary suspect at the unusual end of a pursuit in Houston Tuesday.

As the suspect tried to flee in a grassy field, he was first struck by a police SUV and then taken down by the helmeted crew member, with the whole thing caught on video by a local news station.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/e15Td

A woman's stirring rendition of the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial has been viewed millions of times and earned widespread praise after video of the impromptu performance was posted to Facebook.

Star Genleah Swain's beautiful voice prompted many to stop what they were doing to listen to her sing; by the time she finished, a large crowd gave her a rousing ovation. 

Some Facebook users said they were moved to tears by the heartfelt performance, while others commented that she should sing the national anthem at the next Super Bowl. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/c7yIj

Meet Sweepee Rambo, the newly crowned "ugliest dog in the world." 

The 4-pound dog, who is blind in both eyes and wears "doggie Depends," has been with her owner Jason Wurtz for the past 15 years. 

She may have the title, but to Wurtz she's absolutely perfect. 

In the entry for the competition, he called his beloved pet "the prettiest little blue eyed Chinese Crescent Chihuahua he's ever known."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/k20rY
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Update: Flames burned dangerously close to KTLA reporter Steve Kuzj and photographer Victor Vargas after fire crews started lighting backfires that quickly burned toward their truck. 

Seconds later, the heat became unbearable as Kuzj and Vargas rushed to pack up their truck and get out of the area safely. 

The Erskine Fire in Kern County has burned 19,000 acres and destroyed about 100 structures in just 18 hours since it started on Thursday. 
 
Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Nlixr

Firefighters are battling a 5,000-acre wildfire that is burning out of control and has destroyed an estimated 80 homes in Lake Isabella Thursday, according to the Kern County Fire Department.

The Erskine Fire was burning south of Hwy 178 in Squirrel Valley in Kern County.

Evacuation orders were in effect for South Lake, Lakeland Estates, Mountain Mesa, Squirrel Valley and Yankee Canyon.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/oUhDT

The newest robot from Google's Boston Dynamics does the dishes and serves drinks. It's also the butt of jokes, apparently.

In a just-released video, the SpotMini slips on a banana peel and hits the floor hard. But the 55-pound robot rebounds, quickly climbing up the stairs.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/sDF18

A woman seen taking items from properties in the remote northwest Antelope Valley is wanted for questioning by L.A. County sheriff's investigators.

At the time of the June 4 incidents, the woman was wearing a yellow bikini bottom and green bikini top.

If you know who she is, contact authorities.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/IeJVE
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Amid a record-breaking heat wave, thousands of state, local and federal firefighters are continuing to battle wildfires burning across California Tuesday.

Here, firefighters on the 5,400-acre San Gabriel Complex fires get a chance to take a break from the work in the heat.

"It is just super hot," L.A. County fire Capt. Mike McCormick said. "You go through a gallon and a half, 2 gallons of water in a day."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/MC7PU
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
A bizarre and hostile confrontation between an Uber driver and a Leimert Park man who accidentally left his cellphone in the driver's car earlier in the day was captured on surveillance video. 

CJ Yu told KTLA he offered the driver a reward for bringing the phone back, but the driver became angry at the amount of money and threatened him. 

The video shows the Uber driver carrying what appears to be a large stone and walking toward Yu. Later in the video, the driver is seen running back to his vehicle after Yu says he stole the cellphone he had just returned. 

Yu was working with detectives to locate the driver. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/xvcZW

Look to the skies Monday night and you'll be treated to a possibly once-in-a-lifetime event. 

For the first time in nearly 70 years, the summer solstice will coincide with a full "Strawberry" moon, according to the Farmer's Almanac. 

Monday's full moon is the only night in the month when the moon is visible in the sky all evening long.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Ljo3b
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
A reward was being offered Friday for a family dog who was caught on surveillance video escaping from the Pooch Pet Hotel in Hollywood.

The video shows "Cash" opening the door of his pen and then running through the lobby before pushing open a door to the street.

That was last Saturday. Since then, his owners Louis Angelo and Talita Trygsland have been organizing searches throughout the Hollywood area as well as posting fliers, according to a post on the "Finding Cash" Facebook page.

"Cash is a rescue dog with separation anxiety. He is very attached to his mom and dad who love him very much. He is very friendly with humans, not so comfortable with other dogs. He is fearful of loud sounds and wind and is easily startled," the post stated.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/sUZw2

Attempting to show vulnerability in hopes of receiving a lesser sentence for the murder of his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp, disgraced Paralympian Oscar Pistorius walked without his prostheses and started weeping in court Wednesday.

Murder carries a minimum sentence of 15 years in South Africa, but the defense is trying to secure a lesser sentence by arguing there are mitigating factors, including Pistorius' physical and emotional disabilities.

"He was anxious, he was frightened. â€¦ He was suffering from anxiety disorder, and that's not gone," Roux said. "This must all be seen in context of his disability," his attorney said.

Pistorius is expected to learn his fate by Friday.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/ilAxf

The 24-story Monaco Tower at the Riviera Hotel and Casino â€” the first high-rise on the Las Vegas Strip when it opened in 1955 â€” was imploded early Tuesday morning in a dramatic display.

Associated with mobsters and featured in multiple Hollywood films, the hotel was demolished to make way for an expansion of convention facilities. The Monte Carlo tower will come down later this summer.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/UtF8V

Update: A magnesium-fueled fire in Maywood has prompted evacuations, power outages and a warning about smoke and odors across parts of Los Angeles County.

"The problem with magnesium is when water goes on it, it violently reacts," a fire official said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/KcUi9

After Nicole Lencioni woke up to the news of the mass shooting in Orlando, she felt compelled to honor the victims in some way.

"I'm literally here standing for something," she said at L.A. Pride in West Hollywood, holding a rainbow-flag sign with the words 'We Are With You Orlando.' "I'm standing for the sign.

"I just want them to know that we're thinking about them," she added.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/DPFO5

"I am one of the 11 million undocumented immigrants living in the shadows of the United States," valedictorian Larissa Martinez announced during her graduation speech at McKinney Boyd High School in Texas.

Martinez said she fled to Texas from Mexico with her mother and sister, and grew up caring for her sister while her mother worked from morning until night. 

The graduate described her efforts to become a U.S. citizen, but said "the U.S. immigration system is broken" and she has waited seven years for her application to be processed.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/e8Wdj

Xander Hendriks was with his parents and two brothers watching the Baja 500 in Ensenada last weekend when one of the race competitors lost control of his truck.

The San Clemente family tried to run to safety, but the 8-year-old and his mother didn't make it in time. Xander was killed and his mother was seriously injured.

Brandon Hendriks, a youth pastor at Pacific Coast Church, and his wife Melissa broke their silence Thursday about their tragic loss in order to let people know how special their young son was and to urge friends and family to share memories of him.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/rAsIu

The San Diego Zoo released this video of a 3-week-old baby red ruffed lemur, the first of its rare species to be born at the zoo in 13 years.

"Ony" weighs in at just 9.2 ounces. His mom is doing a great job of caring for him, but he gets daily weigh-ins to make sure he's growing well, according to the zoo.

The zoo says it's working to bring red ruffed lemurs back from the brink of extinction.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/5aWzk

A wandering black bear took a dip in a La CaÃ±ada Flintridge pool on Wednesday, and Sky5 was overhead.

California Department of Fish and Wildlife wardens are responding.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/SRMZD

A brazen kidnapping attempt was captured on surveillance video as a man tried to drag a 13-year-old girl out of a Dollar General store in Florida. 

"In my 10 years I have never seen an instance like this in broad daylight in a public area," a sheriff's official said. 

The girl's mother could be seen struggling with the would-be kidnapper before finally throwing herself on top of her daughter to keep her from being pulled outside.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/YmDMZ
Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders addresses supporters at a Santa Monica Airport hangar. Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/KSB7j
Presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton delivers remarks from Brooklyn, New York. Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/hScAC
Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump delivers remarks at the Trump National Golf Club in Briarcliff Manor, New York. Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Uia9o

A zookeeper at the Oregon Zoo captured this video of a playful black bear named Takoda enjoying a soak â€” and some toys â€” in his tub.

Takoda, which means "friend to all" in Sioux, was orphaned in Montana and has called the zoo in Portland home since November 2010.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/7wBMx

Veterinarians are hopeful an abused Labrador mix found with patches of missing skin and gashes all over his body is headed toward recovery after being chained and left to die in a park in Compton. 

"I just don't understand that kind of sickness that makes anybody want to hurt any animal," said a volunteer helping to treat the dog, named Phoenix. 

Volunteers believe Phoenix was dragged by his chains before he was found in some bushes over Memorial Day weekend. A search is underway for whoever abused Phoenix.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/lvfz5

Donald Trump described a black supporter as "my African-American" after pointing him out during a rally in Redding on Friday. 

"Oh, look at my African-American over here. Look at him," Trump said. "Are you the greatest?"

Trump campaign spokeswoman Hope Hicks said "There's no ill will intended, obviously." She added Trump was "grateful for this person's support."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/69sKZ

Update: Los Angeles County Sheriff's officials arrested a driver in Hacienda Heights who fled on foot after driving a vehicle on the wrong side of the road, running red lights and crashing into at least one car. Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/U0N1i

The father who lunged at the man who killed and mutilated his daughter is speaking out, saying he attacked the convicted serial killer in court to wipe the smile off his face. 

I wanted to break his jaw and get that grin off his face ... If we're being honest," Van Terry said of Michael Madison, who has been sentenced to death. 

The grieving father may be charged in connection with the incident, but Terry says he would be OK with that. 

"I call it a father feeling his pain," Terry told a local TV station of his actions. "And if I did get charged, I'm alright with that. Because I did what I felt was right."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/uCi9R

A 2-day-old sea otter pup that had drifted away due to strong sea tides off Morro Bay is back in her mother's arms thanks to rescuers with the Marine Mammal Center.

Video posted on the organization's Facebook page showed the crying pup being tossed into the water near the mother's location. Within seconds, the mother otter appears.

"Her mother rises from the sea, wraps the pup in what appears to be a hug and pulls her underwater," the post stated.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/TMlEp

An 18-year-old Pakistani schoolteacher died after she was set on fire for refusing a marriage proposal, according to police.

Four men barged into the home of Maria Abbasi's parents, where she was babysitting her 5-year-old sister. The men beat Abbasi, drenched her in gasoline and set her body ablaze before leaving her for dead, her family members said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/BUMpm
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message: BREAKING: The shooting at UCLA was a murder-suicide, police just confirmed. LAPD Chief Charlie Beck also said the issue has been contained and police hope to clear the campus soon. Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/2SWyn

Two tiny, blue-eyed bobcat kittens were captured on video just weeks after they were born in the Santa Monica Mountains.

Biologist Joanne Moriarty was monitoring the movements of Bobcat-339 earlier this spring when she noticed the animal appeared to be creating a den, according to a post on the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area's Facebook page.

Rangers used the bobcat's GPS history to locate the den last month and discovered the kittens.

The two little brothers, which have been dubbed B-340 and B-341, were measured, examined and tagged.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/GndQM

Secret Service agents jumped into action to protect Bernie Sanders after several protesters tried to rush the stage during a rally in Oakland on Monday.

The Democratic presidential candidate was uninjured and continued speaking until several agents grabbed him and pushed him away from the microphone. 

Afterward, Sanders told the crowd, "We don't get intimidated easily."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/a9Avz

From prison to Columbia University graduate. 

At 67, ex-drug dealer David Norman recently proved that if you keep chasing your dreams, you will eventually succeed. He was the oldest person in his class to graduate from the Ivy League institution this year. 

In addition to his studies, Norman -- who has maintained a drug-free life for over 20 years -- also serves as a mentor to those who have been incarcerated.

"When my perspective changed, my life changed," he says of his transformation. "Whatever happens outside has to begin inside."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/0lZa5
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
An onboard camera captured remarkable footage as a SpaceX booster rocket landed on the deck of a floating platform off the coast of Florida.

The sped-up video was tweeted by the company's CEO, Elon Musk, after the launch of Falcon 9, a rocket that sent a communications satellite into orbit.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/uVBhb

A puppy named Bubba who tested positive for meth and heroin after being seized during a drug bust in Tustin was reunited Wednesday with the officer who rescued him.

"Bubba looked very healthy and happy, and both he and Officer Laurich seemed to thoroughly enjoy their time together," a post on the Tustin Police Department's Facebook page stated. 

Bubba already has a number of rescue groups waiting to help him find a forever home once he has fully recovered, the post said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/kXwWH

Republican presidential hopeful Donald J. Trump joined thousands of his supporters in chanting "build that wall" at a rally at the Anaheim Convention Center Wednesday.

The chants came after the candidate referred to his plan to have Mexico pay for a wall along the U.S. border.

Protests erupted outside the event, and extra police officers were on hand in case of violence.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/6I7gk

Cameras were rolling as a massive tornado destroyed a home in Ford County, Kansas, Tuesday. 

It was the fourth straight day that multiple tornadoes ripped through the Plains states, leaving several people injured.

One meteorologist even captured an image of dual tornadoes that touched down simultaneously for about 30 seconds.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/9cP43

Instead of decorating a nursery, a Utah couple started planning a funeral after being told their unborn son would likely die within minutes of his birth.

At 23 weeks, doctors told Ben and Alyssa Reidhead their son's brain was growing outside of his skull.

"We picked out a casket and we picked out what we were going to do," Alyssa Reidhead said.

But their little boy defied the odds and came out fighting.

"We heard a cry and that made me cry and him cry because we were like, 'Oh, he's crying,'" Alyssa Reidhead said.

"I know that miracles can happen ... because we have witnessed it with this baby," family members posted on a GoFundMe page.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/59iCp
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
One-year-old Jacob Marbury was allegedly assaulted weeks ago by a babysitter while his parents went out for a date night.

Police in Sherwood, Oregon, say it may be difficult to prosecute the accused person due to a 2012 state Court of Appeals ruling. No arrest has been made in the case.

The baby's mother and father took to Facebook, and the hashtag #JusticeforJacob has since gone viral.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/eC3kf
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Set to dramatic music, CHP released this video of its "slowest pursuit ever," involving a group of wayward baby geese in the fast lane of Interstate 80 in Berkeley. 

The "nail biting" chase ended with the "felonious fowl" being channeled back into the bay, officials said in a tongue-in-cheek post. A CHP official confirmed the adorable creatures were not taken into custody. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/dYlpo

Donald Trump's latest effort to appeal to Hispanic voters came in a newly released video targeting evangelical Christians. 

"We're going to bring back jobs, you're going to start paying taxes after you're making a lot of money. Hopefully that's going to be soon. We're going to stop drugs from pouring into our country. We're going to strengthen our borders. We're going to stop the drugs," he said. 

Trump did not mention religion or his controversial proposal to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

The presumptive GOP nominee has begun reaching out to Hispanics in an effort to heal relations as polls show Hillary Clinton enjoying a nearly 40-point lead over him among the critical voting bloc. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/9NDtC

A terrier mix puppy named Bubba was successfully treated for drug addiction after he tested positive for methamphetamine, heroin and nicotine following a bust in Tustin, police say. 

Bubba was found in a motel room after officers served an arrest warrant for 40-year-old Joshua West, 40. Police reported a "large quantity" of illegal drugs were discovered in the room along with used needles.

The puppy is continuing his recovery and doing "excellent"; additional charges of animal cruelty are expected to be filed against his former owners, according to police. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/mRgFL
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
The space shuttle fuel tank known as ET-94 is making its final trek through the Los Angeles area today as it heads to the California Science Center. 

In this time lapse video, you can see it crossing a 405 Freeway overpass. 

Throngs of spectators have lined city streets to watch the 66,000-pound fuel tank wind its way through a 16-mile stretch of Inglewood and L.A. in a journey reminiscent of when Space Shuttle Endeavour was paraded in 2012. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/W0ZkT

In a moment one mother and son will likely never forget, a Florida school teacher was treated to the surprise of a lifetime Thursday when her Marine son walked into her classroom after two years overseas.

Paula Riggs was talking to her students about music when she was interrupted by an unexpected guest, video posted on Pasco County Schools' Facebook page showed.

The surprise guest turned out to be her son, Sgt. Paul Riggs.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/RjNoU

A suspected mass shooter was dragged from a Michigan courtroom after interrupting a victim's tearful testimony.

Jason Dalton allegedly shot Tiana Carruthers while she was escorting her daughter and four other children to a park in Kalamazoo. 

Six people were killed in the shooting, which left Carruthers and one other person wounded.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/HGlES
We're giving away a $500 gift card. Watch the KTLA 5 News at 10 tonight for your chance to win.

status_message:
BREAKING: A massive fire has engulfed the old Ruby's Diner at the end of the Seal Beach Pier. 

Firefighters have run hose for hundreds of feet down the course of the pier, and boats from the Long Beach Fire Department were helping douse the flames. 

Watch live video from Sky5 here: http://on.ktla.com/ZHbo5

An Ohio State Trooper was being called a hero after pulling a trapped infant from a car after a fiery crash that was caught on dash cam video.

The video showed Trooper Sean Eitel following a motorist who was swerving all over the road and hit two utility poles before her car overturned and burst into flames.

As rescuers pulled the woman out of the car she can be heard saying that her baby was still inside.

"He is upside down in his car seat, held by the car seatbelt," Eitel said. "Is it going to explode? I don't know, so I just wanted to get him out."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/kWCEZ

A police officer has been ticketed after running a red light and slamming into a passing motorist during a high-speed pursuit, according to the Florida Highway Patrol.

Officer Chris Bonner, 29, of the Ocoee Police Department, and the civilian driver, 26-year-old Yahaira Castro Montalvo, were both injured in the collision.

The two people in the pursued vehicle, suspected of armed robbery, were not apprehended.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/CO3Th

A Colorado mother has been arrested after disturbing video that surfaced online allegedly captured her verbally abusing and threatening to kill her toddler over a lost charger, according to police and local reports. 

 "Nobody f------ wants you," she yells at the boy, who is hysterically crying throughout the 16-minute video amid his mother's shouts and screams. 

The woman who shot the video said she previously witnessed the mother physically abused the child. She has also been charged with child abuse because she did nothing while recording the incident, according to a local television station. 

The woman said she can't walk or move, and feels bad that she didn't do more to help the boy. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/BI0uZ

Surveillance video of a frightening takeover robbery at a grocery store in Honolulu on Monday shows an assailant holding the 76-year-old shop owner in a choke hold.

The man attacked the woman from behind and dragged her to the back of the store with his arm firmly around her neck, the video showed.

While she was being subdued, a second man robbed the store, according to police. A third man acted as a lookout, authorities said.

A customer later found the woman bleeding on the floor and called police.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/AiuLr

A gas station worker in Lancaster repeatedly bashed a man's pickup truck after warning him he had stayed too long at the pump, according to a witness who recorded video of the altercation.

The man was there for several hours, according to the witness. "I'm not doing anything illegal. I'm here to buy some freaking gas," he says in the video.

The female worker responds: "I told you to move and you do not move. â€¦ The customer is not right."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/q5Mm4

Disturbing -- but ultimately gratifying -- video shows a police officer and several good Samaritans rescuing a man from a fiery SUV in Anchorage, Alaska.

The witnesses and Officer Mitchel Veenstra initially struggled to free the driver, whose arm was trapped under the vehicle. They ultimately succeeded, allowing the man to escape the inferno.

"Oh, you guys saved my ... life," he says in the video. "I thought I was literally going to die."

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/jQJFi

A man who exposed himself in the girl's locker room at Moorpark High School on at least two occasions was captured on surveillance video recently released by authorities. 

The man entered the locker room, took off his clothes and stood at the back of the room, but did not attempt to make any physical contact with the girls, investigators said.

The incidents occurred on May 11 and 12. Anyone with information on the man's identity was asked to contact authorities at  805-797-7137 or 805-947-8220.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/CFsxl

BREAKING: A roaming bear has climbed a tree near a school in Rancho Cucamonga, after being corralled by police and California Fish and Wildlife officials.

Video released by the Rancho Cucamonga Police Department shows the bear walking on a sidewalk in the area before it ascended the tree.

Watch KTLA's live video here: http://on.ktla.com/p3SOX

Amazing video from a police patrol car's dashcam captured a rare sight early Tuesday morning: a meteor streaking brightly across the sky in Portland, Maine.

"You never know what you are going to see on duty," the Portland Maine Police Department said in posting the video.

The fireball prompted hundreds of reports to The American Meteor Society.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/IDLeE

A man who tried to run from authorities as his pants fell to his ankles was captured after he tripped on a Chicago expressway Tuesday morning.

Video showed a state trooper and three expressway workers detaining the man after he fell face down onto the roadway. 

Officials did not know why the man was walking on the expressway.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/snMyb

Update: Two people and a dog were rescued from a cabin cruiser that caught fire off the Malibu coast Tuesday morning. 

A private vessel helped the boats occupants, who were not injured, and kept them aboard their vessel until rescue personnel arrived, according to an official. 

Aerial video from Sky5 showed the boat completely engulfed in flames before a firefighting ship eventually arrived at the scene and doused the fire.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/z8XJi

A custodian has graduated with a mechanical engineering degree from the same college where he cleaned and picked up trash for the past eight years. 

Michael Vaudreuill, 54, took the custodian's job after his plastering business went under in 2007. He said he lost his house, his business and his hope. 

Vaudreuill received his degree over the weekend from Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts. 

"Graduation was a crowning achievement. One of the best days of my life," he says. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/zy3T1

status_message:
"I just knew this child needed somebody to be there for him," a Georgia policeman said of the now-viral photo showing him hugging a toddler at a hospital after the little boy was found alone. 

Officer James Hurst had escorted the 16-month-old child to a Savannah-area hospital and remained with him during his medical exam. When the youngster began to cry, Hurst instinctively comforted him. 

"It was just human instinct; humanity," he recalled. "The hospital staff was taking great care of him [but] he was sobbing and crying. I picked him up and within minutes he was asleep on my chest."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/NIz95

status_message:
An LAPD officer comforted a toddler who was found abandoned in a car that crashed into a fire hydrant in Panorama City. 

Video captured the officer holding the 2 year old shortly after the child was discovered alone in the car with water gushing over it early Saturday morning, video from the scene showed. 

The toddler was transported to a local hospital as a precautionary measure. 

His mother has been arrested, according to LAPD. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/MwmDt

The LAPD became the latest law enforcement agency to accept and complete the international #RunningManChallenge, video posted online today shows. 

Demonstrating their best '90s dance of movies, a group of uniformed officers moved and grooved their way across various L.A. landmarks, showing off the downtown skyline, Dodger Stadium and the Hollywood sign. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/WGBnD

An attempted package thief who was confronted by a homeowner tried to tell him that her mother lived at the home. The homeowner said he was going to call police, and she dropped the packages and fled.

Now the Alhambra Police Department is looking for help identifying her.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/SwXej

Actor Danny Trejo confronted school officials at an emotionally charged community meeting two days after a melee involving dozens of students took place at Sylmar High School. 

At one point, the "Machete" star and San Fernando resident got up and walked up to administrators as he repeatedly urged them to listen to students while a large crowd cheered and applauded his remarks. 

"You are so wrapped up in whatever you do, that you're not listening to them," the "Machete" star said, pointing to the students. "They'll come up with the solution." 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/xjqQP

Sheriff's deputies were forced to run for cover when a "suicidal" man in Orange County fired at them with an automatic rifle in an incident that was captured on a patrol vehicle's dashboard camera.

The deputies were responding to a report of armed suicidal man in his garage when the shooter emerged and fired dozens of rounds at them.

The man went back into the garage and came out firing several more times before he eventually walked out with his hand in the air.

"Miraculously, this incident ended without any injury to the deputies, suspect, or neighbors," the Sheriff's Department stated.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/ps2ut

Two years after the dog he says helped him through some of the worst times of his life was stolen, a Wisconsin man was reunited with his long lost pal in a heartwarming scene that was captured on camera. 

Jose never though he'd see Chaos again after the theft. But as fate would have it, a Winnebago County employee found a stray dog in her driveway late last month. 

The dog was identified as Chaos through his microchip, and county Animal Services contacted Jose to let him know his beloved dog had been found. 

"This is just a miracle," said Jose, who was moved to tears upon being informed of the good news. "I couldn't be any happier, I feel amazing."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/KSFCN

Dramatic video shows an unconscious driver being pulled from a burning car in Palmdale Thursday morning. 

The car caught fire after crashing into a cinder block wall and the passed-out driver was unable to get out of the vehicle. 

Three sheriff's deputies and another man immediately pulled the driver out of the car and dragged him to safety. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/oT3hg

A fire that led to a devastating explosion that killed 15 people -- including 12 first responders -- at a Texas fertilizer plant in 2013 was deliberately set, authorities said Wednesday.

The West Fertilizer Company exploded with such force it caused a magnitude-2.1 earthquake, according to officials.

The blast also destroyed 500 homes and left a crater 93 feet wide and 12 feet deep.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/7nfr9

Update: Three hours after climbing KTLA's iconic radio tower on the Sunset Bronson Studios lot early Wednesday evening, an unidentified man came down safely on his own and was taken into police custody.

At one point, the man was perched more than 80 feet above the Hollywood lot, forcing the closure of Sunset Boulevard for blocks in both directions.

Read KTLA's story here: on.ktla.com/Qf63q

LAPD identified the suspected gunman and released surveillance video Wednesday in a fatal shooting outside downtown's Standard Hotel last December. 

A $50,000 reward is being offered for information leading to the arrest of Jamaine Harrington, who is suspected of killing Thomas Johnson on Dec. 13. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/t2Ixv

"Love is our basic, our nature. Love is very, very important -- for not only healthy mind, but also healthy body, also."

That's how the Dalai Lama described the importance of love in the world. Today, the 80-year-old Tibetan Buddhist leader continues to inspire and share words of wisdom around the world.

His exclusive interview with KTLA's Christina Pascucci airs weeknights all this week on the KTLA 5 News at 10.

The "tallest, fastest and longest" dive roller coaster in the world just opened over the weekend, and here's what it looks like. 

The new Valravn coaster at Cedar Point in Ohio keeps riders hanging for four seconds before a complete vertical drop of more than 200 feet. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/KZSag

A heartbreaking image of two abused dogs appearing to comfort each other has gone viral.

A 3-month-old boxer named "Sammie" was shot, dragged behind a car and spray painted, according to a post on a YouCaring fundraising page.

After Sammie arrived at the Paws & Claws Animal Clinic in Columbia, South Carolina, he was immediately befriended by fellow shelter dog Simon, who suffers from mange and extreme neglect.

"Sammie accepted Simon's soft touch and was grateful for the love and affection that Simon showed him," the post stated.

Caregivers said it was a perfect example of how "companion animals do feel pain and show compassion for others."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/gLd3M

Incredible video shows a tornado barreling through Oklahoma Monday, lifting whole trees out of the ground. A tornado watch is in effect for 12 counties in the state.

"You are in a life-threatening situation," the National Weather Service warned. "Flying debris may be deadly to those caught without shelter. Mobile homes will be destroyed."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/6xhXW

Vinny Desautels endured teasing for two years while he grew his hair out to donate to kids with cancer, but said he was "happy" to have helped others.

Now, the 7-year-old Roseville boy who gave selflessly has been diagnosed with late-stage cancer himself.

"Well, the veins from my hip are traveling to another place right behind my eye and it's making it squinty," 7-Vinny said. Doctors were still trying to identify what type of cancer Vinny has.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/0M9Pp

Mother Nature put on a dazzling display overnight before Mother's Day as the Northern Lights were visible over Western Washington. 

A green glow exploded into curtains and pillars against the backdrop of the night sky around 1 a.m., according to the National Weather Service Seattle.  

"Probably the best #aurora display we've seen in a decade here in #Seattle. Simply amazing," the agency tweeted. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/QnTFp

Terrifying video captured a violent crash in China that left a crushed car partially under a semi-truck. 

The drivers said they didn't see the other vehicle as they approached the intersection. 

First responders rescued three people from the wreckage; none of their injuries were considered to be life threatening. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/wFGDr

Brayden Armstrong was born without his left arm, but the 6-year-old now has a brand new Captain America-inspired prosthetic arm thanks to a generous Michigan man and his 3-D printer.

Brayden was thrilled by the gift, exclaiming "I like it very much" as he showed off the arm to his kindergarten classmates. 

His mother, Ashley Clayton, says she can't wait to see what Brayden can do with the arm.

"I am so thankful and so grateful for the generosity. It's an answered prayer, it really is," said Clayton.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/VHCD1

Rain drenched parts of SoCal during a spring storm Friday, pouring off this building in Valencia.

"Good thing we work indoors," said the KTLA viewer who sent in this video.

With slow-moving thunderstorms possible, a flash-flood watch has been issued through evening for most local mountain ranges.

The driver allegedly involved in a dramatic pursuit and standoff that shut down the entire 91 Freeway in Anaheim Hills, jamming traffic in the area during the evening rush-hour commute, has been arrested. 

John Lopez led authorities on a slow-speed chase that began in Compton, then refused to get out of the car when came to a rest on the side of the 91 Freeway after spike strips were deployed, according to the L.A. County Sheriff's Department. 

A SWAT Team used tear gas to flush him out of the vehicle, while a K-9 helped take him into custody.

Anaya Ellick was born without hands, but that's not stopping the talented Virginia first grader from accomplishing things. In fact, the little girl -- who does not use prosthetics -- was recently honored with a penmanship award. 

Anaya gives herself no limits and no excuses, according to her parents. Writing and drawing may not be the easiest task for her, but it's a challenge she accepts and works at. 

"She is a hard worker and has some of the best handwriting in her class," says Tracy Cox, the girl's principal.
