status_message:
A $50,000 reward is being offered in the hit-and-run death of a young mother who was struck and killed just as she lifted her 5-year-old daughter out of the backseat of their car on a street in Boyle Heights.

Grainy surveillance video shows a 2001 Toyota Corolla striking Korina Campos' car and spinning out.

Campos died from her injuries, while her daughter suffered a fractured pelvis.

The hit-and-run driver, who appeared to be bleeding, ran away.

Witnesses who attempted to detain the driver told police he simulated having a gun in his waistband and they let him go.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/UMRbC

Three inmates who escaped from an Orange County jail kidnapped a taxi driver at gunpoint, and forced him to stay with them for a week, authorities said, releasing new details about the fugitives' whereabouts during the eight-day manhunt. 

Two of the inmates â€” Bac Duong, 43, and Hossein Nayeri, 37 â€” got into a physical fight over whether the taxi driver should be killed. 

While Nayeri and the third inmate, 20-year-old Jonathan Tieu, were away from the San Jose motel room where the group holed up, Duong left with the taxi driver. They drove back to Southern California, and Duong turned himself in the following day.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/9teGW
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Winds were so strong in the South Bay that they nearly ripped the roof off of Hennessey's Tavern in Hermosa Beach, this viewer video shows. 

The region has been battered by high surf and strong winds since a storm moved in to Southern California over the weekend. 

On Sunday, powerful waves along the coast prompted the closure of the Redondo Beach and Manhattan Beach piers. Both were reopened this morning. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/GpsJN

In what's being called the "craziest wipeout ever captured on film," a pro surfer took a terrifying drop from the top of a 40-foot wave off Maui.

Tom Dosland, who had a stiff neck and destroyed board afterward, said it felt like he jumped from a cliff, and then like he was in a car crash.

Hawaii has seen enormous waves thanks to El NiÃ±o.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/jySEV

A viewer captured some of the massive waves that forced the closure of both the Redondo Beach and Manhattan Beach piers Sunday. 

The video shot by Mike Galliano showed waves sweeping along the Redondo Beach Pier as spectators were standing on the structure.

A lone surfer being tossed around by the large surf can also be seen in the video. Both piers were reopened Monday although surf advisories remained in effect. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/GpsJN

A skateboarder took advantage of windy conditions as a winter storm moved across Southern California.

Meanwhile, high surf conditions prompted the closure of the Redondo Beach Pier, seen in this video, and the Manhattan Beach Pier.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/RqyXa

A massive tree toppled onto the eastbound 134 Freeway in Burbank, blocking some lanes and prompting a response from the LAFD and California Highway Patrol.

Motorists across the Southland have been bedeviled by roadway obstructions and hazardous driving conditions as a storm brings rain and high winds to some areas.

Please share your weather photos with us in the comments section below, and read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/RqyXa

The 101 Freeway near Ventura looked more like a shallow lake this morning as debris flows and flooding prompted the closure of most of the highway for about two hours. 

The roadway flooding came as a strong storm system moved across Southern California, drenching the area with moderate to heavy rain. 

The storm was also expected to bring a wide range of weather-related impacts to the area, including flooding and mud flows in recent burn areas, dangerous winter driving conditions in the mountains, and powerful winds with the capability of downing trees and power lines. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/RqyXa

(Video: Ventura County Sheriff OES)

BREAKING: The Orange County Sheriff's Department has just released this video of Jonathan Tieu and Hossein Nayeri being escorted back into a Santa Ana jail, nine days after the pair plus a third inmate escaped from a maximum-security facility. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/4BErK

Fourteen-month-old snowboarder Sloan Henderson has taken to the slopes with surprising -- and adorable -- ease.

A video recorded by her father shows the toddler demonstrating her precocious skill at Park City Mountain Resort in Utah.

"She really took to it and has really good balance," Sloan's mother said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/mxz68

Hundreds of miles above Earth, members of the International Space Station held a moment of silence Thursday for the seven-member crew of the doomed Challenger flight. 

"As you guys are aware, today is the 30th anniversary of the space shuttle Challenger accident," NASA astronaut Scott Kelly said. 

"So I'd like to take a moment of silence, and recognize the sacrifice of all those crew members, and how their spirit and their legacy lives on in our achievement in space." 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/5DHNZ

A frantic Chicago teenager called 911 three times, minutes before police fatally shot him and a neighbor â€” and now the dispatcher is facing possible disciplinary action. 

Quintonio LeGrier, 19, reported that there was an emergency when, on the first of three calls, the dispatcher hung on him.

Minutes later, police fatally shot a neighbor who was at the teen's door before shooting him six times, killing him.

LeGrier can be heard in 911 tapes obtained by KTLA sister station WGN. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/yV0Nf

In an incredible show of sportsmanship, an undefeated wrestler at Norton High School in Massachusetts gave up the chance at a perfect season to let an opponent with Down syndrome win a match. 

Devin Schuko says he's humbled by the attention for what he described as a "simple act of kindness." He then went on to praise opponent Andy Howland for the victory. 

Howland's mother, meanwhile, thanked the teen for giving her son a memory he will never forget. "It's nice to see good sportsmanship is not dead," Debbie Erickson Howland said. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/12Evg

A bedtime ritual for a South Carolina toddler is touching the hearts of thousands.

Kathryn and Caleb Whitt were rushing to get their daughter, Sutton, to bed on Sunday night so they skipped her bedtime prayers.

Much to her their surprise and delight, the couple heard the 2-year-old saying her own prayers over the baby monitor.

"I was just shocked at her age that she wanted to think through everyone she wanted to pray for," Kathryn Whitt said.

Little Sutton gave thanks for her parents, her grandma and Santa Claus before finishing up with a big "amen."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/9jgDJ

An 18-year-old who can't read music and never had a formal piano lesson sat down and performed in front of customers at the Lansing Mall in Michigan Friday, resulting in a video that has become an online sensation.

Monntel West said he taught himself to play by watching videos on YouTube and practicing on an electric keyboard.

Since the video was posted to Facebook by Sara Hadley, West has been getting offers for free piano lessons and free pianos. He said he was even contacted by a record label in Los Angeles.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/m0EcR

This video shows a man being sought for inappropriately touching a little boy in a restaurant bathroom on Sunday in Long Beach.

The man allegedly assaulted the child in the men's room of a Buffalo Wild Wings restaurant and then fled, police said.

The victim was under 10 years old and had gone to the bathroom alone while his family was eating dinner.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/QtbEX

Police were called in Tuesday night when hundreds of people and cars began to gather on the iconic Sixth Street Bridge on the eve of its closure prior to demolition.

Officers from the Los Angeles Police Department moved in a line down the 84-year-old bridge forcing bystanders and vehicles to clear the roadway, aerial video showed.

Only one person was arrested.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/FTQIR

An extraordinary moment was captured on camera as a freshly hatched king brown snake took its first breath.

The video was recorded by Billy Collett, the head of Reptiles & Venom at The Australian Reptile Park.

The tiny creature may look cute, but it's better to look and not touch.

This little guy is deadly and will eventually grow to upwards of 8 feet long.

Read KTLA's story here http://on.ktla.com/9vNMk

An Ohio police officer said it was a "miracle" he survived after being struck by a big rig that skidded off the road earlier this month in an incident that was captured on his dashboard camera. 

The driver of the big rig was stopped on some railroad tracks and unable to get out of the way of an oncoming train, which struck the semi and sent it careening out of control.

"I remember seeing the train hit the trailer and then I felt the impact of the semi," Capt. Brad Moore said. "It's a miracle. I mean, it really is. I mean it's very ... makes you think a lot."

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/OcZpy

BREAKING: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 2.7 struck 2 miles north northeast of Moreno Valley at 6:15 a.m., the USGS just reported. 

Did you feel it?
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
When 15-year-old Trevor Sullivan awoke from heart-transplant surgery, his breathing was labored. He was sobbing with emotion.

"I'm so happy," he told his father, who was at his side. "I feel amazing. I've never felt so good."

A video clip of the joyful moment has gone viral, helping the Sullivan family's efforts to raise awareness of organ donation.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/5wk3t

BREAKING: A truck parked on Sunset Boulevard in East Hollywood burst into flames after a collision involving two other vehicles.

A witness captured dramatic video of the blaze, which LAFD firefighters extinguished within 10 minutes.

A woman suffered a minor injury in the crash. The cause of the incident was unknown.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/rEZCa

A Florida officer who responded to a noise complaint against neighborhood kids playing basketball on the street by joining in on their fun promised the group he'd return for a rematch. 

Officer Bobby White made good on that promise in a big way on Saturday, bringing along his colleagues and a very special guest: former NBA star Shaquille O'Neal. 

The ex-L.A. Lakers player had expressed interest in playing in the rematch after watching the video of White's response. 

"These kids will never forget the day Shaq rolled up to their house to play ball," the Gainesville Police Department said. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Afnr1

Donald J. Trump boasted that support for his presidential campaign would not decline even if he shot someone in the middle of a crowded street.

"I could stand in the middle of 5th Avenue and shoot somebody and I wouldn't lose voters," Trump said at a rally in Iowa.

After the event, the billionaire declined to answer when asked to clarify his comments.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/xnjEw

A "Tyrannosaurus rex" was seen shoveling snow in front of a Virginia home, providing fodder for a #Jonasblizzard video that has gone viral.

The amusing footage was shared by the Arlington County Fire Department, which encouraged residents to follow the costumed homeowner's example and clear snow away from fire hydrants.

Adorable new video of a mother sea otter grooming her brand new pup was captured by workers at the Monterey Bay Aquarium recently. 

The aquarium staff initially grew worried about the mother when she began spending an unusual amount of time in the pool, a move they say is rare for healthy sea otters. 

But concerns were subsided when they realized the otter had given birth. "Aquarium staff witnessed a BRAND NEW pup resting on her belly, being furiously groomed by a proud momma," the aquarium's website stated.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/q7UOc

Update: The U.S. Strategic Command confirms the mysterious light was a Russian rocket body that had re-entered Earth's atmosphere over Arizona Tuesday evening.

Video courtesy of Matt Decker of Oxnard.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/ZY3PS

Two LAPD officers brought some holiday cheer to a World War II veteran in Venice who neighbors had grown concerned about after not hearing from him for an unusually long time. 

Officers Natali Nunez and Abel Torres responded to the welfare check call and found 94-year-old Herman Perry was well, but hard of hearing and unaware of his neighbors' concerns. 

"He told us that not too many people stop by anymore," Torres said. Moved by the encounter, the officers drove to a Christmas tree lot and returned with a tree, two sets of lights, mistletoe and candy donated by the lot owner who heard their story. 

Fellow officers also donated presents to Perry, who said, "I can't believe all this is going on. This never happened to me," and then smiled. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/74jGh

In a history-making launch, SpaceX guided a reusable rocket safely back to Earth after liftoff on Monday.

The tremendous feat marks a big step toward making space travel cheaper â€” the company's rockets cost between $60 and $90 million. 

One SpaceX spokesperson said the task is "like launching a pencil over the Empire State building and having it land on a shoebox on the other side ... during a wind storm."

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/Hj2Wn

Amazing video shows pro surfer Kelly Slater riding what he calls the "best man-made wave ever" in what's likely a game-changer for surfing.

"It's a freak of technology," Slater says of his Kelly Slater Wave Company.

The wave pool is in a secret location, but surfing media have tied it to a former water-ski lake south of Fresno.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/HXlqT

Surveillance video shows a New York gas station owner using a shoe to successfully fend off an armed robber. 

The store owner initially began to fill a bag with cash, but as the robber leaned in to grab more, he decided to fight back. 

The owner throws a shoe at the robber, then charges him and grabs back the bag of money. The robber was armed, police say, and fired a single blast into the pavement as the owner chased him.  

"He made those actions in the heat of the moment and those are his choices and we will not comment on those choices," police later said. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/Ha6zt

A 15-year-old high school football player has died after he jumped on top of three girls to shield them from gunfire in Tennessee. None of the girls were injured.

Zaevion Dobson was killed Thursday after suspected gang members opened fire on a crowd, shooting "randomly."

The teen was remembered by community members as a hero who was not only involved with sports, but was a mentor at a local non-profit that aims to empower minority youth to reach their full potential.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/MBPho

Dramatic dashcam video shows a shootout between a Florida deputy and a convicted felon who had recently been released from prison.

Authorities said Andrew Coffee was pulled over for riding a scooter without a tag. The footage shows him punching Deputy Chris Lester in the face before gunfire erupts.

The suspect fled the scene and was later taken into custody.

Both men were recovering after being wounded in the shooting.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/yHXRQ

Newly released video shows a previously undetected mountain lion kitten, believed to be about 6 months old, meowing into the camera before heading off for food in the Santa Monica Mountains. 

Researchers say the kitten belongs to well-known mountain lion P-23, who was famously photographed atop a deer on Mulholland Highway. 

The kitten was a surprise to researchers, who had thought P-23's only kittens from a summer litter had been killed three months ago. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://on.ktla.com/Mcij0

Hillary Clinton had a message for a supporter's father who is backing Donald J. Trump: "I don't have horns."

The Democratic presidential hopeful delivered the assurance in a cellphone video recorded by Kayla Helmers, a 22-year-old volunteer, at a town hall in Iowa.

"Hi Shawn, I am here with your daughter," Clinton said. "I hope you can see I don't have horns. And I really do hope that as this election goes on you will listen to your daughter. Thanks. Bye."

After a threat prompted the daylong closure of all L.A. Unified schools and was later determined to be "not credible," LAPD Chief Charlie Beck defended the decision to temporarily shut down the campuses.

All LAUSD schools will be in session on Wednesday, officials said.

Martin, who lives a little over a block from the school, was arrested after an adult intervened and police were called.

Surveillance footage shows a man was holding a gun prior to being shot and killed by deputies in Lynwood, sheriff's officials said Sunday.

In less than 20 seconds, a Christmas tree can become engulfed in flames, filling a room with fire, as seen in video released by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission.

The video aims to warn people that typical holiday items, such as candles, wrapping paper and trees, can pose a fire hazard if not properly looked after. 

Christmas trees were the first items ignited in about 200 fires annually between 2010 and 2012, resulting in 10 deaths, 20 injuries, and about $17 million in property loss, according to the Safety Commission.

Read KTLA's story and get safety tips here: http://on.ktla.com/lbar1

A giant wave that crashed onto and over the Ventura Pier was captured Friday morning by Ricky Staub, who posted this amazing photo to his Instagram account, @NeighborhoodFilm.

The pier was closed indefinitely after being damaged by the surf.

The "largest surf event of the season so far" was expected to bring waves of up to 15 feet to L.A. and Ventura counties, and up to 10 feet to Orange County, according to the National Weather Service.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/anb4p

As he rocked back and forth in his chair sobbing in court, a former Oklahoma City officer listened while he was found guilty of multiple rape and forced oral sodomy charges Thursday. 

Daniel Holtzclaw preyed on women, often those with drug or prostitution records that would undermine any claims against him, in one of Oklahoma's poorest neighborhoods for about 6 months. One young woman, only 17 at the time, was raped on her mother's front porch.

On his 29th birthday, jurors recommended a total of 263 years in prison for Holtzclaw, who was convicted on 18 of 36 charges against him. As he left the courtroom, Holtzclaw proclaimed his innocence to family members and stared down jurors.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/732le

Dramatic video from Sky5 shows waves pounding the Ventura Pier, which was damaged and closed Friday morning as a result of the high surf. The footage also captured water surging into a nearby neighborhood, flooding streets and possibly homes.

A 99-year-old woman who won a shopping spree at a 99 Cents Only Store on her birthday filled her cart with Christmas goods Thursday, but she had no plans to keep the toys and stockings for herself.

Instead, Donna Goldstein decided she was going to use her shopping spree at the Beverly Grove store to make holiday stockings for children in need and donate them throughout the community.

"Sometimes we don't realize how much is needed. I feel bad that I can't do it for everyone, but it makes me feel very good that I am able to do what I can," Goldstein said.

Two-year-old Ryland Wade, who has epilepsy and spastic quadriplegia, suffered a seizure shortly before he was scheduled to meet Santa Claus at an Ohio mall.

"It really sapped his energy, but we didn't want that to stop him from meeting Santa," his mother, Samantha Wade, said.

The boy's parents took him to the shopping center, where "Santa immediately cuddled with him and very quietly talked to him for awhile."

"When it came time for a photo, he pretended like he was snoozing along with Ryland, making for one awesome picture and a very memorable moment for us," Samantha Wade said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://on.ktla.com/XVWOk

A brief LAPD pursuit of a stolen yellow coupe came to an end in Watts Wednesday, and after the driver got out with his hands up, he was followed by a trio of passengers.

A woman was injured and her 6-month-old terrier mix killed when they were struck by a hit-and-run driver in Redondo Beach Monday, now authorities are hoping video of the crash will lead them to the person responsible. 

The video shows a dark-colored four-door sedan with tinted windows making a left turn as Lindsay Harrie and her beloved dog Kira were walking in a crosswalk at the intersection of Grant Avenue and Slauson Lane. 

"They didn't stop. They just kept going," Harrie said, tearfully. "Then I saw (Kira) in the middle of the road, bleeding."

Anyone with information about the collision was asked to call Redondo Beach police at 310-379-2477.

In what investigators called "one of the worst things they have ever seen," bones belonging to a child were discovered in a pig enclosure on the property of a Kansas City man suspected of killing his 7-year-old son, police say.

The parents of a Hollywood producer who disappeared right before the Thanksgiving holiday made an emotional public plea for help locating their son.

Police responding to a "domestic" call in which someone was heard shouting "I'm going to kill you" amid a woman's hysterical screams were surprised to discover it was only a man trying to kill a huge spider. 

After responding to the apartment in Australia, officers told the man that neighbors had also heard the crash of furniture being flung around, in addition to the death threats and screams. 

"It was a spider," the man explained. "A really big one."

When asked about the woman screaming, he responded, "Yeah, sorry, that was me. ... I really, really hate spiders."

Nearly a week after 129 people were killed during terror attacks in Paris, a Thousand Oaks-area exchange student who survived the incident was reunited with his family at LAX. 

"I was having the best time of my life so far in Paris," Bruno Sayjor said of last Friday's soccer match. "All we hear is a big 'kaboom.' Everyone just started to disperse running, just running for their lives."

The 21-year-old's family was unable to contact him for about four hours following the attacks. When they finally did, his grandmother said she was "very, very thankful the lord saved him.

Just minutes after 7-year-old Gabriella "Gabby" Doolin was reported missing from a high school football game, the Kentucky girl was found dead in isolated area behind the campus.

The little cheerleader vanished while she was cheering on her two brothers who were playing in the game, her mother told police.

A search of the immediate area resulted in the discovery of Gabby's lifeless body in a pond in a secluded wooded area. Police were investigating her death as a homicide.

Gabby's father posted this statement on Facebook:

"We've never been this empty. I'd give anything to hold my baby girl just one more time. I love her with all my heart," Brian Doolin said.

If it seems like more sharks are appearing along the California coast these days, you're right. The uptick is linked to El NiÃ±o, says marine biologist David Valencia.

"The white sharks have always been there, but we're seeing them maybe more often because temperatures are changing, and the white sharks are looking for different places to forage, especially the juveniles," Valencia said.

In addition to great whites, there have been recent hammerhead shark sightings. Back in October, a stretch of Newport Beach was temporarily closed after an apparent sighting. 

All this week, we're covering the science of sharks. KTLA's "Shark Encounters" airs nightly on the KTLA 5 News at 10.

The Eiffel Tower was lit up in France's tricolor Monday evening as Paris mourns last week's terrorist attacks. 

The monument had been closed to tourists and left dark immediately following the attacks, but current plans are to light it up in the country's colors again on Tuesday and Wednesday. 

Monuments around the world, including The Sydney Opera House, the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin and One World Trade Center's antenna all lit up in France's blue, white and red in a sign of solidarity over the weekend.

This veterans memorial in Arizona is designed to be "perfect" only for an instant each year: at 11:11 a.m. on Nov. 11.

At that time every Veterans Day, the sun's rays pass through ellipses in pillars that represent the five U.S. armed forces, forming a "perfect solar spotlight" over the Great Seal of the United States.

The monument was dedicated in the community of Anthem on Nov. 11, 2011, in a symbolic reference to the eleventh hour, "when the guns fell silent to end World War I," a monument brochure states.

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/1lky88E

On the eve of Veterans Day, protesters marching from Milwaukee's City Hall set an American flag on fire. The blaze was immediately extinguished by police officers.

In the aftermath of the incident, Milwaukee police ceremoniously folded the damaged flag.

"While the protestors may have been within their rights to trample on and burn the flag, that does not excuse their actions. They showed their disdain for our country, our rule of law, and the brave men and women who have fought and died for their rights," Wisconsin state Sen. Van Wanggaard responded.

Police said a 17-year-old known gang member was in custody on suspicion of murder after an hourslong search.  

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/1QuuW6h

It was March 2014 at a charity race for the Pat Tillman Foundation in the Bay Area. Joe Bell, a 95-year-old veteran, put on his military uniform and sat outside his home to cheer on the participants. 

One by one, the runners began to detour from the street to shake Joe's hand and thank him for his service. The touching moment, caught on video by Joe's neighbor, was shared hundreds of thousands of times on social media. 

Ten months after the video went viral, Joe passed away at his home, according to the San Jose Mercury News. "He wouldn't have lasted nearly as long if it wasn't for the love of the people who saw that video," his son told the newspaper.

This Veterans Day, we honor the more than 21 million veterans in this country. As part of that, on Wednesday at 7 p.m., we're airing "America's Veterans: A Special Tribute." The hour-long special hopes to recognize our veterans and tell their stories.

Dramatic body camera video shows a suspected DUI driver ramming an Oklahoma police patrol car, sending the officer who was trying to stop her to the ground. 

Master Patrol Officer Matt Stacy had attempted stop the vehicle as it went through a school's parking lot, according to a local TV station. Instead, the SUV drove toward him. 

When officers finally caught her, Stacey Ann Bunsey yelled, "I'm God" at them, another body cam video showed. 

She was arrested on a number of charges, including assault and battery with a deadly weapon on a police officer, and DUI drugs, authorities say. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/1OBQgYh

Nathaniel Stocks is only 5 years old, but he is officially a hero. 

The kindergartner is being credited with saving his grandmother's life during a fire at the family's home using the lessons he learned just two days earlier during a tour of a local fire station.

Investigators say a space heater in Nathaniel's room caught fire during the night.

Instead of panicking, fire officials said, Nathaniel crawled down the hallway beneath the smoke and alerted his grandmother.

Both got out of the house safely.

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/20IxGRY

Disturbing surveillance video released Monday allegedly shows residents of an assisted-living facility being abused by the very people trusted with their care.

The video was recorded last year at The Anyelir Home in Rancho Cucamonga, which caters to residents with varying levels of disabilities.
 
In the video, a caregiver can be seen repeatedly pushing one resident. In another instance, a resident was shoved so hard he fell to the ground.

Two women were arrested as a result of the investigation. Investigators believe there could be other victims.

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/1kHJiny

California's historic drought has hit one area particularly hard. In East Porterville, about 160 miles north of Los Angeles, more than 500 families are out of water. Some homes rely on private ground wells, while others use bottled water to survive.  

"Everything's gone," said resident Vickie Yorba. "I cry myself to sleep."

Tulare County officials warn that even with a tank program providing some relief, a permanent solution involving new piping is still years away. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/1klYO92

Video captured animal control officers pursuing and then catching a mountain lion that had been roaming the streets of San Dimas Sunday evening. 

The puma desperately tried to evade capture before it was ultimately caught by an officer with the aid of a net, the footage shows. 

 No tranquilizers were used, and the lion was not injured, according to authorities. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1kGcJWX

A mysterious, bright light that coursed across the night sky in Southern California and beyond prompted rampant speculation and a little bit of panic this weekend. 

The stunning sight on Saturday night was captured on numerous cellphone cameras, with some theorizing that the object was a comet or aliens. 

The Pentagon later confirmed it was a scheduled missile test flight at sea from USS Kentucky. Testing will continue until Nov. 12, meaning more sightings are possible. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1NBZK4p

A caught-on-camera distraction theft in Corona â€” in which a group of inconspicuous women enters the store and talks to employees while one steals a worker's purse â€” is the latest in a string of similar crimes across California.

Within the last two years, two to five women have gone into businesses and committed such distraction thefts, usually stealing behind-the-counter purses. SoCal crimes have occurred in Bell, Huntington Beach, Palmdale, Orange, Buena Park and now Corona. At least three more have occurred in the area south of Sacramento.

Police in Huntington Beach warned businesses to be vigilant. They described the thieves as "heavy set" Hispanic women ranging from their 20s to their 40s, and conversant in English and Spanish.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Q9eJEh
link_name: Caught-on-Camera Distraction Theft in Corona Mirrors Yearslong...

status_message:
The acrobatic antics of a spotted skunk were captured by a wildlife camera in Saguaro National Park in Arizona. 

While a skunk doing a handstand might seem bizarre, it is actually quite normal and not a particularly good sign for anyone standing too close.

It's commonly known that most skunks will spray a "a strong unpleasant scent as a form of defense," according to the U.S. Department of Interior.

But unlike other skunks, spotted skunks take their self-preservation a step further and will sometimes go into a handstand in an "attempt to intimidate any would be aggressors," the agency says.  

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1OpM6T6

Two mountain lion sightings in the Monrovia and Hollywood Hills areas in the past several days has some residents on edge.

A "humongous" mountain lion was seen apparently relaxing next to a Beachwood Canyon home Halloween night. 

"It was really scary. I felt like I was in a zoo, except I was on my street and in a residential neighborhood where little kids are running around," a witness told KTLA. 

The next day, surveillance footage caught another mountain lion walking past Monrovia homes with something in its mouth. A local resident said he believed it was his neighbor's cat. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1H3lGUp

For the second time in a week, SeaWorld crews helped a humpback whale become untangled from fishing lines off San Diego County's coast. 

Crews worked about three hours to remove lines from the roughly 40,000-pound, 45-foot adult whale, during the second rescue on Saturday. Unfortunately, they were not able to remove the lines completely, and it remained around the whale's mouth and appeared to be embedded in its jaw. 

"We helped the whale significantly," said a SeaWorld official who led the rescue effort. "It's definitely not dragging anything. Hopefully it can free itself from the line in its mouth."

A third entangled whale was spotted off Newport Beach on Saturday, and crews remained on standby incase it needed assistance. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1M6Goj9

A 32-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of public intoxication and assaulting an Uber driver in a violent incident that was captured on video.

The driver said he told the passenger to get out of the vehicle and sprayed him with Mace after being punched repeatedly.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1Q14iTg

Thousands of revelers took to the streets of West Hollywood for the city's annual Halloween Carnaval.

A witch, Stormtrooper, "One Direction" and Edward Scissorhands were spotted among the crowd, which was expected to grow to about 500,000 people.

We'd love to see your Halloween costume. Share a photo in the comments section below.

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/1LJaKdA

BREAKING: Firefighters in Riverside are battling a dramatic 35-acre brush fire that began in a riverbed and spread to nearby Fairmount Park.

No injuries have been reported, but some structures are threatened, fire officials said. The blaze is 50 percent contained.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1WnXX8t

A shark encounter was captured by a fisherman who says a 10-foot hammerhead circled and swam after his kayak for an hour off La Jolla's coast. 

"After he was following me, I mean this may sound silly, but we kind of made eye contact and that's when he started ramming my kayak several times," Nick Cervantes said. 

The fisherman had hooked the shark, and although it eventually snapped itself free it continued to follow Cervantes. 

He eventually came across boaters who helped him to safety.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://bit.ly/1PVLfcU

It was almost lights out for the popular "Halloween House" in Riverside after a thief crept onto the property overnight and stole lighting specially designed for the extravagant holiday display.

Home security cameras show the thief at work as he took expensive floodlights used in the Halloween light-and-music show.

After an outpouring of anger on social media, the alleged perpetrator appeared to have a change of heart.

Homeowner Melanie Betty told KTLA the alleged thief gave an umpire at a local park a backpack filled with stolen lights.

The thief even apologized on Facebook, calling it a stupid stunt.

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/1LHyn6c

Dramatic video of an inmate's brazen and violent escape from Men's Central Jail surfaced on Thursday.

The male inmate breached security in the jail's visiting area and assaulted multiple sheriff's deputies in his bid for freedom.

Video obtained by KFI showed one deputy being kicked in the upper torso and knocked backward as he tried to stop the leaping inmate.

The escapee was then spotted climbing a chain link fence and darting across a set of railroad tracks just moments before an oncoming train rolled through the area.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://bit.ly/1NbgDmh

A Northern California mother is angry after school officials forced her 12-year-old son to turn his American flag T-shirt inside out because they deemed it "gang related." 

The patriotic shirt was considered a possible safety risk because of the red star at the top, a design that a school district official said has been associated with gangs in the past. 

"I mean, they are trying to keep everybody safe. I understand, but it feels like it is a little too far. Especially when it is a patriotic shirt," Lori Carpenter told a local TV station. "It's just kind of ridiculous"

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/1RCPlEi
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Police are hoping someone will recognize a man wanted for attempting to rape a woman as she walked home from work in Boyle Heights.

The unidentified man stalked the woman for several blocks, before grabbing her. The assailant told the woman not to make any noise, but she ignored him and screamed for help.

"Her screams led to a nearby neighbor hearing the screams and coming out and assisting her," an LAPD detective said. "That ultimately saved her."

The man ran away, but his image was captured by a camera at a Metro station platform near the scene of the attack.

Read KTLA's story here: http://bit.ly/1WjxrIi

A story of compassion and healing has captured the hearts of over a million people after a man rescued and rehabilitated an injured baby deer who didn't want to leave her adopted family.

Darius Sasnauskas spotted the injured fawn with her mother and sibling in the Yellowstone National Park area. The fawn could not keep up with its mother, putting the fawn in serious danger. 

So, Sasnauskas took her in, made a leg brace "from an oatmeal box" and taught her to drink from a bottle.

Once she could care for herself, Darius released the fawn back to her real mom.

From time to time, the fawn comes back to visit Darius and her new best friend, Mack, a huge dog who happily adopted the role of foster dad.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://bit.ly/1kILhbw

Update: Dramatic video shows police officers shooting beanbag rounds at a man outside a Chase bank while responding to a bomb threat and robbery in downtown Los Angeles. 

In a video recorded by witness Paul Bortoli, the man is seen reaching into a suitcase and throwing several pieces of paper just before the officers moved in and fired. Police later confirmed the use of non-lethal ammunition in the incident.

Subsequent video from Sky5 seems to show the same man, shirtless and handcuffed, being examined by firefighter-paramedics and police before being placed on a stretcher in a seated position.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1R9tDb0

Students spend too much time taking "unnecessary" exams, President Obama said Saturday while announcing new guidelines for standardized tests.

The guidelines call for taking only "tests that are worth taking," and recommends no more than 2 percent of classroom time be spent on taking these tests.  

Two major teachers unions have praised Obama's announcement, but one official added, "the devil is in the details."

Those details are not expected to be released until January. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1jJGma2

A newly released video purportedly shows U.S. and Kurdish soldiers freeing some 70 hostages from an ISIS-controlled prison, in a daring raid that left one Delta Force member dead.

U.S. Army Master Sgt. Joshua L. Wheeler, 39, was the first American to die in combat in Iraq in nearly four years.

The hostages had been facing "imminent mass execution," the Pentagon said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1MMRidA

BREAKING: Hurricane #Patricia -- the strongest hurricane ever recorded -- made landfall on Mexico's Pacific coast about 4:15 p.m. Pacific Time Friday with 165 mph winds about 55 miles from the port city of Manzanillo.

The storm began lashing the coast Friday evening with strong winds and rain as tourists and residents in resorts such as Puerto Vallarta and Manzanillo sought shelter. 

Astronaut Scott Kelly tweeted this incredible photo of Hurricane Patricia from the International Space Station Friday.

Kelly's photo shows an expanse of white covering most of the visible portion of Earth. "Stay safe below, Mexico," Kelly tweeted.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1NYiAnp
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Breaking: The Tournament of Roses has selected Erika Karen Winter to be the 98th Rose Queen. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1W7vuhW

An anti-violence advocate is now paralyzed after being shot in the back during an attempted robbery, and the teenager arrested was supposed to attend one of his speeches on reducing juvenile crime rates. 

The Cal Poly Pomona student turned his life around after a criminal history beginning at the age of 12 and facing abuse in foster care. But while in Georgia to share his message of peace, Semaj Clark was shot. 

"I won't be able to walk anymore, and that hurts me, but it's not going to stop be from doing what I got to do," he said tearfully from his hospital bed in Georgia, where he continues to recover. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1OV1oxA

Surveillance video shows a van slamming into a car that was occupied by a 15-year-old girl and her father, who were hospitalized in critical condition after the crash.

The van apparently ran a red light at the Glendale intersection, a police spokesperson said. The driver of that vehicle sustained only minor injuries.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1OK06H7

Surveillance video captured a frantic scene Wednesday as at least four armed robbers burst into a jewelry store at an Orange County mall and began smashing cases. 

Others in the store took cover as at least one of the robbers brandished what appeared to be a firearm.

The heist, reportedly at Fredric H. Rubel Jewelers at the Shops at Mission Viejo, lasted only about 60 seconds. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1LMvD93

Sixty-one skydivers from 12 countries came together to break a world record while soaring thousands of feet over Perris.

The group formed the largest-ever formation of jumpers wearing specialized wingsuits, and the dive was captured on video taken in midair by Mark Harris. 

The jump's organizer called it an "absolutely incredible experience."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1NmchXx

Update: Riverside's popular "Halloween House" has once again returned for the holiday, this time with a nod to a classic movie from the '80s. 

This year's version features the theme song from "Ghostbusters." The display itself is comprised of four singing pumpkins, two Matrix boards, strobe and flood lights, tombstones and hand-carved pumpkins, according to a description posted along with video of the home to YouTube.

Last year, the attraction was briefly shut down by police because of noise complaints. It went on again, however, after the organizers obtained a special event permit.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1XhY42F

After a groom reportedly got cold feet and called off his wedding, the jilted bride's family decided not to cancel the reception.

Instead they invited Sacramento's homeless to the banquet hall of a four-star hotel, where the celebration had been planned, and served up the sumptuous pre-paid meal.

The nonrefundable honeymoon was also paid for in advance. The bride and her mother are on their way to Belize.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1PrV02n
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Amid a week that included flash flooding, mudslides and a "1,000-year rain event" in the Antelope Valley, Riverside County was hit with its own weather occurrence when a landspout tornado was spotted in the Menifee area on Saturday. 

The sighting was confirmed by the US National Weather Service San Diego California, which said the small tornado formed after sea breezes pushed around the Santa Ana Mountains, from the northwest and southeast, and met in a "convergence zone." 

No damages or injuries were reported. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1GMB4PJ

Incredible video shows the mess on Highway 58 near Mojave, where nearly 200 vehicles remain stranded after Thursday's storms.

Rescuers probed up to 6 feet of mud to try to find vehicles stuck underneath â€” and any potential victims. Remarkably, no injuries have been reported. 

Cleanup could take some three days, and might take longer if predicted storms come into the area.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1PmIkKf

Video from Sky5 showed vehicle after vehicle stuck hood-deep in mud and debris on Highway 58 near Mojave Friday after flash floods hit the area the day before. 

The packed mud and stuck vehicles prompted a portion of the highway just past the 14 Freeway to remain closed Friday morning and left traffic backed up for nearly 5 miles. 

Crews in excavators and bulldozers were also seen working to clear the mud, but the cleanup effort could take several days. "That's going to be a long process," one official said. "Avoid the area."

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1QAXadv

A truck driver traveling on Highway 58 near Tehachapi captured this unbelievable video during a flash-flood triggered by Thursday's storm. Jose Vargas can be heard asking someone to call 911 as the road in front of him is suddenly transformed into a rushing river powerful enough to sweep away cars.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1X7KM8P

Wild winds and golf-ball sized hail battered portions of the Antelope Valley Thursday as a volatile storm system moved through northern Los Angeles County, triggering dangerous flash floods and mudslides. Video provided by Jake Stark in Quartz Hill.

Read KTLA's story here: ktlane.ws/1jrtjKi

Sky5 was overhead as at least one deputy repeatedly punched a man on the ground at the end of a high-speed pursuit in Pasadena.

Some 15 punches appeared to be thrown.

The chase began as a call about a possible residential burglary in Rancho Cucamonga, and proceeded across the 210 Freeway, according to the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1GfiODz

The L.A. City Council agreed to pay $2.5 million to the children of a woman who was assaulted by an LAPD police officer and later died.

Video played at the criminal trial of Officer Mary O'Callaghan showed she hit Alesia Thomas in the throat and kicked her in the groin moments before the 35-year-old arrestee lost consciousness in the back of a patrol car.

As O'Callaghan jabbed Thomas in the throat, the handcuffed woman looked into the camera with wide eyes. She can be heard on the video repeatedly saying, "I can't."

Minutes later, Thomas' eyes closed and her head fell backward, the video showed. 

Thomas was later pronounced dead at a hospital. O'Callaghan was sentenced to 16 months in jail.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1RJ3OiF

In a spectacular crash caught on dashcam video, a pickup truck went airborne after making contact with a second vehicle that was spun around several times by the impact. The incident on the 210 Freeway in Fontana may have been triggered by road rage, according to a witness.

The badly injured driver of the truck had to be extracted after landing on top of a vehicle in the lot at Rock Honda.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1PtZWCV

Before and after video shows a stranded dog being rescued from a mine shaft, and her grateful kisses after being raised to the surface.

The pup, dubbed "Corona" for the city near where she was discovered by a group of off-roaders, had minimal injuries.

Now her rescuer is trying to help the young pooch find a new home.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1K9Dk3B

A 23-year-old Florida woman was arrested after police started following her feed on Periscope as she live-streamed herself allegedly driving while drunk.

Viewers of the live-streaming app alerted the Lakeland Police Department to the young woman's video feed.

In the video, released by police, Whitney Beall talks about how drunk she is and slurs her speech while seeming to be happily surprised by the number of followers she has.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1K4WgjY

When Esperanza High student April Clark was asked to homecoming by her friend Sean Boots, April's sister Melissa was there to capture moment on video. In the weeks since, millions have seen the sweet 30-second clip.

April and Sean, both students at the Anaheim school, have Down syndrome.
 
Their sisters helped plan the surprise invitation. It's the first time a boy has asked April to a dance, and April has also been named a homecoming princess.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1R7uloZ

"I'm too high," an Ohio man told an emergency dispatcher before admitting that he had smoked some weed and couldn't feel anything, according to a recently released 911 recording. 

The call prompted police to respond to the home, where an officer found the unidentified 22-year-old man laying in the fetal position. He was surrounded by "a plethora of Doritos, Pepperidge Farm Goldfish and Chips Ahoy cookies," according to a police report. 

A glass pipe, rolling papers, and a glass jar of marijuana were among the items allegedly found in the man's car. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1WTJL46

A single disturbing photo captured the heart-wrenching sight of four dogs -- barely more than skin and bones -- huddling together in a backyard in Pico Rivera.

Janette Gonzalez shared the photo on social media after reporting it to authorities as a case of animal abuse. She explained she wants to make sure there is justice for the dogs.

"It's one of the saddest things just because â€¦ I have dogs of my own, I work at a dog store, so I can't picture â€“ especially puppies â€“ going through that," Gonzalez said.

Various authorities have confirmed the dogs have been rescued, and that an investigation is underway.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Mhctc5
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
BREAKING: An Atlas V rocket has just been launched from 30th Space Wing (Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif.) in Santa Barbara County. 

Sky 5 video captured the launch from the San Fernando Valley, which is nearly 150 miles from the base. 

The Atlas V rocket is carrying a National Reconnaissance Office payload from Space Launch-Complex 3 in support of national defense

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1jcac6j

Damien Pereira wanted to be a firefighter since he was a little boy. His realized that dream, but his vision came to a tragic end when the 25-year-old was battling a wildfire near Sequoia National Park. 

An oak tree crashed down onto Pereira, trapping him. He was airlifted to a trauma center, paralyzed.

Now, as Pereira, his wife and 2-year-old son work through his rehabilitation and get help from the Fire Family Foundation, Pereira misses fighting fires more than anything.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1j2qNJw

A "no longer in fashion" '90s rap group was apparently trying to ignite a comeback when they posted a disturbing video to Instagram showing a person with a gun watching an LAPD officer as he exited his patrol car, police said Tuesday. 

"The investigation revealed that the film was made by members of an early 1990s rap group no longer in fashion," the Police Department stated.

Detectives determined the video was made for entertainment purposes only and was not a credible threat to officers. They did not name the rap group. 

Read KTLA's story here: ktlane.ws/1LgbVCo

Two bears were no match against a 20-pound French bulldog who easily chased them away from a Monrovia home over the weekend. 

Surveillance video shows the bears slowly walking around the home's yard when the small dog quickly runs toward them, prompting the bears to jump back and one to try to run away. 

The bulldog continues to chase the bear up and down the porch before it manages to escape by hopping headfirst over a fence. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1iZoneD

A mother and her 15-month-old infant were rescued by a U.S. Coast Guard helicopter team from a flooded home in South Carolina.

At least five weather-related deaths have been reported amid a severe rainfall event that Gov. Nikki Haley said has not been seen "in 1,000 years."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Z0xtbW

"I'm doing well," an Army veteran said in his first public comments since being shot several times while trying to block the gunman from entering his classroom in Thursday's Umpqua Community College shooting. 

In a video posted to Facebook, Chris Mintz also acknowledged the outpouring of public support, saying he was "overwhelmed" by it. He also wished the other surviving victims a "safe and speedy recovery." 

Prior to being shot, Mintz urged his classmates to get to safety and refused to allow the shooter to enter his classroom, telling him, "You're not getting by me."

Mintz sustained two broken legs and will have to relearn to walk, family members say. A GoFundMe has been set up to help pay his medical bills. 

Click here to read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1LrgQlT

"By the way, it was a gun-free zone," Donald J. Trump said of Umpqua Community College in Roseburg, Oregon. "I will tell you, if you had a couple of the teachers or somebody with guns in that room, you would have been a hell of a lot better off."

Trump went on to say he has a license to carry a gun in New York, and if someone attacks him, he will respond.

"Can you imagine? Somebody says, 'There's Trump, he's easy pickings.' What'd you'd say?" Trump said, mimicking holding a gun with his hand.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1RnMgIW

When a burglar attempted to flee a Pomona store he attempted to rob, he became trapped in an inescapable hallway. For about 45 minutes, he can be seen desperately trying to escape by kicking, and using a hammer and other tools. 

When "that door shuts, you're done. ... You're not getting out of there," an owner of the Boost Mobile Store by 20/20 Mobile said. 

The secure area, complete with reinforced steel doors, was made after the owners lost thousands of dollars in previous burglaries at other stores.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1M7LriS

An expecting couple -- who also happen to be horror-movie buffs -- decided to put a unique twist on their pregnancy announcement video.

Judy and Gavin Holt said producing the clip was therapeutic for them, following their two previous miscarriages. 

They don't yet know if they're having a boy or girl, but the baby has already been cast in an upcoming sequel to the announcement video. 

 Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1PRCwWi

Just about three weeks after they met, Keith Edwards and Reina Emerson began a cross-country adventure together â€” on foot. The couple walked from Florida to California for some six months, arriving on the sand in Huntington Beach Friday.

Their journey, meant to raise awareness about ocean pollution, ended in a surprise. 

In a moment that was caught on video, Keith Edwards got down on one knee and asked an unexpected question.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1hgrON1
link_name: Coast-to-Coast Journey With a Message Ends in a Surprise

status_message:
A sad, somber and angry President Obama walked before the cameras Thursday to bemoan another community traumatized by a mass killing, this time in Roseburg, Oregon. 

"Somehow this has become routine â€¦ We have become numb to this," the president said.

Predicting someone would accuse him of politicizing the issue, Obama responded: "Well this is something we should politicize. It is relevant to our common life together, to the body politic ... This is a political choice that we make, to allow this to happen every few months in America." 

As he reached the end of his 12-minute statement, Obama's anger and impatience seemed to shift to sadness and resignation.

"May God bless the memories of those who were killed today â€¦. may He give us the strength to come together and find the courage to change."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1MLGgYP

"I'm so blessed that â€¦ I was''t there at the wrong time," said an emotional Umpqua Community College student who was on campus during a deadly shooting. 

Ten people were killed and seven injured at the school in Roseburg, Oregon. The 20-year-old male shooter was dead after an exchange of gunfire with responding officers, authorities said.

"It's crazy â€¦ I have no idea how to handle it," student Natalie Cordelo said. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1iONNM2
link_name: Witness Recounts Shooting at Umpqua Community College

status_message:
Update: A naked man wielding a stick was arrested after viciously assaulting a 75-year-old woman during a random attack on a street in Irvine, police say.

The victim was walking her dog when Craig Andrew Ledbetter suddenly attacked her from behind, police said. He punched and kicked her, eventually knocking the grandmother of four to the ground.

Photographs taken in the hospital showed the brutality of the attack. The woman suffered a dislocated shoulder, a broken arm, internal bleeding and bite marks on her chest and back, family members say.

Officers had to use a Taser to take Ledbetter into custody. He was arrested and booked on suspicion of aggravated assault, elder abuse, animal cruelty and resisting a police officer.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Vo3RpD
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Surveillance video captured a vicious attack on a South L.A. shop owner after he refused to sell liquor to three young people -- believed to be minors.

The daughter of the 56-year-old victim said in a Facebook post that after her father refused to serve the trio, the two boys and a girl returned to the store a short time later with at least four others. 

"My dad had pepper spray and warned them to leave but they refused because they wanted to walk out with the alcohol," Beetna Lee wrote. 

Eventually, the argument moved outside, where one of the assailants smashed a bottle over the store owner's head.

Surveillance video showed the group kicking, stomping and even stabbing the shop owner as he lay motionless in the street.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1OH7GSz

A glow-in-the-dark turtle was captured in stunning video recently released by scientists. 

The turtle is the first reptile ever discovered to be biofluorescent, meaning it reflects light and re-emits it as different colors. 

The sight was "absolutely gorgeous," according to the photographer, who added that biofluorescent animals have "led to monumental breakthroughs in biomedical science."

The video was captured near the Solomon Islands in July, and was released this week. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1O7N4D2

Cellphone video captured a 19-year-old man allegedly trying to carjack two vehicles while wandering a busy Victorville street completely naked Monday morning. 

The woman who shot the footage said the incident began not far from a crowded school bus stop. He then got into violent confrontations with two drivers before sheriff's deputies arrived. 

At that point, he allegedly attempted to steal their patrol car. 

Deputies used force to take the man into custody. He was arrested on suspicion of carjacking, first-degree residential burglary and being under the influence of a controlled substance.

A registered sex offender who worked across the country as a professional photographer and children's tumbling coach has been arrested in Orange County on multiple child sex allegations.

Christopher Brown was booked on suspicion of possession and manufacturing of child pornography, digital penetration and oral copulation with a child and failure to register as a sex offender.

It is believed the 42-year-old used his various professions to lure his victims into taking illicit photographs and engage in sexual misconduct.

Investigators believe there may be additional victims.

"Life is like a roller coaster," one man said during his proposal to the woman who, by the end of the ride, was his fiancee. 

"It's got its up and downs, it's got twists and turns and it even throws you for a loop sometimes," he continues to say while riding the bumpy Indiana coaster. "You can go by yourself, but it's a lot more fun to go with another person. So I wanted to ask you if you want to be my roller coaster buddy. Allie will you marry me?"

Spoiler alert - she did say yes, and the entire proposal was captured on camera.

Demarrea Chante Barnes, 29, was booked on two assault charges, police said.

The victim, Tuyen Nguyen, remained hospitalized in critical but stable condition, according to his daughter.

Update: Surveillance video captured the dramatic end of a pursuit in Arleta, where a stolen pickup truck hit a station wagon before crashing through a fence and into a home.

The three occupants of the truck attempted to flee on foot but were apprehended by police.

The driver of the station wagon suffered minor injuries and was transported to a hospital for treatment.

An 80-year-old man in Texas has been rescuing stray dogs and treating them to rides on a train he built himself.

Eugene Bostick says the dogs get really excited about going on the train. He added he will keep doing it for as long as he can.

Meanwhile, a woman who took a photo of the "dog train" that went viral has started a GoFundMe to raise money to help Bostick care for the pets.

An apparently relieved House Speaker John Boehner sang the cheerful song "Zippity Doo Dah" multiple times during a press conference discussing his resignation announcement Thursday. 

Boehner said after witnessing Pope Francis address Congress the previous day, he hoped everyone would "head his call to live by the golden rule."

"Last night I started to think about this. And this morning I woke up, and I said my prayers as I always do, and decided, you know, today's the day I'm going to do this. As simple as that," Boehner said about the surprise announcement. 

He plans to leave Congress next month.

For the first time in three decades, a spectacular lunar combination will have stargazers around the world looking up. 

Sunday's supermoon will appear 14 percent larger and 30 percent brighter before it is eclipsed - a sight you won't be able to see again until 2033. 

And that's not all - the eclipse will also include this year's final "blood moon."

The partial lunar eclipse will begin at 5 p.m. PST and peak two hours later.

When Deputy Brian Bussell learned a mother and her two young sons were sleeping in an Ohio jail lobby because they had been evicted from their home and had nowhere else to go, he went out of his way to help the family. 

Bussell used his own money to pay for the family to stay for 10 days at a local hotel, then took them to Wal-Mart and bought them new clothes and shoes. He also helped the mom look for a more permanent housing solution. 

"This is a true act of kindness. He did not tell anyone at work what he had done but the lady took a picture with him and posted it on Facebook. That's actually how we found out," Butler County Sheriff Richard Jones said. 

Read KTLA's story here: www.ktlane.ws/1gRMUko

History was made Thursday morning when Pope Francis became the first pontiff to ever address a joint meeting of Congress.

In the speech, he urged the U.S. not to turn its back on undocumented immigrants, to reject the victimization of religious and ethnic minorities, to overcome income inequality and to save the planet from climate change, citing Scripture and the nation's founding ideals. 

The pope, who will later swap the corridors of power for a humble lunch with homeless people, also asked lawmakers to wage a constant battle against poverty and to ensure the wealth of the world is equitably shared and used to create jobs.

Read KTLA's story here: www.ktlane.ws/1iNLpFO

Five-year-old Sophie Cruz received a blessing and kiss on the cheek from Pope Francis after being plucked from a massive crowd of onlookers in Washington D.C.

The L.A. resident and American citizen, whose parents are from Mexico, then gave the pontiff a heartfelt letter she had written â€” a plea for him to lobby Congress and President Obama on immigration reform.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1MrgIQj

Pope Francis has canonized Junipero Serra, a controversial Spanish missionary who traveled to California and founded several mission. 

"Junipero sought to defend the dignity of the native community, to protect it from those who had mistreated and abused it. Mistreatment and wrongs which today still trouble us, especially because of the hurt which they cause in the lives of many people," Francis said through an English interpreter. 

The pope spoke at the Wednesday mass hours after first appearing at a welcoming ceremony at the White House where he touched on political issues such as climate change and immigration. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1JqAZ41

A 12-year-old girl who was "sobbing and desperate" when she was clinging to the side of a bridge and threatening to jump off it is alive and safe because of the actions of a South Pasadena officer, police said. 

Officer Chris Perez was on routine patrol Tuesday evening when he was flagged down by a group of citizens regarding a suicidal child. He said he knew he had to help her. 

"I was scared ... the last thing I wanted her to do was to jump, and the last thing I wanted her to do was to try to jump for me, and me not being able to catch her," he said. "But ... my main concern was just getting her to safety."

Eventually, the quick-thinking policeman gained the girl's trust, and was able to approach and get her to safety. As he pulled the child over, she hugged him tightly and then started to cry. 

Read KTLA's story here: www.ktlane.ws/1PtaErf

Pope Francis has arrived at the White House, where he delivered remarks ahead of a meeting with President Obama. 

"Mr. President, I am deeply grateful for your welcome â€¦ As the son of an immigrant family, I'm happy to be a guest in this country, which was largely built by such families," he said during his first direct address to the American people. 

He then weighed in on a number of political issues, including climate change, Cuba, marriage and immigration.

The pope said he was ready to listen to the "hopes and dreams of the American people" and to offer guidance to those charged with guiding the nation's political future "in fidelity to its founding principles."

Read KTLA's story here: ktlane.ws/1WicvDc

The victim was only 6 years old when it started. For two years she endured sexual abuse at the hands of a 32-year-old Victorville man who told investigators he liked "messy sex."

Luis Gilbert Sanchez was sentenced to 366 years to life in state prison after being convicted of what the deputy D.A. called "one of the worst" cases she's ever prosecuted.

"You can't articulate [what] was seen in this case. It's the most bizarre sexual conduct I've ever seen," said prosecutor Kathy DiDonato.

Update: In an encounter captured on a GoPro camera, a kayaker fishing near the Santa Barbara coast said he had to fight off a hammerhead shark that became aggressive with him. 

The hammerhead circled Mark McCracken's kayak for about 15 minutes, at times biting and ramming the man's small boat. He stated he hit the shark some 20 times in an effort to keep it at bay before finally fleeing back to shore. 

"Even after I was on shore, he paced back and forth in about 3 feet of water like he was just waiting for me to come back out," McCracken said. "Pretty bizarre and crazy experience to say the least." 

Hammerhead shark sightings that close to the shore are generally rare, but experts say they are known to visit Southern California waters during El NiÃ±o years. 

Read KTLA's story here: www.ktlane.ws/1L3i32A

Months after being covered in oil in the massive Refugio State Beach oil spill, the last of the rescued sea lions were released into the ocean at Imperial Beach Friday. 

"She had the attitude of a survivor," Jody Westberg from Sea World said of one of the sea lions that was tagged with a satellite transmitter to allow scientists to track her movements. 

"To see her get through this and be back out there now, and be a scientist at sea for us, this is what we've been working toward, Westberg said.

Under fire from critics and fellow presidential hopefuls yet again, Donald Trump spoke out Saturday in defense of his reaction to a supporter's comments about Muslims.

The commenter claimed President Obama is Muslim and asked the candidate how he plans to "get rid of" Muslim "training camps" in the country. 

Trump did not address the man's claims about the president and said, "a lot of people are saying that bad things are happening. â€¦ We're going to be looking at a lot of different things."

Trump later tweeted, "Am I morally obligated to defend the president every time somebody says something bad or controversial about him? I don't think so."

On Sunday, controversy continued to surround the GOP race when Ben Carson said Muslims should not be elected president of the United States.

"Oh my God. We need to get down," a man in the video says repeatedly "Guys, we need to go down. It's going to flood."

People seen in the video safely made it down as rain and hail fell around them and water cascaded down the mountainside. 

Seven other hikers in the area died, including six from Southern California.

Morales said the recent encounter with a hammerhead shark was his fourth in the past few weeks. He added he believed it was the same shark.

A photo showing 10 uniformed soldiers breastfeeding their children was removed from Facebook just hours after being posted, according to the photographer who took the picture.

Former airwoman Tara Ruby said she orchestrated the Army approved photo shoot so the images could be used to make a new nursing room at Fort Bliss more inviting.

After one of the photos was apparently removed from her Facebook business page -- Tara Ruby Photography -- and from other pages that had shared it, Ruby reposted the image. She and others vowed to "continue to do so every time it disappears."

Terrifying footage captured a driver's harrowing escape from a community apparently in ruins due to the Valley Fire.

In the video, massive flames rise on both sides of the vehicle, burning trees, brush and multiple structures as glowing embers fly through the air. 

The driver noted that he had waited too long to leave the rural Anderson Springs area.

"There was no smoke or ash coming our way, and there were no sirens or air support nearby, so we honestly didn't know how close (the fire) was," he said.

The Valley Fire had consumed 61,000 acres as of Monday morning and was only 5 percent contained

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1Oa4grg

A police officer extended a hand of compassion to a suicidal man in North Carolina Thursday, not only pulling him away from the ledge of a bridge but embracing him with a hug that was captured on local traffic cameras. 

"He was getting that hug whether he wanted it or not," the officer later said. "Call it tactical, call it compassionate, I think it was probably both."

The incident happened the night before World Suicide Prevention Day.

On this somber day, ceremonies and memorials were held around the country to remember the nearly 3,000 people who lost their lives in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. 

At the World Trade Center, where most of the victims were, the 14th anniversary was marked with bagpipers and drummers playing solemn tunes as the names of the victims were read. 

The National Anthem was played during a ceremony in Pennsylvania at the crash site of United Airlines Flight 93. 

And in Washington D.C., a flag was unfurled over the side of the Pentagon at sunrise. 

Moments of silence were also observed across America at the exact times each of the four planes crashed.

The chase came to an end after a CHP vehicle used a PIT maneuver to stop the suspect's vehicle.

He jumped out of the car with a gun and ran into the restaurant.

A Granada Hills family struggling to pay for their son's medical treatment, including a costly motorized wheelchair, have turned to social media after repeated denials from their insurance company.

Avery Faeth, 11, was diagnosed with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy a few months before his third birthday. There is currently no cure.

The Faeths filed a claim with their insurer to cover a motorized wheelchair that would allow Avery to stand with the push of a button. Doctors say it would enhance and elongate the sixth-grader's life, but the claim was ultimately denied.

Huntington Beach fishermen got an unexpected surprise over the weekend when they accidentally got the attention of a hammerhead shark. 

The shark was likely attracted to chum the fishermen were using to bait yellowtails. In the video, it's seen latching onto a fishing line and wrestling with the men for several seconds before setting itself free. 

Sunday's incident was the third reported shark sighting off Southern California's coast in about a week.

A Santa Ana homeowner who woke to find a gun pointed at his head Friday morning felt he had a 50-50 chance of survival when he decided to grab the intruder's weapon. 

"It was tough because he tried to pin me. It's a battle, 50-50, who's going to die here?" Erickson Dumaual asked himself at one point. 

Eventually Dumaual got hold of the gun and shot the intruder, who he says was continuing to pursue him, before shoving the man in the swimming pool and waiting for authorities to arrive.

A crew of lifeguards operating off of a rescue boat were outfitted with the cameras last week as they went about their daily work.

The result was a compilation video showing some of the 470 rescues the lifeguards made over a two day period on Aug. 29 and 30.

A 7-year-old boy who memorized the words to "Fight Song" while battling a cancerous tumor recently sang an amazing duet with the song's creator, Rachel Platten, that was captured on video at Children's Hospital Los Angeles.

Jeremiah Succar, who has stage-four atypical rhabdoid theratoid, started singing the song when he got bad headaches. "But now he sings it in the morning, before bed and during shots he has to get," his father said.

Recognizing how much the song meant to Jeremiah, his parents took to Instagram and started #RachelMeetJeremiah. Eventually, the hashtag found its way to Platten's Twitter account and she decided to surprise Jeremiah.

Thousands of tiny red crabs recently spotted off Santa Barbara County's coast are yet another sign that a "Godzilla"-like El NiÃ±o will hit California, according to researchers. 

"This is definitely associated with El NiÃ±o," said a biologist who captured the stunning footage, which was posted by the Channel Islands National Park. "This could be a record event."

The pelagic red crabs are typically found in Mexico's warm waters, but this year's warm sea-surface temperatures in the Pacific Ocean have led researchers to predict a strong El NiÃ±o will hit. 

"Godzilla El NiÃ±o" is expected to peak in the late fall or early winter, and may be stronger than in 1997 when the most powerful El NiÃ±o on record formed.

Coach Otis Newell, a popular football coach at Simi Valley High School, was fired after appearing in a rap music video talking about his former life on the street and past drug use.
