status_message:
Six-year-old Terry Fowler is being praised for saving his grandfather's life after the 84-year-old man from North Carolina recently had a heart attack. 

When he began experiencing intense chest pains, Willard Sumner told his grandson to call 911. Luckily for him, the young boy already knew what to do. 

As he told a local television station, his mother is a diabetic and has explained to him how to handle medical emergencies. 

The 911 dispatcher even called him one of the "best callers" he's spoken to "in a long time." 

As for Terry, he says he's just happy that his grandfather is still alive. 

Watch KTLA's full video here: http://ktlane.ws/1I5uNh7

Newly released video shows the exact moment giant panda Mei Xiang gave birth to her second cub on Saturday at the National Zoo. 

The footage shows the tiny but vocal hairless newborn squirming toward its mother right after being born. 

Both cubs appear to be healthy, zoo officials said, adding that their sex would be determined at a later time.  

Watch video of the first cub's birth here: http://ktlane.ws/1MManS9

A low-slung bridge in Massachusetts has become notorious as the site of frequent collisions involving high-profile trucks.

The Westwood Police Department posted a surveillance camera at the location, where at least seven of the often-spectacular crashes have been captured on video.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1EaX9vq

After being stuck in a sewage pipe for 10 hours, a tiny puppy was rescued and then reunited with its mother. 

The 1- to 2-week-old puppy was initially found when Phoenix police officers went to a home to serve a drug-related search warrant. 

Law enforcement and personnel from the Arizona Humane Society did everything they could think of to free the pup, which they successfully did late Thursday night much to their relief. 

"Oh my God, I'm so relieved. I don't want to cry," said AHS worker Nicole McCormick. "Oh, it's been all day. I'm so glad he's OK."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1NsCrdA

Dramatic video shows an employee being nearly run over as he tried to stop a robbery at cellphone store in Santa Ana earlier this month. 

Police released video of the getaway Thursday in hopes of identifying the driver and the man who ran out of the Cell Spot store on South Bristol Street with a phone on Aug. 4.  

"Now these subjects are looking at robbery, assault with a deadly weapon, hit and run â€¦ If he's willings to  ram into innocent victims, I'm sure they would have been willing to run over a pedestrian," Cpl. Anthony Bertagna said. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1U234oo

Stunning video captured a "fire whirl," or "firenado," at the front lines of the Soda Fire, which has burned nearly 300,000 acres on the Oregon-Idaho border. 

The photographer says the "fire whirl" shot flames a hundred feet into the air, causing hot dirt and ash to rain down. 

Such events occur when heat from a wildfire causes an updraft that spins up like a tornado, according to CNN.

The Soda Fire is one of about 80 burning across western states. Three firefighters were killed in one of the blazes in Washington on Wednesday. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1gYFuMK

Do you recognize this man? Police suspect he is responsible for 13 armed robberies in the Orange County area. 

Police say he typically waits until no one is around, then exposes a handgun to a lone cashier at locations such as Ralphs, CVS and Rite Aid. 

"There's no telling what he would do if somebody didn't hand over the money or how far he would take it to get the money," a Huntington Beach police officer said. 

"Share" this post to alert others.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1Lk6VOu

The first day of school brought mixed emotions for many students, including 4-year-old Andrew Macias, who spoke to us on his way to pre-kindergarten on Tuesday. 

When we asked Andrew if he would miss his mother during his first day at City Terrace Elementary School, the young man firmly said, "No." He paused a second and then began to tear up. Seconds later, Andrew's mom gave him a hug off camera.

Andrew was among thousands of LAUSD students who filled classrooms Tuesday morning as summer vacation officially came to an end. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1UQGTUH

Shocking video of an armed robbery victim using his car to run down two of his alleged robbers landed a teenager in jail, police said. 

Quinn Chavez, 18, had just been robbed at a park in New Mexico when surveillance video captured what happened next. The video shows two people running down a street as a black car speeds into view and slams into them, sending one person flying into the air. Both were OK.

Four people suspected in the robbery were charged earlier this week, but Chavez was also taken to jail. "You're never excused when you're using your vehicle as a weapon," an officer said.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1gHhT2Y

In a dramatic rescue, L.A. County firefighters hoisted a driver up to a helicopter after a vehicle crash that sparked a brush fire in Simi Valley.

The blaze erupted after a truck veered off the side of the 118 Freeway, tumbled down an embankment and burst into flames. A search-and-rescue team recovered the patient, who was flown to a nearby hospital in unknown condition.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1J8iSV2

A Tucson-based photographer has been trying to capture a rainbow and lightning bolt together in a single image for years. He finally did it.

"I was just trying to find a foreground without telephone poles or other junk in the way," Greg McCown wrote on Facebook. "Found it just in time as this was the last bolt to strike before the storm dissipated into nothing."

The result was a photograph that quickly went viral once it was posted on social media.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1N3WKxL
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
A mother who delivered a baby girl on the side of the 405 Freeway in Seal Beach offered sincere thanks after firefighter/paramedics arrived to help with no time to spare.

Holding her newborn and with her older daughter at her side, Anuradha Suratkal told Orange County Fire Authority first responders, "You are real heroes."

An OCFA dispatcher talked Suratkal's husband and daughter through the first moments of delivery as firefighters rushed to the family's SUV on Sunday.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Mluo1N
link_name: OC Firefighters Arrive Just in Time to Help Mom Deliver Baby o...

status_message:
The driver of a stolen box truck slammed into concrete K-rail off the 5 Freeway in Boyle Heights and ran from pursuing CHP officers, apparently trying to blend into the neighborhood.

He was taken into custody within minutes, about a half-hour after the chase began in the Santa Clarita Valley.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1gXHBRv
link_name: Pursuit Beginning in Santa Clarita Ends With Driver's Arrest i...

status_message:
U.S. Forest Service Firefighter Michael Hallenbeck, 21, has died battling the Sierra Fire near Lake Tahoe.

Hallenbeck was killed when a tree fell on him. He was the agency's second firefighter to die while on duty within the past week.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KZMCpl
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
BREAKING: A 20-year-old woman was arrested Saturday after allegedly abandoning her newborn son, with his umbilical cord still attached, in South L.A. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KXxSaj
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
On her wedding day, Brooke Zugg received a heartfelt letter that her adoptive mother had written to her 20 years earlier.

Zugg was just 18 months old when Sherry Blackledge wrote, in part: "We just want you to know how very much love and happiness you have brought to us. You have made us a truly great family."

Video shows Zugg and her mom crying tears of joy as the bride reads the letter for the first time.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1J1e1qm
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Dramatic video shows armed bounty hunters banging on the front door of a Phoenix house during a search for a fugitive â€” before realizing they had mistakenly arrived at the home of the city's police chief.

A swarm of police officers responded to the scene after Police Chief Joseph Yahner's significant other called 911.

One of the 11 bounty hunters was arrested on charges of criminal trespass and disorderly conduct.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1T7hlzU

An 8-year-old boy with disabilities, who is so small he had to be handcuffed around his biceps, can be heard crying out in pain after being restrained by a Kentucky sheriff's deputy.

Cellphone video shows the deputy handcuffing the boy after the child allegedly acted out in class.

The deputy said he restrained the boy after the child tried to elbow him.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1HnCZcn

Police released graphic video Monday of a man being run over by his own car, hoping it may lead to the arrests of two men involved in the hit-and-run.

The video showed the victim involved in an apparent road-rage confrontation with two men standing next to their vehicles on a street in Hemet.

Suddenly, one of the suspects jumped into the victim's car and struck him at a high rate of speed, according to police.

The victim received no life-threatening injuries.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1gFQaAc

Disturbing video shows a man in Florida chewing the skin off of his fingertips in what police said was an attempt to avoid identification.

The footage was recorded by a camera inside a patrol car, where 20-year-old Kenzo Roberts was being detained. He had been taken into custody following a traffic stop involving a stolen Mercedes-Benz and was allegedly in possession of a firearm and three fraudulent credit cards.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1hczksN

Two teen girls were caught on surveillance footage stealing two puppies who were still nursing and not yet ready to leave their mother, workers at a pet store in Compton allege. 

In the video, one girl can be seen leaning over a gate and grabbing a puppy while the other stands by. 

The alleged theft happened Thursday at Jazmin's Pet Supply. 

"Share" this post to alert others. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1Ic6hOZ

Body-cam video shows firefighters battling a dramatic blaze at a home in Victorville.

In the footage, released by the San Bernardino County Fire Department, flames are seen erupting through the roof after chainsaws are used to ventilate the structure.

Firefighters searched the house after extinguishing the inferno and found a dog, which was reunited with its displaced owners.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1DfPZ8x
link_name: Victorville House Fire

status_message:
Police are hoping to identify a man seen on surveillance video threatening clerks with a machete as he robbed a Walgreens in Placentia.

The man entered the store on East Yorba Linda Boulevard about 7:50 p.m. Wednesday wearing a ski mask and black clothes. Video shows the robber pointing his machete in the direction of the clerks as he demanded cash. 

The robber then fled the store on foot and removed his mask. He was described as white, about 29 years old, standing about 5 feet 10 inches tall with curly brown hair and was clean shaven.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1gtDZX7

Gut-wrenching video captured the moment a mother was confronted by police about leaving her 1-year-old daughter in a sweltering van in an Oklahoma Wal-Mart's parking lot. 

"Oh God. I can't believe I did that. Oh my God. My husband's going to kill me," the mother can be heard saying while screaming and crying. 

It's not known how long the toddler was left alone, but her temperature soared above 100 degrees during the Tuesday incident, CNN reports. 

The child is now with her father, and the mother has been detained.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1MXzSg8

Cellphone video posted on Instagram captured the brutal attack on an L.A. County lifeguard by several people on the Venice Pier.

The lifeguard was climbing down from a lifeguard tower on the pier when he was struck on the back of the head by a man.

The video uploaded by Shona Mccoy shows the lifeguard being hit repeatedly and knocked to the ground.

Three people in their 20s, two men and a woman, were taken into custody, according to police.

The lifeguard was being treated for injuries to his hand and arm, including a possible fracture.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1H8MbB9

(Warning: Contains graphic video) In what prosecutors have described as a "purposeful killing" and an "asinine act," a former University of Cincinnati police officer is seen on video fatally shooting a driver during a traffic stop. 

Body camera footage shows Officer Ray Tensing talking to Samuel DuBose after pulling him over for an alleged missing license tag. DuBose appears to start the car and begin driving away when he is shot in the head by Tensing. 

"This is the most asinine act I've ever seen a police officer make â€” totally unwarranted," a Hamilton County prosecutor said. 

Tensing's attorney told reporters that he believes the officer feared for his life. Tensing pleaded not guilty to murder and voluntary manslaughter charges Thursday. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1MvLTLH

"Deal with it yourself," a 911 dispatcher told a woman who was trying to keep a teenage gunshot victim alive before hanging up on her a few seconds later.

A gunman had just opened fire outside a house party in New Mexico striking 17-year-old Jaydon Chavez-Silver when his friend called 911.

During the call, the dispatcher is heard repeatedly asking if Jaydon was breathing. The caller responded: "He is barely breathing. How may times do I have to f**king tell you?"

That's when the dispatcher said, "You can deal with it yourself. I'm not going to deal with this, OK." 

Chavez-Silver died from his injuries.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1MtU0Zl

Boulder County Sheriff's deputies met their feathery match when they encountered an adorable baby owl in Colorado. 

A female deputy from the Sheriff's Office was among the group who crossed paths with the young Northern Saw-whet Owl while they were driving near a campground last Thursday. 

In the viral video, she talks to the tiny bird, which in turn appears to click back at her in response. A short time later, the owl safely flew away. 

Watch KTLA's full video here: http://ktlane.ws/1IpE9Jn

A couple's first date ended in an unexpected way after they got lost in the foothills above Altadena and were hoisted into a helicopter by a sheriff's search and rescue team.

Shaunt Ghazeri said he lost his sense of direction during a conversation and hike with Tina Mirzakhaniann.

They used his cellphone to call for help and expected to be met by deputies on foot. Instead they ended up being airlifted to safety.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1gWiXAB

Update: A 4.2-magnitude earthquake struck San Bernardino County around 5:45 a.m. Saturday, hitting about 1-mile east-southeast of Fontana.

The temblor was downgraded from a 4.3 to a 4.2 magnitude. No injuries were reported and the quake caused "superficial damage," according to fire officials.

Did you feel it?

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1I0nJUa
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Cellphone video sent to KTLA captures a shooting involving an armed man and LAPD officers on Ventura Boulevard.

Watch KTLA's video here:  http://ktlane.ws/13IZK8H

Police are searching for additional victims after they say this Huntington Beach cab driver raped a woman he was driving home.

Samy Hakim was arrested eight months after the November assault was reported, and now police believe there may be additional victims. 

Hakim drove a taxi for Huntington Beach Yellow Cab and frequented the Huntington Beach and Newport Beach areas.

"Share" this post to alert others. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1MqxtNO
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Update: A sex offender accused of sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl in Santa Clarita is in the U.S. illegally and had recently been released on bail from immigration custody, federal authorities say.

Kaene Dean, 26, a citizen of the Philippines, was released in April on $10,000 bond so he could be free while he contested his immigration case, the L.A. Times reported on Tuesday.

Dean has been charged with two counts of child sexual abuse and is being held in lieu of $110,000 bail.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KiPY3x
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Heavy rains triggered a massive mudflow in Wrightwood as a summer storm moved across Southern California.

Are you experiencing severe weather in your area? Post your photo in the comments section below; we might share it on the KTLA 5 News.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1CPZTgQ

A summer storm brought wild weather to Southern California this weekend, including record-rainfall and lighting that temporarily prompted the closures of several local beaches. 

Saturday's rain set daily and monthly records for parts of the area, including Downtown Los Angeles, which saw 0.38 inches of rain. 

More showers, thunderstorms, lightning, high surf, potential flash flooding and even hail could hit the region into Monday, according to the U.S. National Weather Service (NWS). 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1CPZTgQ

After saying Sen. John McCain "is a war hero because he was captured," Donald Trump attempted to walk back his blunder.

"Captured or not, all our soldiers are heroes!" the billionaire said on Twitter. But the damage to his presidential candidacy may be irrevocable.

A spokesman for McCain said the Vietnam War veteran had no comment on Trump's comments.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1fUp1Jq

"It felt like the car was getting ready to melt. It was so hot."

That's how Laya Fonseca described driving through the Cajon Pass as flames from the North Fire began approaching the side of the 15 Freeway.

"It was scary," said Fonseca, who was accompanied by her brother and a friend during the ordeal. They managed to drive to safety without being injured.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1gFDsRY

Update: About 20 vehicles stopped along the 15 Freeway were engulfed in flames as a rapid-moving wildfire jumped across lanes Friday afternoon. Another 10 vehicles were damaged. 

At least 3,500 acres have burned so far in the Cajon Pass. Only two minor injuries were reported.  

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1gFDsRY

While a woman and two teenage girls slept in a nearby bedroom, an alleged burglar was wandering through their Venice home.

Fortunately for investigators, the alleged robber provided a picture of himself committing the crime.

When the burglar picked up the victim's iPhone he accidentally activated a video application, which recorded him standing in the victims' living room, police say.

Anyone who recognizes the man was asked to call police.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Gp4tOd

This exclusive cellphone video shows the final moments of a deadly confrontation between Moreno Valley police and a man accused of attacking an officer and stabbing another person on Thursday. 

When officers located the man suspected in both attacks, he "was holding an unknown object at that time and refused to drop the item, and advanced on officers," a Riverside County sheriff's official said. 

The man was then shot by police. He was pronounced dead at the scene. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1OhFPFH

Three new giant otter pups made their debut at the Los Angeles Zoo on Wednesday.

The pups, two males and one female, were born on March 28.

They join their 10-month-old siblings, which were the first to be born at the Rainforest of the Americas habit since it opened in 2014.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1CEIZSH

When beachgoers saw a great white shark stranded on a shore in Cape Cod, they didn't run away â€” instead, they helped rescue it.

A bystander's video shows people pouring buckets of water on the 7-foot shark, which apparently beached itself while trying to catch a seagull.

Experts arrived at the scene, tied a rope to the shark's fin and towed it out to sea. It was then tagged before being released.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1DhlWbc

BREAKING: A stunning new look from the New Horizons spacecraft flyby of Pluto shows the first detailed images of the dwarf planet's surface since its discovery 85 years ago. 

NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration just released the image, which shows a mountain range with peaks jutting up to 11,000 feet above the icy body's surface. 

"Yesterday, America's space program took another historic leap for humankind. Today, the New Horizons team is bringing what was previously a blurred point of light into focus," NASA spokesman Dwayne Brown said.

Read KTLA's story here: http:// ktlane.ws/1J11j9L

A wild police chase through the San Gabriel Valley came to a dramatic end after the driver ran across all lanes of the 10 Freeway. He was chased off the roadway by someone who appeared to be a plain-clothed officer, Sky5 video showed. 

The pursuing person caught up with the driver a short time later and appeared to hit or shove him, forcing the driver to fall to the ground. He was later seen being handcuffed. 

Earlier in the chase, the pursuit driver had stopped at a gas station to fill up his tank, but was unable to do so because he had parked the car on the wrong side of the pump. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1V3jXT6

BREAKING: Graphic videos have been released showing Gardena police fatally shooting an unarmed 34-year-old man in 2013.

Officers responding to a bicycle theft stopped two men on bikes, mistakenly believing they might be the thieves. As it turned, out the men were helping look for the bike. Ricardo Diaz Zeferino, who was shot by officers, was the brother of the man whose bike was stolen.  

A federal judge ordered the videos released on Tuesday, saying the public had an interested in seeing them after the city settled a lawsuit over the shootings for $4.7 million.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1K5OHj9

A Texas police officer is being hailed as a hero for saving the life of a woman during a traffic stop. 

What Officer Dustin Clinkscales didn't realize when he pulled the woman over for talking on her cellphone was that the woman was choking and had taken it out to try and call for help.  

The officer immediately sprang into action, performing the Heimlich maneuver until the item in her throat dislodged. He then saved her from a possible head injury after she passed out and collapsed on the pavement. 

As it turns out, the woman who Clinkscales helped was the daughter of a colleague. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1CEOCjF

BREAKING: Firefighters are battling a brush fire burning along State Route 241 near Santiago Canyon Road that is 125 acres and growing.

Structures in Irvine Lake are threatened and evacuations have been ordered, according to Orange County officials. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1eX6Qlm

Nearly four months after he fell through the roof of a burning home, a Fresno firefighter appeared at an emotional news conference with his family and doctors to give an update on his condition.

"I appreciate all of the support from everybody," Capt. Pete Dern said. "I'm just here today to tell you I'm feeling pretty good."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1dV0bqW

Dramatic cellphone video captured a dangerous scene in the Hollywood Hills: an Audi driving backwards for miles on a narrow and windy stretch of Laurel Canyon.

Kevin Zanazanian, who shot the video, told KTLA the stunt jeopardized the safety of pedestrians and motorists. He said he recorded it for safety reason.

After the video was uploaded to YouTube, the Los Angeles Police Department said it was investigating the incident and working to identify the driver, whose identity remains a mystery.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Mnp3DV

An 89-year-old Burbank woman recounted being brutally attacked by a man during a home invasion robbery.

Gerri Dickinson told police that the intruder forced his way into her house and tied a sheet around her neck during the assault, which left her with several cuts and bruises on her arms and face.

Dickinson used a medical alert system to call for help after the man fled, police said.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1ISGSvs

Bystanders captured dramatic video of four women being struck in an Illinois hit and run.

Incredibly, no one was seriously injured in the incident, which East St. Louis police say stemmed from an ongoing feud.

Authorities have released the name and a photo of an 18-year-old woman suspected of being behind the wheel during the crash.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1HUg7rA

News video shows the dramatic rescue of a disabled man who was trapped in a flooded building after a big rig sheared a fire hydrant in Glassell Park.

The amputee's cries for help were initially inaudible due to the sound of gushing water from the hydrant, which caused the structure's roof to partially collapse.

After firefighters used chainsaws to cut open a door, a stream of debris poured out and the man was escorted to safety.

"I thought I was going to drown," Chris Gregg said. "These guys are the greatest in the world."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1TnKuss

Update: L.A. firefighters have called knockdown on a fire that spread quickly from nearby brush to the attic of a Mormon church in Glassell Park. The church's roof collapsed, causing significant damage, and two firefighters were injured.
link_name: Brush Fire Speads, Burns Mormon Church in Glassell Park; 2 Firefighters Injured

status_message:
Thousands of fans gathered at L.A. Live Tuesday to honor the U.S. women's national soccer team in their first public appearance since winning the FIFA Women's World Cup. 

The women's team routed defending champion Japan in a 5-2 victory Sunday, bringing home a record third championship and the first Women's World Cup title since 1999.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1LUIre7

Florida State University quarterback De'Andre Johnson, 19, can apparently be seen punching a woman in the face during an argument captured on surveillance video released Monday.

A day after the June incident, Johnson was suspended from the team. He was later dismissed and charged with battery. 

"While it is clear from the video that De'Andre Johnson was not the initial aggressor, his family wants to take the lead in helping him learn and grow from this experience," the former quarterback's attorney said. 

The woman suffered bruising under her left eye, swelling to the left cheek and upper lip, and a small cut near the bridge of her nose, according to court documents.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1HJNopi

A rare sight was captured on video over the holiday weekend off Southern California.

Video recorded by a drone off the coast of Newport Beach shows the breathtaking image of a humpback whale creating its own rainbow.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1JQNhWF

Video captured the terrifying moment a plane crashed on a crowded Carlsbad beach while families celebrated the Fourth of July holiday. 

Screams can be heard as beachgoers watched the single-engine plane descend. Crowds then ran to the scene.

A 12-year-old boy suffered a gash to the head when he was hit by a wing. The pilot was the only person in the plane and was not injured.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1NJcFiw

A bald eagle from the L.A. Zoo soared high above the outfield at Dodger Stadium as part of a stirring Fourth of July celebration at Chavez Ravine.

The majestic bird was released from a box in the upper left-field stands, took flight and then landed on the arm of its handler in right field.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1G0LeKs

Graphic video shows a theft suspect being fatally shot by a Texas police officer after brandishing what authorities said was a BB gun.

James Bushey, 47, was escorted out of a Palestine restaurant by two officers after allegedly stealing beer from a nearby store.

The footage shows Bushey pulling out what appears to be a handgun following a brief struggle with police.

The officers involved in the shooting returned to duty after a grand jury reviewed the incident.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1LPL692

A burglary suspect suddenly broke down in tears in a Florida courtroom when he realized the judge was a former middle school classmate.

"I'm sorry to see you there. I always wondered what happened to you, sir," Judge Mindy Glazer said.

She recalled Arthur Booth as "the nicest kid." "I used to play football with him, all the kids looked up to him," she said.

Glazer wished Booth luck and told him she was hopeful he could turn his life around.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1LIFTPb

Stunning underwater video shows a turtle's-eye view of Australia's Great Barrier Reef, the largest living structure on Earth and one of the world's most biologically diverse places.

Posted last week by WWF Australia, the video comes amid a campaign to protect the UNESCO World Heritage Site from dumping and bring attention to other threats to the reef.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1LIncLB

A homeless man who turned in $2,400 he found on a street in Canada has rejected money raised for him after his story drew media attention, saying instead that he really just wants a job. 

The unidentified good Samaritan returned the large sum to police in mid-June. After locating the money's original owner, they tracked down the homeless man to inform him that a GoFundMe page had raised thousands for him. 

His response surprised them, as he requested in a letter that the money be donated to others in need. He then told them that what he really wants is a job. 

A local writer is working to honor the man's request, and has asked for the public's help in finding him a job. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1NzHQMz
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
A robber was caught on surveillance video punching a 7-Eleven employee in the head and knocking him to the ground before jumping over the service counter and continuing the beat the 24-year-old man.

Two men made off with an undisclosed amount of cash from the Fontana store as well as additional merchandise. 

Police are asking for the public's help identifying the assailants.

"Share" this post to alert others. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1JvgqcD

A man was beaten with a tire iron in an apparently unprovoked attack that was captured on surveillance video at a gas station in Seal Beach.

The footage shows the 26-year-old victim pumping gas into his Jeep when suddenly he is approached from behind by the assailant, who remains at large.

"Share" this to alert others.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Hv3qU7

A Connecticut man who didn't have his glasses with him accidentally bought the wrong lottery ticket, a happy mistake that ended up making him $30,000 richer. 

Bob Sabo had meant to buy two $20 lottery tickets from an instant ticket vending machine, but ended up with a 30X Cash ticket instead. When he got home, he discovered the ticket had won the top prize. 

"Winning the way we did was a very freaky thing," Sabo told CT lottery officials. "I bought the [winning] ticket by accident." 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1SYbTAX
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Two men purposely got up close to juvenile great white sharks in Huntington Beach on Friday with one goal in mind - selfies.

Using stand-up paddle boards, the two men move alongside the sharks for more than two minutes, at one point dunking a paddle in the water directly above a shark and later sitting on a board and dipping both feet in the water. 

Although experts say the sharks are likely feeding on the abundance of stingrays living near the shoreline and are not after large prey - such as humans, lifeguards have warned people to be cautious, the OC Register reports.

An activist climbed a flag pole outside the South Carolina Statehouse and removed the Confederate battle flag.

A quick-thinking 10-year-old girl made a bold move to save herself and her little sister when a thief stole the family car while they were still inside.

Before she died, 2-year-old Sophia O'Neill endured a horrific beating that left her with a torn liver, a split kidney, damage to her pancreas and a collapsed lung. Doctors also found rib fractures, both new and healing.

Police say her life-ending injuries came at the hands of a Minneapolis teenager who was dating her mother.

When Sandy Weber's son Erik was diagnosed with autism as a toddler, doctors told her that he would likely be placed in an institution.

SWAT officers shot and killed a man suspected of unleashing a barrage of gunfire on Dallas' police headquarters and planting explosives outside the building on Saturday.

After being separated by hundreds of miles and five years, an Army veteran was reunited Wednesday with her long-lost pet poodle.

When Jessica Gutierrez was deployed to Afghanistan in 2010, she left "Cookies Chanel" with her sister in New Mexico. Soon after,  Cookies disappeared.

Somehow, the little poodle made her way to San Diego where she was found by animal services workers. They used the micro-chip in Cookies neck to reunite her with her grateful owner.

"I actually didn't expect her to remember me ... but she did," Jessica Gutierrez said.

A man who has posted more than 100 videos of alleged water waste in L.A. amid a statewide drought says he's not trying to shame people, and only wants to promote positive change. 

Tony Corcoran videotapes examples of water waste, then posts many of them to his YouTube page, along with addresses. Some of the videos are tagged #droughtshaming. 

But not everyone is happy with what Corcoran and others who engage in so-called "drought-shaming" are doing, with one online user arguing that it promotes "greater discord among the civilian population." 

What do you think of the practice?

They are friends and coworkers, but now two L.A. County sheriff's deputies say they have become brothers after one donated a portion of his liver to help save the other's life. 

"I don't think I can ever pay him back," said deputy Jorge Castro, who was diagnosed with a failing liver in January 2014.

"He's given me life, my boys, my wife, the rest of my family, but I never thought I was going to have a brother at age 40."

After a yearlong search for a transplant, Castro thought he would die by the end of 2015. His luck changed when one of his comrades said he would help, and was found to be a perfect donor match.

Hidden cameras caught video of officers appearing to eat marijuana-laced "edibles" at a Santa Ana pot shop during a raid last month, according to an attorney for a medical marijuana patient who was present.

A New Mexico mother says her 8-month-old daughter is alive today because of the quick actions of an Albuquerque police officer. 

Alyssia Rios called for help when her baby wouldn't wake up, and Officer Martin Smith was the first person to respond to the scene. Body camera video just released by the Albuquerque Police Department shows him performing CPR on the unconscious child. 

A short time later, little Karly Rios woke up, much to the relief of her mother. 

"That's what makes this job good," Smith told a local TV station. "That's the good part of it."

A rarely seen film shot just before Amelia Earhart left California on her ill-fated attempt to fly around the world is being released for the first time.

The film was shot in Burbank in late May 1937, and featured Earhart posing in front of the plane she was flying when she disappeared. 

About a month into Earhart's around-the-world trip, she lost radio contact during a 2,500-mile mid-Pacific stretch between New Guinea and a small island she intended to land on. Her plane was never found.

Protesters confronted L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti outside his home and expressed their anger over the LAPD's fatal shooting of Ezell Ford, a mentally ill black man.

More than a dozen rescued sea lions bounded back into the ocean about five weeks after someone poisoned them with chlorine at the Pacific Marine Mammal Center.

Some are calling Army Capt. Steve Voglezon a hero after he helped rescue a couple trapped in their vehicle following a head-on two-vehicle collision in North Carolina. 

Voglezon was driving when he saw the fiery wreckage and stopped to help on Sunday. He grabbed a fire extinguisher to break one of the car's windows, pulling the occupant to safety. 

"We have a calling to do whatever we we're called to do," Voglezon told a local TV station. "Today I was called to be there at that spot at that time."

John Spurrell, who shot this cellphone video of the rescue after helping get the driver out of the other vehicle, was among those who credited the Army captain with saving lives that day.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1c1kVMX

An altercation among rival biker gangs at a Texas restaurant escalated into a shootout that left nine people dead and at least 17 hospitalized.

More than 170 people were arrested in the incident, which apparently began inside the restaurant's bathroom with a shove or disrespectful glance, authorities said.

Officers at the scene returned fire when when they were fired upon, according to a Waco police spokesman. None of the officers were injured.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1JsZ3Yu

A husband and father of two from Riverside County was among six Marines identified Sunday after their bodies were discovered among a helicopter's wreckage over the weekend. 

"He was a great father, he was a great Marine.  He loved his country and he really wanted to go to Nepal to help those people," his wife told CNN after learning of his death. "We're going to do everything we can, every day until we meet again, to make him proud."

Sgt. Eric Seaman, 30, was on a disaster relief mission in Nepal when the U.S. Marine Corps helicopter he was aboard lost contact. The wreckage was not found for several days. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KZx3tC

"Not one more child drowns." 

That's the mission of ISR, which since the 1960s has been teaching infants how to be safe in the water.

"I will teach them how to roll into a float and stay in that floating position. I teach them how to hold their breath and wait until someone comes and rescues them," says ISR instructor Andrea Berman.

On Monday on the KTLA 5 News at 11, we'll dive in with infants learning water skills, and we'll also go in depth uncovering a silent summer killer known as secondary drowning.

A videotaped gaffe by Rep. Loretta Sanchez has sparked outrage among those who found the comment to be racially offensive.

Sanchez, a candidate who wants to replace retiring Senator Barbara Boxer, was speaking at a California Democratic party convention event when she made a stereotypical Native American "war cry."

Referring to the difference between Indian Americans and Native Americans, the congresswoman tapped her hand to her mouth.

Sanchez's main opponent, Attorney General Kamala Harris, was later asked for her reaction to the gesture.

"I don't know what to say to that. That â€“ that â€“ that's shocking," said Harris, whose mother is Indian.

(Video courtesy of Uduak-Joe Ntuk)

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1B5q8tC

Dramatic surveillance footage captured the moment a freight train crashed into a bus in Georgia.

All of the passengers were able to flee the bus before the collision, but video shows the impact caused the bus driver to be thrown to the ground. 

A passenger who was able to exit the bus was also struck by its doors as the train ripped through the transit vehicle. 

Everyone was reported to have survived the crash.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1IF00O6

Body cam video appears to show a Georgia police officer being dragged by a car after questioning a suspected shoplifter.

Brandon Christopher Adams, 23, turned himself in several days after the incident, which took place at a gas station in Savannah. He faces charges of aggravated assault on a police officer and felony obstruction of an officer.

The policeman was almost run over by the vehicle, officials said. He suffered minor injuries.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Gfn58j

There was some screaming and a lot of hissing as a Beverly Grove woman faced off with a stubborn and potentially dangerous opossum that had taken up residence in her laundry room.

While trying to get the opossum to leave, Tara McVicar, made a remarkable discovery. 

Watch more of the video here: http://ktlane.ws/1EaEDwn

In her battle against ovarian cancer, Cheryl Shuman says it was CBD -- the compound in marijuana known for its health benefits -- that saved her life.

"I went from being on 27 pharmaceuticals, unable to go to the bathroom by myself to, within three months, being able to go back to work full time," Shuman said.

After her recovery, the mother of two became a self-described "pot evangelist." She currently serves as CEO of the Beverly Hills Cannabis Club.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1Hqw9pF

Video of a massive lightning strike spreading across the Hollywood sky was captured and shared on social media Thursday night.

The late-season storm brought thunderstorms, lightning, hail and even snow to the drought-stricken area. Forecasters predict more wet weather as a second system moves through the region Friday. 

The lightning strike recorded by @this_means was shared with KTLA after being posted on Instagram.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1ROjBOu

After crashing his vehicle near a lifeguard tower during a police pursuit in Redondo Beach, a male driver ran into the ocean and removed his clothes, authorities said. 

Video captured by Sky5 showed the naked man being combative and apparently resisting rescue attempts Thursday night. 

After a struggle, lifeguards got the man back to shore and officers took him into custody. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1E9i2jN

Forget reading, writing and arithmetic. Cannabis Career Institute, based in North Hollywood, teaches its pot pupils everything there is to know about the marijuana industry.

"Education is the only way to move this industry forward, so on every front, you have to have some kind of outreach or educational program," said founder Robert Calkin.

Courses are available around the country, including in Los Angeles.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1Hqw9pF

Some amazing close-up video of a great white shark sighted off the Orange County coast was captured by deputies who attached a GoPro camera to end of a boat hook and lowered it into the water. 

The fireboat was patrolling offshore from Surfside on Monday morning when they spotted the large fish, which marine scientists confirmed was a great white shark. 

The Orange County Sheriff's Department, CA posted the GoPro video, along with video shot from an airship, to its Facebook page on Wednesday night.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1FmCq7W

A 20-year-old San Bernardino woman was arrested on suspicion of child endangerment after her 3-year-old daughter pointed a loaded handgun at police.

Detectives were questioning the 20-year-old in connection with the theft of two handguns from an L.A. County Sheriff's Department patrol car, when the toddler walked out of a bedroom holding a firearm.

The girl pointed the black semiautomatic pistol at officers, who immediately took the weapon from the little girl. The gun was loaded and turned out to be one of the stolen weapons.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1RFXRo7
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Surveillance video shows a police officer using what appears to be pepper spray on two handcuffed teens who are sitting inside a holding cell in an Illinois city jail.  

The video â€” from Alton, a St. Louis suburb â€” was recorded in January but just made public this week. It shows one of the boys twisting in pain after the officer sprays him.

The city's police chief says an investigation is ongoing. Illinois state officials are also investigating.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1PHgcx0

Meet the so-called "Martha Stewart of Marijuana."

In addition to her role as CEO of the Beverly Hills Cannabis Club, Cheryl Shuman also manages a $100 million fund that invests in cannabis-related projects.

"I would like to see cannabis as accepted at dinner as much as a wine tasting would be," Shuman says.

Our weeklong series, "Money Smart: The Business of Marijuana," continues on the KTLA 5 News at 11 tonight.

A woman arrested for DUI in Fontana on New Year's Eve said she may have ended up killing herself if not for the police officer who took her to jail.

Mariya Fair, a married mother of two who had recently attempted suicide, said the arrest changed her life. "He was genuinely concerned," said Fair, who thanked her arresting officer in person the day after Mother's Day. 

"I was very surprised when she came in ... I didn't expect someone to say 'thank you,'" Officer Wayne Blessinger said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1IAgLs4

Reminiscent of the wild, Wild West, entrepreneurs are flocking to California and setting up pot shops in anticipation of recreational sales becoming legal after the 2016 elections.

Investors could be getting in on the ground floor as the legality of the industry changes.

What do you think? Should California legalize recreational marijuana?

Our weeklong series, "Money Smart: The Business of Marijuana," continues tonight at 11 on the KTLA 5 News.

Update: Trapped under a vehicle after being struck by a car in a 99 Cents store parking lot, an 80-year-old woman is crediting three officers from the El Segundo Police Department with rescuing her. 

After witnesses called 911, the officers quickly responded from a nearby station and lifted the car off Chickie Lea-Bou. She sustained major injuries but is expected to fully recover. 

"I think we underestimate our police officers," she said from her hospital bed, adding that she planned on making a gift for them. 

The driver, also 80, apparently mistook the gas for the brake, Lea-Bou said. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KFhuar

A medical marijuana dispensary in North Hollywood is about to debut a new convenience for clients: a drive-thru.

"Nobody has a drive-thru right now," said the dispensary's budtender, Michael Holland. "So if, let's say, for whatever reason it's a little busy in here or somebody's on the rush and ... they already know what they need, they can easily come through."

What do you think?

The rapidly changing pot industry is the focus of our weeklong series, "Money Smart: The Business Behind Marijuana," airing every weeknight on the KTLA 5 News at 11.

Residents are "livid" after a water main broke for the fourth time in three years in West Hollywood on Sunday, one local claimed. 

"What really gets me the most is that the gallons and gallons of water that was wasted, this entire block of over 265 people that live here, could have used that water for a week," WeHo resident Roxanne McBride said.

Thousands of gallons were wasted and locals were without water for much of Mother's Day, officials said. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1J2andM

The creator of one of Los Angeles' most recognizable and iconic sculptures - the LACMA's highly-photographed "Urban Light" - died Sunday. 

Since the 1970s, controversial artist Chris Burden gained attention for performances like locking himself in a school-sized locker and staging his own shooting, as well as his many sculptures.

"Chris's work combines the raw truth of our reality and an optimism of what humans can make and do," LACMA's director said. 

Burden died of malignant melanoma at his Topanga Canyon home, according to a friend. He was 69.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1zR3bPB

"Am I dying? I know I'm dying. Just hand me my walkie-talkie."

Those were among the last words of a Mississippi policeman after he and and another fatally shot colleague were found by two citizens on a street in Hattiesburg.

K-9 Officer Benjamin Deen, 34, and rookie Officer Liquori Tate, 24, both died shortly after being rushed to a hospital.

Three suspects have been charged in connection with the incident. 

Among them was 26-year-old Curtis Banks, who said "No sir, I didn't do it," in response to a reporter's question as he was led into a police station.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1EqhEPg

A Montana wildlife official captured video of an unnerving encounter between humans and bears on a bridge in Yellowstone National Park.

The footage shows several apparent tourists making a dash to safety after finding themselves a little too close to a black bear sow and her three cubs.

No one was injured in the incident, and the animals made their way safely back to the forest, officials said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1IsxAVU

Tens of thousands of law-enforcement officers attended the funeral of NYPD Officer Brian Moore, 25, who was shot in the face while trying to question a suspect in Queens.

Eight pallbearers carried Moore's casket into St. James Roman Catholic Church on Long Island as bagpipes played "Amazing Grace."

During the service, Police Commissioner William Bratton choked up as he promoted Moore, posthumously, to detective first grade. Applause filled the church. 

Afterward, the flag was folded and presented to the slain officer's family.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1IV11Az

The Cleveland Cavaliers  are apologizing for a controversial video that many think mocks domestic violence. 

In the video, a man wearing a Cavs T-shirt is recreating a scene from the movie Dirty Dancing with his girlfriend when he realizes she is wearing a Chicago Bulls T-shirt and decides to throw her to the ground.

The Cavaliers have pulled the video, which has caused plenty of negative reactions, but some have called the outrage overblown. 

What do you think?

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1EVfUjc

A newly released dashcam video shows a white Delaware police officer kicking a black suspect in the face, leaving him unconscious.

Cpl. Tom Webster of the Dover Police Department was initially cleared of wrongdoing in the 2013 incident. But he was indicted Monday on an assault charge after the state's attorney general's office took the case to a second grand jury.

The suspect, Lateef Dickerson, was taken to a hospital after his arrest and treated for a broken jaw.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KRBdV1

A dramatic end to a grueling endurance test showed the determination of one Army captain as she tried to earn a rare military decoration at Fort Dix in New Jersey. 

After a 12-mile march, and with the finish line in sight, Capt. Sarah Cudd began to falter, but she didn't give up. 

With fellow soldiers cheering her on, Cudd crossed the finish line under the three-hour time limit.

Less than 25 percent of soldiers who attempt the test are successful.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1IicJGg

A woman claims a Panorama City man admitted to killing his roommate and storing her body in a closet.

"She scratched him and then he grabbed her by her neck and squeezed it and squeezed it and squeezed it until she stopped moving," the woman, who goes by the name of Bubbles, said the suspect told her.

Police were able to find the body and arrested Mario Villalobos on suspicion of homicide. He was being held on $1 million bail. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1ENIKCf

Dramatic video recently captured a motorcyclist trapped under a truck after a three-vehicle crash on a freeway in Corona.

In the video, dozens of people and a paramedic official try to help the motorcyclist, and eventually use several jacks to lift the truck and drag him out to safety.

"It's totally amazing. I mean, the car was clearly pressuring him," one man said. "I'm glad he's OK. Doesn't matter what race you are, or who you are, everybody got out of their cars, trying to help the guy out."

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1IIyhuC

Julio Benitez became so enraged at the selfies his wife posted on Instagram that he beat her in the head, tried to choke her, and threatened to kill her, Fresno police said.

The young mother was able to break free and ran away with two children, ages 5 and 7. But Benitez was able to get away with a 2-year-old child, according to police.

The 37-year-old eventually returned home with the child and was arrested.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1AB39GE
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Devastated when their beloved dog was taken during a messy break-up three years ago, a San Diego family was overjoyed when they were reunited with him after he was found nearly 2,500 miles away. 

When Andrea Arce and her two young daughters first saw the German shepherd, it was as if no time had passed at all. The dog whined and scratched at his crate, clearly recognizing his family. 

"It's a connection that we had the first three years of his life," Arce said, holding back tears of joy. "We never forgot him and he never forgot us."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1EQ3HO0

A shirtless man got himself into quite a predicament after climbing up a basketball hoop in Seattle and somehow managing to get stuck upside down. 

Hanging by a foot, the man flailed and thrashed about while officers tried to figure out how to get him down.  

Eventually, a couple of firefighters came in with a ladder, cut the net down and rescued him. 

"He may be arrested for property destruction, or at least goal-tending," the Seattle Police Department tweeted on Friday. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1JKpcDa

Update: Prince William and Kate Middleton introduced their newborn daughter to the world outside London's St. Mary's Hospital.

The family then departed in a Range Rover after the prince placed the new royal baby, snug in her car seat, inside the vehicle.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1GEIX8N

A South L.A. woman says she was thrown to the ground by a male LAPD officer as she tried to record her neighbor's own violent altercation with police, and the whole thing was caught on video.

Deirdre Mehmood said she grabbed her cellphone when she saw police using a Taser on her neighbor, whose home had been vandalized, prompting the LAPD response.

As she tried to record police actions, a female officer reacted angrily, and then a male officer threw Mehmood the pavement, the video appears to show.

"He never gave me a command to 'get back,' or 'hey, stop.' He never says anything to me," Mehmood said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1JdIzAY

A 73-year-old ex-Marine in Northern Californian says he punched a bear in the face to save his two dogs.

Carl Moore says he would do it again to protect his dogs, who were sleeping on the porch when the bear approached.

According to several witnesses, the bear reared up and turned toward Moore, who threw a punch that sent the bear running.

"Boom, I hit him good," Moore said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1zwtgng

In less than a month, this could be similar to the view you'll get from the newly opened reboot of the classic Colossus roller coaster at Six Flags Magic Mountain.

Twisted Colossus is set to open May 23, the Valencia amusement park announced this week. The ride replaces the original wooden roller coaster, which shut down in August after 36 years in operation.

The new "record-breaking" hybrid coaster will offer a four-minute ride over nearly 5,000 feet of track.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1biitRO

Days after Nepal's devastating and deadly earthquake, there was a glimmer of hope as rescuers pulled a teen who had been buried beneath the rubble for nearly six days to safety. 

A large crowd erupted in cheers as a search and rescue crew brought Pemba Tamang's was carried to safety. Despite his difficult ordeal, the 18-year-old showed no signs of serious injury. 

According to a Nepalese Armed Police Force official, Tamang dodged death because of a motorcycle that shielded him from the pressure of the concrete and steel and he "survived by good faith." 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1bG9Y3u

Update: An earthquake that struck near Carson has been downgraded from a 3.6 to a magnitude 3.4, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

The temblor was centered 14 miles south of Los Angeles. 

Did you fee it? 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1DEDsVu

A woman was arrested Wednesday after allegedly setting fire to a gas pump in Jerusalem after a motorist refused to give her a cigarette.

Surveillance video shows the woman talking to a man as he put gas into his car. She starts to walk away, then turns around and approaches him again.

Israeli police say the woman pulled a lighter from her pocket and ignited the gas pump.

No one was injured.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1GxNU3f

Two pregnant cows were hoisted from a 30-foot animal trailer that overturned on the westbound 210 Freeway in Sylmar Wednesday, and Sky5 was overhead.

The vehicle's driver was hospitalized in serious condition. Three sheep and a dog were also rescued.

About 40 firefighters responded to the crash, which prompted lanes closures and miles of backed-up traffic.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1FylEBr

After making a sharp U-turn, and appearing to nearly lose control of the car, a man was detained following a pursuit through South L.A. 

Police pursued the reckless driver for about 30 minutes, when the man ran on foot briefly before surrendering Wednesday morning. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1DVUmzA

Amid the angry and violent protests in Baltimore this week, one child's kind gesture is being shared on social media as a sign of goodwill in a city rocked by unrest.

The photo was posted to Facebook on Tuesday by Bishop Cromartie in Baltimore. It shows a young boy with his arm outstretched offering a water bottle to a police officer in riot gear.

"One of the many pictures that I captured today in the midst of helping clean up the city," wrote Cromartie. "It speaks volumes."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1PV01yj
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Update: Police hope video of a hit-and-run driver backing into an 86-year-old woman at a McDonald's parking lot in Huntington Beach will lead to someone identifying the driver and his passenger. 

The video shows a gray Dodge Challenger backing into the victim as she was walking across the parking lot. The driver and passenger both exit the vehicle briefly, then get back inside and flee northbound on Beach Boulevard. 

The victim, who police said suffered head injuries, was left lying on the ground. 

Police are looking for witnesses and have asked that anyone with information call the Police Department's information hotline at 714-375-5066.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1DxV1Xe

A Baltimore mother is being praised after cameras captured her berating and smacking her son after reportedly seeing him throw rocks at police during the city's violent protests.

"I wish I had more parents that took charge of their kids out there tonight," the police commissioner said. 

Nearly 200 people were arrested on Monday after more than 140 vehicles were set on fire and at least 15 police officers were injured during the protests. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1QEFv6b

Hundreds of National Guard members have been deployed to  Baltimore after a state of emergency was declared in the wake of a day of rioting that injured 15 police officers.

As darkness fell on the city, flames erupted at a church senior center in Baltimore as well as several other buildings.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1OZnNH5

Incredible video shows powerful winds knocking 11 railroad cars from a bridge onto the ground below during a severe storm near New Orleans Monday.

A news photographer's camera was rolling when the derailment occurred. The railcars were empty and no injuries were reported.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1QBsGcS

Sky5 spotted three whales swimming off the coast of Bolsa Chica State Beach Monday morning. 

The small pod, which was believed to be a family of gray whales, was located about a quarter-mile from the beach. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1GpHqDE

Dramatic video shows boaters navigating a deadly storm during a sailboat race in Mobile Bay, Alabama.

Two people died and five others were missing amid the high winds and heavy rain, which were captured by a boater's GoPro camera.

As many as 40 people were rescued from the water during the regatta, according to the U.S. Coast Guard.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1FrxoFO

Large flames and plumes of dark smoke could be seen from miles away after a tanker truck carrying 8,500 gallons of gasoline overturned and caught fire on Sunday. 

Both sides of the 710 Freeway in Bell remain closed as firefighters work to clean up the roadway.

No one was injured in the crash. 

Video courtesy of Ludwing Perez.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KlnN3k

President Obama jokingly turned the tables on this "anger translator" â€” aka comedian Keegan-Michael Key â€” while riffing on climate change at the White House Correspondents' Association dinner.

"Every serious scientist says we need act. â€¦ Miami floods on a sunny day and instead of doing anything about it, we've got elected officials throwing snowballs in the Senate," Obama said, his voice rising.

"OK, I think they got it, bro," Luther said.

"What about our kids? What kind of stupid short-sighted, irresponsible, bullâ€”" Obama continued before his translator cut him off.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1DNsopq

A single image captures the overwhelming moment when a mother battling breast cancer first breastfed her newborn son.

The unidentified woman was diagnosed with stage 3 breast cancer halfway through her pregnancy. 

The woman had one breast removed, underwent chemotherapy while carrying her son, and then was induced at 36 weeks in order to receive more treatment.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1GrxgVA
