Update: A mother has been arrested after her three children - ages 1, 3 and 4 - were critically injured while home alone during a house fire in Fresno.

Original Post: Helmet cameras recently captured firefighters wading through a pitch-black home and dark plumes of smoke as they frantically rescued three unconscious children from a burning Fresno building. 

"The mother had given us a general direction of where the kids were to be located. It's zero visibility inside the building â€¦ we're feeling down the wall trying to recognize objects," a local fire chief said of the incident. 

The three children are in critical condition and an investigation into where the mother was at the time of the incident is underway.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1Es39OJ

A young mother in Olympia, Washington, allegedly told police that she slashed the throats of her 6-month-old twins and 2-year-old daughter to keep them quiet for her husband.

Christina Booth, who is believed to be suffering from postpartum depression, made a 911 call Saturday sobbing and screaming at the operator that her children would not stop crying.

When police arrived they found the twins on the couch crying "uncontrollably" and "bleeding from their necks." The 2-year-old was upstairs with a similar wound. All three survived their injuries.

Booth allegedly told police "she knew if she killed all the kids the house would be quiet" for her husband "who gets annoyed when the children cry."

Just-release surveillance video shows an arsonist run up to a Yorba Linda home, ignite a container of flammable liquid and throw it into the house. 

A young woman and the family dog who were inside were injured, and the blaze destroyed the home, causing $1 million in damage. 

Now fire investigators are asking for help finding the unidentified man, who sped away on a children's BMX bike. He may have burn injuries.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1yOlp1o

Her hands were cuffed behind her back, but authorities say that didn't stop Roxanne Rimer from stealing a police car and leading them on a high-speed chase that was caught on dramatic dashcam video. 

At one point, she could be heard asking for help driving the car during the pursuit, which reached speeds of 100 mph on Pennsylvania roads. She even managed to honk the vehicle's horn a few times. 

Rimer eventually ditched the police car, as dashcam showed her walking away from it with her hands still cinched in cuffs behind her back. She was arrested a short time later. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1BxAGDK

Mr. Incredible was convicted of battery Tuesday in a videotaped assault on Batgirl during a costumed character brawl on Hollywood Boulevard.

Muhammet Bilik, who was dressed at Mr. Incredible, was accused of punching, kicking and body-slamming the woman dressed as Batgirl as Chewbacca and Freddy Krueger characters tried to break up the fight.

A man dressed as Spider-Man told KTLA that the Oct. 21st fight began after Mr. Incredible complained that Batgirl was standing too close to him.

Would you drink or use this black, sludgy water? 

One Gardena resident who complained about the dark, smelly liquid coming from her home's taps and toilets was told by Golden State Water Company that testing indicated it was safe even for drinking. 

But Diane Morita isn't buying it. She expressed concern over the water's impact on her family's health. "We have one dog with cancer," she said. "One of my daughters has skin issues." 

Other area residents say they have also complained of a similar issue the past few months, but to no avail. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1z6c1oI

Surveillance video captured the frightening moment when a man working in a manhole in Oregon was run over by a truck driver.

Travis Roberts survived the accident with only a broken rib. 

"Just amazed, I'm sitting here alive and not worse off, not paralyzed," Roberts said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1yoGiLO

The staff at an Arizona hospital initially thought Richie Lopez's face was just swollen at birth. But they soon realized his eyelids weren't open because he did not have eyes.

"By the time we left, all the nurses had cried with us," said Richie's mother, Kelly Lopez.

Now she and her husband are facing the unique challenge with optimism and love. They hope Richie â€” who does have an optic nerve â€” will be able to see one day with the help of scientific advancements.

In the meantime, he uses special toys and is enrolled in developmental programs.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1zLrb5D

An Oklahoma police officer fatally shot a man who took off running after being patted down, and the entire incident was captured by a body-cam.

In the graphic video, released by the Muskogee Police Department, a man identified as 21-year-old Terence Walker is seen stopping suddenly. He bends to down to pick up something he dropped on the road.

Officer Chansey McMillin then draws his pistol, takes aim and fires five shots. Walker was hit three times, police said. He died at the scene.

In the video, McMillin is heard saying the suspect dropped a handgun; another officer says the weapon is loaded.

Later, an emotional McMillin leans against a police car.

"Why did (Walker) have to do that?" he asks as other officers comfort him. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1yXyiVL

Newly released video shows a woman being forced into the trunk of her car by a brazen robber who pointed a gun in her face as she was stopped at an ATM in Texas. 

Authorities released the video in hopes of catching the gunman, who allegedly drove the victim to other banks and demanded she take more money from her account. 

The woman was finally able to escape when the man stopped the car and walked away.

Cellphone video appears to show a police officer trying to tip a paralyzed man out of a wheelchair during an incident in San Francisco.

Bo Frierson says he wanted to help some friends who were being questioned by police after an argument.

"You don't run my foot over," one of the officers says to him in the video. Frierson, who denies running over the officer's foot, was cited for obstruction.

The Police Department's Internal Affairs Division is conducting an investigation.

An 11-year-old girl who helped save her grandmother's life after finding her unconscious described the frightening moments when a paramedic talked her through CPR over the phone.

A sheriff's deputy is under investigation after cell phone video showed her getting into a patrol car that was parked in a disabled parking space at a Circle K store in Sacramento.

A Michigan man who killed a newborn puppy that he used as a weapon to assault his girlfriend with was sentenced Tuesday to six months in jail. 

Timothy Tucker, 51, was given credit for 68 days of time already served, meaning he'll spend roughly four more months behind bars. 

In exchange for the guilty plea to felony assault, prosecutors dropped the charge for killing and torturing the 2-week-old dog, according to reports. 

"This is one of the few cases that turns my stomach," Kalamazoo County Assistant Prosecutor Mike Reisterer said. "To take a two-week-old puppy and bludgeon his significant other to the point that she requires hospitalization and the puppy is deadâ€¦is incomprehensible."

Everyone's favorite nonagenarian, Betty White, got the surprise of a lifetime for her 93rd birthday â€” a hula-dancing flash mob.

The unsuspecting actress thought it was just another day on the job at her "Hot in Cleveland" TV set in Studio City Friday when dozens of crew members suddenly appeared in bright attire and a choreographed dance.

When Make-A-Wish America granted 3-year-old Juniper's wish to visit Disneyland, the foundation enlisted her friend and fellow cancer survivor to deliver the news.

The result was a heartwarming video in which Violet, dressed as Cinderella, urges her pal to "twirl like a princess, do your princess pose" and get "nose kisses" from Mickey Mouse.

"Juni, I love you," she says. "Have so much fun."

Juniper's wish was granted in October. The video was released this week.

The two girls had been diagnosed with retinoblastoma, a rare form of cancer that begins in the eye. They are both now in remission.

Many couples may dream of having a famous band perform at their wedding, but for several ones in Los Angeles, that was the reality recently when Maroon 5 dropped by for a surprise performance.

A group of pranksters in an SUV made an apparently startling admission to LAPD officers who were questioning them at Venice Beach:

"I can't do this. We have a bunch of Coke in the back," blurted out one of the jokesters. "I'm sorry."

The officers handcuffed the foursome while searching the trunk of the vehicle, which resulted in the discovery of â€¦ several cans of Coca-Cola.

The incident, which was uploaded to YouTube, ended with the NelkFilmz pranksters shaking hands with the officers before being sent on their way.

"Remember that it is against the law to make a false report," the Los Angeles Police Department's Rampart Division later said on Twitter. "The time taken to respond to this takes away from calls where there's an actual need for police resources."

What do you think of the stunt?

Police say she punched a woman who was walking to work, then stole her purse and was later spotted on surveillance cameras using her credit cards.

The victim was just one of multiple employees at the Hustler Casino in Gardena who has been mugged. In the past year alone, five people have been victimized, three of them being employees.

Premiering 7 p.m. Tuesday, Wrestling With Death l WGN America introduces you to the Lathams, an Arkansas family who are morticians by day and professional wrestlers by night. Don't miss it.

For just $10 you can get your name, or just about any word, tattooed on this 22-year-old woman's body. 

Illma Gore, a Los Angeles-based artist, has created a KickStarter for her latest art installation - an offer to tattoo peoples' names, ideas and designs on her entire body. 

"It's art. It will annoy people or make them happy or make them smile. Either way, that's what art's supposed to do," Illma told KTLA.

This cellphone video showing a baby girl playing with an apparently real handgun and putting its muzzle in her mouth led to the arrest of an Indiana couple, police say.

A former Rialto school accountant embezzled $1.8 million in lunch money by stuffing the cash into her bra. The thefts dated back to 2005; now she's been sentenced to five years in prison.

Judith Oakes, who worked in the school district's nutrition services department, was taken into custody in August after surveillance video showed her taking bundles of cash.

Oakes earned about $77,000 a year, but lived a luxury lifestyle, authorities said. She had two homes, off-road vehicles and took expensive trips.

She has been ordered to pay $1.845 million in restitution.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1x0pfPA

Surveillance video released by the LAPD shows a woman being violently attacked and robbed in the lobby of an apartment building in the Koreatown area.

The incident was one of four that occurred between Nov. 9 and Dec. 30, the Los Angeles Police Department said. All of the episodes had similar details: a Hispanic male followed a lone Korean woman into an elevator, assaulted her and robbed her.

The attacker is described as 20- to 30-year-old, between 5 feet 6 inches and 5 feet 8 inches tall, and weighing between 130 and 170 pounds.

"Share" this to alert others.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1BFLZbI

A Kentucky police officer accidentally shot himself while standing next to his wife in a Cincinnati elevator, and the entire incident was captured by surveillance video.

Officer Darryl Jouett removed his gun from its holster and was apparently trying to put it in his pocket when it went off.

A bullet ricocheted off the elevator door and hit him in the stomach.

Jouett on Monday told WCPO - 9 On Your Side he was at home and on the mend.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1IiulwZ

For more than three hours, a 39-year-old taxi driver who had been stabbed multiple times during an argument in Brazil did not realize he had a knife lodged in his head.

Doctors say they believe shock and "a bit of drinking" are the reasons he was not aware of the protruding knife.  

Miraculously, Juacelo Nunes de Oliveira survived. And despite being stabbed four times â€“ including three in the torso â€“ he left the hospital healthy and OK on Sunday, five days after the incident.  

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KeBmTr
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
BREAKING: A body found in a dumpster in San Diego County has been identified as 3-week-old Eliza Delacruz, who had been missing since a shooting that left her parents and uncle injured, the Long Beach Police Department confirmed.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KbRNQm
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
A security guard used a machete to detain a man who allegedly tried to rob an adult store in Anaheim.

The man entered the Couples Mega Outlet and got into a physical altercation, during which he struck the guard with a glass water pipe, Anaheim police said.

The guard then grabbed the machete, hit the man on the head with it and held him until officers arrived, authorities said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1vJaKzj

BREAKING: ESPN SportsCenter anchor Stuart Scott has died after a yearslong battle with cancer. He was 49.

After the news was announced, ESPN tweeted this quote from Scott: 

"When you die, it does not mean you lose to cancer. You beat cancer by how you live, why you live, and in the manner in which you live."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1rTguuR
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Update: A missing 3-week-old girl was found dead in San Diego County after being abducted from the Long Beach home where her parents and uncle were shot and wounded, police said.

Detectives believe Eliza Delacruz was taken by a man suspected in the shooting.

Her body was discovered in a dumpster in the coastal city of Imperial Beach, authorities said.

No one was in custody in connection with the incident.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1KbRNQm
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Update: A 4.2 earthquake struck near Castaic, following a 3.0 temblor that occurred 20 minutes earlier in the same area, according to the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS).

Did you feel it?

There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.

The Los Angeles Fire Department said it was monitoring the situation but was not in "earthquake mode."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1vKjncF
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
After her fiancÃ© called off the wedding just days before the ceremony, one Tennessee woman decided to turn her sorrow into a colorful photo shoot celebrating the next chapter in her life. 

"It doesn't matter what happens in life as long as you stay true to yourself and don't dwell on the negative," Shelby Swink told CNN after pictures of her trashing her gown swarmed the Internet. 

The owner of a Memphis bridal shop has since put the dress on display in hopes of inspiring other brides-to-be to not forget to love themselves.  

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1BuCZGi

Karma may have been at work when an intoxicated man who allegedly stole a bicycle in Huntington Beach crashed into a concrete trash can within minutes, and lost his front teeth. 

Witnesses say the man was attempting to sell the stolen bike for $10 in order to buy more alcohol.

But before he could find any buyers, the man crashed and found himself lying in a pool of blood. He now faces costly dental work and theft charges. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1vFDLf7

Cellphone video captured the moment that a scuffle between two men on board a crowded Metro Blue Line Train spilled out onto the station landing where the confrontation ended in deadly gunfire.

Stunned witness at the Artesia Station in Compton looked on as the victim, already shot once, tried to chase down the gunman who then turned and fired several more times.

The victim was pronounced dead at the hospital.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1D0vH1e

Just minutes after posting his plan on Facebook, a husband fatally shot his wife and then himself at a New Hampshire hospital room.

Family members say Mark Lavoie acted out of "out of love" for his wife Kathy.

In his Facebook post, Lavoie wrote that his "baby was trying to escape the bi-polar demons that have been swirling around in her brain since childhood."

He blamed himself for her current hospitalization saying, "because of my selfishness in dialing 911 she is experiencing the only thing she feared more than her illness â€¦ life support on a respirator."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1K8e1mi
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Before being arrested on New Year's Day, sexual assault suspect William Mattson was badly beaten by the victim's boyfriend, who is his own nephew. 

The nephew discovered his 52-year-old uncle on top of his girlfriend and began repeatedly hitting him, driving Mattson away from the family's South Carolina home, a local paper reported. 

Mattson has been charged with first-degree criminal sexual conduct. His injuries from the beating included a swollen left eye and bleeding on his face and lips. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1BrD3q9
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
A young mother is under arrest in connection with the death of her 2-month old baby, who police say died of acute methamphetamine poisoning.

The infant passed away in June at a Northern California hospital after experiencing symptoms including choking and difficulty breathing.

The child's mother, 21-year-old Shelby Frederick, was arrested on  Dec. 30. 

She is currently five months pregnant.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1xagR51
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Christian Gomez is charged with first degree murder after allegedly confessing to beheading his mother with an ax on New Year's Eve for "nagging" him.

Gomez reportedly told deputies that he was angry at his mother for "nagging him" for two days about moving some boxes into the attic.

The decapitated body of 48-year-old Maria Suarez Cassagne was found dumped next to garbage cans outside the family home.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1vyiOmg
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Get ready for beautiful floats and amazing music. The 126th Tournament of Roses Parade is underway. 

Watch live on KTLA here: http://ktlane.ws/1EG0K41

A freak wind event outside the Rose Bowl sent pop-up tents and debris circling violently into the air Wednesday, a day before the big game.

Witnesses captured the whole thing on cellphone video. The high winds struck the fanfest area outside the Pasadena stadium.

It looked like a "dust devil," a National Weather Service official said.

Click here to read KTLA's story: http://ktlane.ws/1754BJe

Good Samaritans were out in force Wednesday morning after an overnight snow storm blanketed Wildomar.

The snow left dozens of drivers trapped, but they were able to get back on the road thanks to the help of complete strangers. 

One of those helpers, named Greg, had been busy since 4 a.m. using his own Jeep and gas to pull cars and trucks out. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1vFOzuL

He's only four days old, but this adorable baby gorilla is already making a big splash at the San Diego Zoo. 

The unnamed infant weighed just a few pounds when he was born at the zoo the day after Christmas. 

Video released by the zoo Tuesday shows his mother doting on him as throngs of people gather outside to take a closer look at the popular park's newest attraction. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1BhkXrc

As flames roared around them, a group of people urged a scared child who was trapped in a burning building to jump. 

"Jump. Come on, your mama's right here. Your mama said do it," the man who captured the dramatic moments on video is heard saying. 

Seconds later, the video shows a man catching the little boy. Six people were hospitalized in the blaze that burned through the Alabama apartment building on Christmas morning, but no one was killed. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1zOdLp6

Do you recognize these people?

A Mar Vista homeowner says they entered his house in a break-in that was captured on surveillance video by a Dropcam.

The LAPD confirmed that a burglary at the residence was reported and a search for the intruders is underway.

No one was home at the time of the incident.

"Share" this to alert others.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1D4d21N

Several people who were attending a funeral in South L.A. chased down a man who allegedly stole a hearse containing the body of their deceased loved one.

Witnesses said the the vehicle was idling when the man jumped in and drove off. After a confrontation with the mourners, the man was taken into custody by police. The hearse and body were then returned to the Ebenezer Baptist Church.

The pastor's wife told the L.A. Times she could not recall a similar incident in the church's 75-year history. "This is truly one for the books," she said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/13BCQFK

In a heartwarming video that's captured the attention of millions, a son gives his parents a gift they'll never forget.

Joseph Riquelme is seen handing his parents an envelope that simply states, "Your house is paid off. Merry Xmas."

Upon reading the words, both parents began to cry, appearing both happy and taken aback. 

"Sometimes the best gifts come in the lamest packages. Merry Christmas everyone!" Joseph later stated on his Facebook page.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1AXGCXl

Thousands gathered Saturday to honor one of the NYPD officers who was ambushed and killed last week. 

During Officer Rafael Ramos' funeral, he was posthumously promoted to detectives first grade and made an honorary NYPD chaplain. 

Rafael's son Justin spoke at a wake held Friday:

"He was my rock, he was a beacon of wisdom, he was my absolute best friend. Dad, I'll miss you with every fiber of my being," he said, fighting back tears.

Watch KTLA's videos here: http://ktlane.ws/1CNxzKJ

An early morning palm tree fire on Christmas Day created a visually stunning but dangerous scene in Mid-City, as embers fueled by high winds rained down on the area. 

A camera was rolling while the red embers flew through the air near Venice Boulevard and South Mansfield Avenue around 3 a.m. after the palm tree burst into flames. 

It took fire crews roughly 20 minutes to extinguish the blaze, according to the cameraman who shot the footage. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1rksGEA

From all of us at KTLA, have a Merry Christmas and happy holidays.

...and to all our viewers out there who got new phones and tablets under the tree this year, be sure to download our mobile app so you can watch KTLA on the go, get breaking news alerts and stay in touch with KTLA all day long: www.ktla.com/mobile/
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
One of KTLA's favorite Christmas traditions has returned. It's time to sit back, relax and fire up the KTLA Yule log.

We're airing the festive crackling log, along with live Christmas music from KOST 103.5, from now until 11 a.m. on Channel 5.

For our Facebook users, here's a digital version to brighten up your holiday. Or watch here: http://ktlane.ws/1vrXxLX

A chaotic scene turned dangerous when what appeared to be a firework exploded near a gas pump where police and protesters were clashing in Missouri.

Video of the explosion showed people scattering and screaming as thick, white smoke rose into the air.

The clashes were sparked by the fatal police shooting of an allegedly armed black teen just 2 miles from Ferguson, Missouri, where the controversial shooting of Michael Brown led to nationwide protests.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/16PZTyX

Two little girls in Kansas who hadn't seen their deployed military father in six months were treated to a wonderful Christmas surprise when they opened a large gift-wrapped box and found him inside. 

Sgt. Stephen Thompson is stationed in Afghanistan. He slept in airports for three straight days just to visit his family for the holiday, but the reaction of his daughters upon seeing him for the first time surely made the long journey worth it. 

The faces of 2-year-old Stella and 6-year-old Sophia radiated with joy and happiness as they ran into his open arms. In turn, he showered them with hugs and kisses. 

"Merry Christmas," Thompson told them. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1A4KfKP

A SoCal YouTube prankster says he set out to show what homeless people do with donated cash when he gave a panhandler $100 then secretly followed the man with a camera.

What Josh Paler Lin (DJ Paler) says he captured on a now-viral video was a surprise lesson in generosity.

Instead of keeping the cash, the man identified only as Thomas used the money to buy food he gave to others. 

"It completely changed my mindset and, I believe, touched a lot of people's hearts and changed the way they think about people," said Lin, who has now raised tens of thousands of dollars for Thomas.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Ear1aA

A terrifying road-rage encounter between two women and the driver of a truck who allegedly identified herself as a sheriff's deputy was captured on video in Northern California. 

"She's knocking on our window saying she's a cop," one of the panic-stricken women sitting in their car told authorities after calling 911.

The truck's driver, identified as Deirdre Orozco, then allegedly forced the women's car off the road when they tried to drive away. Orozco, who had been released from jail that morning on a hit-and-run charge, was later arrested.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1CvFoV2

A gesture of kindness by a perfect stranger is making a major difference this Christmas for a struggling Florida family that fell on tough times after their infant was born with heart issues. 

The anonymous person recently paid off the balance of Michelle 
Edgar's layaway bill at Wal-Mart, ensuring that her two kids -- 3-year-old Jaycee and 4-month-old Jimmy -- will have something small to open on the holiday. 

Edgar says the family wouldn't have had money to pay for presents otherwise. 

"It's an amazing feeling to know that somebody did that for us, and I want the opportunity someday to do it for somebody else," she said. 

Watch KTLA's full video here: http://ktlane.ws/1zbHNxP

A Wisconsin woman got the surprise of a lifetime when her son, a sailor in the U.S. Navy, unexpectedly came home for Christmas after being deployed for almost two years in the Persian Gulf.

Petty Officer Second Class Bruce Rathsack's mother thought he was en route from Guam to Hawaii when instead he walked into the restaurant where she was having dinner.

She buried her face in her hands, overcome with emotion.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1wd4UWQ

After 17 years of using a wheelchair, one Orange County student found the motivation he needed to walk on his own - a Tinker Bell DVD. 

Students at Tesoro High School earn fake cash and items when they accomplish their goals. When Octavio Nieto spotted his ideal purchase, a school aide told him it would take weeks to earn it.

That's when he got to work -- and in two weeks found the strength to take his first solo steps.

"When he got his 100 'Tesoro dollars' he waved them in her face and said, 'Nothing is impossible with God," another school official said. 

Octavio's next goal is to walk across the stage at his high school graduation next year.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1HbdjQQ

Dueling protesters took to the streets of New York City in the aftermath of an ambush-style shooting that left two NYPD officers dead.

Some demonstrators expressed their support for the police department by carrying signs that read "WE SUPPORT NYPD" and "BLUE LIVES MATTER."

Metal barriers separated the group from opposing activists who held signs that said "Jail Killer Cops" and "BLACK LIVES MATTER."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1zhQlZa

Two little girls thought they were visiting Santa Claus when they got the surprise of a lifetime: Santa was actually their military father who had just returned home from a 10-month deployment.

"Dear Santa, I can't wait till Christmas because it's my favorite holiday and sometimes you make our wish come true," the undercover father recalled one of his daughters saying before he revealed his identity. "My No. 1 wish is for my dad to come home from Germany."

And with that, the hat and beard were off and the Texas family was reunited just in time for Christmas.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1GEP1Ax

A 2-year-old Huntington Beach boy who was born deaf got to hear his mother's voice for the first time earlier this month, thanks to a newly activated cochlear implant. 

Video of Ryan Aprea giggling happily as his mother speaks has earned more than 240,000 views on YouTube in a week.

Ryan's mom said he's become a "little celebrity" thanks to a smile that "lit up the screen."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1sFYyVb

A 52-second video captured a violent confrontation between an alleged panhandler and two Hawthorne police officers on Monday.

The man, identified as Thomas Christopher Brown, repeatedly pushed the officers, punched at least one of them in the face and knocked one to the ground.

In the background, the person taking the video repeatedly yelled out "F*** the police."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/13iwkUD

Caught on Video: A Bay Area cyclist out for a ride near the Golden Gate Bridge experienced a heart-stopping moment when a deer jumped out in front of his bike.

The cyclist, who was headed toward Sausalito when the deer knocked him off his bike, sustained a mild concussion and some memory loss but was otherwise OK.

"I cannot speak to the deer's injuries," he wrote.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1wHY94h

As authorities identified three people killed by an alleged DUI driver who plowed through crowd of pedestrians on PCH in Redondo Beach, a witness got emotional describing the scene.

"People started flying," said Michael Tovar, who jumped out of his truck to help. "I looked down to the car right in front of me and underneath the left front tire was a little boy. â€¦ He was just laying there, underneath the tire."

After people helped get the car off the child, Tovar said he turned to the driver and screamed at her, "What did you do?"

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1C2xp1s

A Glendora photographer laughed out loud when one of his hidden trail cameras captured a huge black bear's interaction with a stuffed Santa toy this week.

Santa was placed on the trail just for fun to see how local wildlife would interact with the toy, the photographer said.

Apparently, this bear didn't take too kindly to the holiday decoration.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1BZXWg1

A 59-year-old amputee who used a wheelchair was brutally beaten before being stabbed to death in Riverside, and police hope this newly released security video can help catch his killers. 

Edward Dickerson, who was known by the nickname "St. Louis," died the morning of Aug. 3 outside a barber shop. He had been beaten "senseless" for at least 20 minutes, police said Tuesday. 

The two assailants were described as white or Hispanic and between the ages of 25 and 30. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1uT1qs9

Will body cameras on LAPD officers lead to an increase in transparency?

That question may be answered soon, when 7,000 members of the department are equipped with the hardware.

Police officials demonstrated the new equipment at a news conference attended by Chief Charlie Beck and Mayor Eric Garcetti.

The mayor noted that his administration had begun implementing a body-camera program "long before" the shooting death of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, and before President Obama requested federal funding to equip officers nationwide with the technology.

Read KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1BSi7tk

This video showing a police officer using a Taser twice on a 76-year-old man in Victoria, Texas has prompted outrage. 

Officer Nathanial Robinson was in the process of arresting Pete Vasquez last Thursday when he threw the elderly man onto the hood of the police car, tackled him and proceeded to use his Taser, dash cam video showed. 

Vasquez told a local television station it appeared the officer "enjoyed" using it. He added Robinson used the Taser again because he couldn't get up from the ground fast enough. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1xoXgzb

The person seen in this video, recorded near a massive fire that gutted a seven-story development site in downtown L.A., is one of two possible witnesses being sought by authorities.

"Investigators have identified them as being in the area of the fire, and merely wish to interview them," the Los Angeles Fire Department and ATF said.

The agencies released videos of both individuals, neither of whom have been described as suspects in the Dec. 8 blaze.

"Share" this to alert others.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1GJhqn3

Do you recognize this man? 

Surveillance video captured a brazen thief stealing nearly $1,000 from a family-owned San Fernando Valley tailor shop, and police are hoping the public can help identify him. 

"Share" this post to alert others. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1zTEpM2

This time-lapse video shows the sea of people who marched in New York City to protest police violence against black men and boys. 

The demonstration was one of several that were held across the nation in response to the deaths Eric Garner, Michael Brown, Tamir Rice and others.

The footage was shot from a high-rise window overlooking Sixth Avenue and West 29th Street.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1sqHBIJ

During a frantic rush to see her ill son, who was believed to be dying, an 87-year-old woman was pulled over for a traffic violation and backed into the patrol car. 

But rather than issue a ticket, the trooper organized a team of three coworkers to help the woman complete her journey - about a 3.5-hour drive.  

"We as law enforcement officers out there and troopers ... we're humans first, you know? We understand that people need help in different situations, and we are willing to help out," a Utah Highway Patrol sergeant said.

Officials commended the trooper's actions and said he was not acting under any orders when he initiated the carpool. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1yOpgro

The man who captured this incredible footage of a tornado in South Los Angeles says he was initially shocked by the chaos caused by the 60-to-85 mph winds.

"What is going on? That's what was through my mind," said Jaime Mena, whose cellphone video has since gone viral.

Although the event was a relatively weak "EF0 tornado," it was strong enough to lift the roof off of an apartment building and blow out windows at a day care center.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1w2UNJ6

Scary moments in West Hills, as this massive 500-year-old oak tree came crashing down onto homes hours after a powerful storm blew through the area Friday.  

Firefighters were already at the scene when it happened and no one was injured. 

The fall was expected, as neighbors say branches from the tree have come down in the past with damaging results. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1ws87oP

Caught on video: A rare tornado ripped through South Los Angeles on Friday, causing damage over nearly 20 blocks.

Roofs were torn off an apartment complex and two homes, according to the National Weather Service, which verified the tornado was a category EF0.

"We looked outside and everything was flying down the sidewalk," one resident said. "It was really wild."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1Gvn4ZX

Ventura County firefighters rescued an elderly Camarillo Springs couple after mud suddenly began pouring through their home amid the storm early Friday. The mudflow push a dresser onto the couple's bed, trapping them underneath.

"It just came pouring in," homeowner Jim Shiraishi said.

Firefighters found waist-deep mud in the couple's bedroom. They were able to carry Jim, his blind wife and their caretaker to safety.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1wHXeCP

BREAKING: A rescuer was swept away in the raging waters of the Los Angeles River Friday. 

Video showed others trying to get the rescuer out of the rushing water as the person was moving past them. 

Another rescuer was eventually able to get a rope out and pull the person to safety.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/13IZK8H

Army Reserve Sgt. 1st Class Robert Vandenberg surprised his wife Patricia with an unexpected homecoming that was caught on camera at the Anaheim Ducks game on Wednesday night.

He first faked a failing Skype connection and then walked up behind Patricia and bent down for a kiss.

It was Vandenberg's first time meeting his newborn son Travis after being deployed in Afghanistan for nearly a year.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1whfAsc

A dramatic standoff between a Montebello father wanted in connection with an Amber Alert and CHP officers ended in heart-stopping fashion Thursday morning.

It appeared at one point that Daniel Perez may have considered jumping from the San Diego-area overpass in front of his four children, who were reported missing Tuesday.

The standoff ended with Perez in custody and the boys all safely released to police.

Read KTLA's story here: ktlane.ws/1wCOlub

A YouTube video shows an LAPD officer swinging his baton at demonstrators during a recent protest in South L.A., and now the department's internal affairs unit has launched an investigation.

In the footage, a woman is heard screaming as the officer swings the baton twice at chest level before a police supervisor touches his shoulder and moves him away. No one is struck.

Another woman, who said she took the video, told the Police Commission that the baton "came within 2 feet of my head."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1GblTAH

Jessica Chambers died in a homicide that a longtime Mississippi prosecutor called "certainly one of the worst I've ever dealt with."

The 19-year-old woman was set on fire while she was in her car. Burned over 98 percent of her body, she tried to tell first responders who committed the horrific crime, her father said.

Doctors told Ben Chambers that Jessica's killer or killers had "squirted fluid down her throat and up her nose, because it just burned her on the inside so bad," he said.

No one is in custody in the case. An investigation is ongoing.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1qpRjPQ

Four Utah state troopers went the extra mile to help an 87-year-old woman see her gravely ill son, perhaps for the last time.

Helen "Skeeter" Smith, who lives in southern Nevada, was on the 15 Freeway and rushing to the hospital in Ogden, Utah, when she was pulled over by Trooper Jeff Jones.

That touched off a sequence of events that led to Smith being escorted to the hospital by Jones and three of his colleagues, who drove her through five counties.

She was able to see her son, Randy, whose treatment is ongoing.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1z1eFMb

Drivers who somehow entered the southbound 110 Freeway in downtown L.A. early Monday faced a hellish scene: a massive apartment complex under construction in towering flames over the roadway.

The fire was so powerful it blew out the windows on surrounding buildings, and firefighters were showered with glass as they worked in intense, reflected heat to knock the flames down.

Arson investigators are working the case.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1G6CpSi

A Georgia mother is outraged after her 6-year-old son was handcuffed at his elementary school after allegedly banging his head on a table and leaving the school, running into a busy street. 

"He just ran away from school. It does not require handcuffs for this," Lakaisha Reid said of her son. 

The boy has special needs, and Lakaisha says school officials should have been better trained in dealing with children like her son. 

"That's pretty young for handcuffs already, you understand? Anything can happen with those handcuffs on him," she said. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1A74Z25

When two Florida police officers learned that a young girl was sad because the family couldn't afford a Christmas tree this year, they knew immediately they had to help.  

So in the spirit of the holiday season, the officers bought a tree and decorations with their own money, returned to the family's apartment and played Santa for the unsuspecting girl. 

The girl's priceless response to her brand new tree was captured in a video that has since gone viral after being posted to Facebook. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1A7tEDG

Protests in Riverside turned violent Saturday night - but it wasn't the demonstrators committing the crime. 

A hit-and-run driver struck two women, causing one to fly onto the roof of the car. 

Police are still searching for the driver, who was possibly driving a BMW. It's believed the individual drove through the crowd because they were blocking the roadway. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1A4NlvG

Do you recognize the man seen on this surveillance video? 

Police are looking for him in connection with the recent theft of a UPS package from the front porch of a home in Venice. 

The resident posted the video to YouTube with the hope that someone out there will be able to identify and help catch the thief. 

"Share" this post to alert others. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1s79dT6

This week, the KTLA 5 Morning News team had a visit from Jiff, the YouTube superstar Pomeranian.

The L.A.-area pooch, who just launched a collar collection, holds the Guinness World Record title as the fastest dog on two paws â€” front and back.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1yroGU3

Update: A 21-year-old transgender woman was gunned down while pounding on the front door of a South L.A. home seeking help, and police hope surveillance footage capturing the incident will help them find her killer. 

Police believe Deshawnda Sanchez, known as "Tata," was running from a robber when she was shot and killed early Wednesday morning. "At this point we cannot say it's a hate crime but we have not ruled out that as being a possibility," an LAPD officer said.

"Share" this post to alert others. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1232NNQ

Update: Police say 5-month-old Trevor Barajas has been located in good condition. His mother was in custody.

The baby boy was last seen with his 15-year-old mother when she left a group home in Westlake on Dec. 1.  

When she returned on Thursday, Trevor was not with her.

An Iowa man was arrested after allegedly assaulting his pregnant wife with a McDonald's McChicken sandwich.

Marvin Tramaine Hill admitted to police that he threw the sandwich at his wife "because he doesn't like them."  

According to police, the 21-year-old then took the sandwich bun and smashed it into her face.

Hill was arrested on suspicion of domestic assault. On the police report, under "tool or weapon used," police wrote "Mc Chicken."

Police are asking for the public's help in identifying the hit-and-run driver who left a 10-year-old boy lying in the street critically injured.

It happened around 5:30 p.m. Tuesday in a marked crosswalk at the intersection of North Main and Sichel streets in Lincoln Heights.

The little boy was thrown 40 feet by the force of the impact. He suffered head trauma, a pelvic fracture and internal bleeding. His friend was not injured. 

The driver sped away in dark-colored vehicle.

When she was a 17-year-old hotel worker in 1986, Chelan said she was given a "blue pill" and several shots of liquor by comedian Bill Cosby. Then, she said, he sexually assaulted her while she was incapacitated.

A mother carrying her 2-month-old son was stared down and then kicked to the ground by a man who apparently wanted to steal her cellphone. 

The woman, who did not want to be identified, said she fell on top of her infant son, but that he was "good."

Police in New York City released the surveillance video in hopes of catching the attacker.

A senior Republican staffer has resigned after her comments that Sasha and Malia Obama should "try showing a little class" caused a firestorm of criticism on social media.

Elizabeth Lauten faced heavy backlash when she wrote a Thanksgiving-Day screed against the teenagers that quickly went viral.

In a Facebook post, she scolded the Obama daughters for what she said was their inappropriate outfits and their bored looks during last week's turkey pardoning ceremony.

"Dear Sasha and Malia: I get you're both in those awful teen years, but you're a part of the First Family, try showing a little class. At least respect the part you play," Lauten wrote.

"Then again, your mother and father don't respect their positions very much, or the nation for that matter," she added. "So I'm guessing you're coming up a little short in the 'good role model' department."

The comments drew rebukes from, among others, the Republican National Committee communications director via Twitter.

"Children, especially the first daughters, are off limits," he tweeted.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1A8BT2X

An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 2.7 struck 15 miles south southeast of Oxnard.

The quake occurred at 8:05 p.m. at a depth of 5.7 miles, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

Actor John Boyega has four words for anyone who's upset he's playing what appears to be a black Stormtrooper in the newest Star Wars movie: "Get used to it."

The 22-year-old British actor posted the message on Instagram after his appearance in the new trailer for "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" prompted heated discussion on social media. On YouTube, some questioned whether a black Stormtrooper made sense, while others reacted with racist remarks.

Supporters responded on Twitter with the hashtag #BlackStormtrooper.

Amid angry and sometimes violent protests over this week's Ferguson grand jury decision, one 12-year-old boy held a sign offering "Free Hugs" as tears ran down his face during demonstrations in Portland, Oregon Tuesday. 

When a police officer asked Devonte Hart why he was crying, he said it was over the level police brutality toward young black kids. 

The officer, Sgt. Bret Bertnum, sighed and replied, "Yes. I know. I'm sorry. I'm sorry."

The two were then captured embracing in a powerful photograph being called "the hug shared around the world" by a local newspaper.

The best Black Friday deal of 2014 is arguably at the gas station: The average price in America for a gallon of regular fell to $2.79 â€” and may be headed to as low as $2.50.

The $2.79 price point is 50 cents lower than it was this time last year.

That kind of savings adds up quickly and it's why economists and CEOs of retailers like Target and Walmart predict that consumers will be willing to spend more this holiday season.

Will you be taking advantage of the price dip?

The Black Friday frenzy is here, and so too is the chaotic scene of shoppers pushing and shoving as they try to score deep discounts and great deals at malls across America. 

This video of a crowd rushing into a Wal-Mart owned store was actually shot in London, where retailers also offered Black Friday deals. 

Back in the U.S., several brawls were reported at stores on Friday, including a fight that reportedly broke out in L.A. over a discounted Barbie doll.

Matthew Heisler died tragically in a house fire at the age of 21, but by donating his organs, he helped save the lives of others, including a Vietnam Veteran and grandfather of four who needed a new heart to live. 

Recently, Tom Meeks connected with Heisler's parents and younger sister for the first time in an emotional meeting where they got to hear their loved one's heart beating inside another man's chest. 

"The heart that I grew up with and, like, felt in all of my hugs when I hugged him -- it's still out there somewhere," said Casey Heisler, who started crying when it was her turn to listen.

A 12-year-old boy carrying an airgun was shot 2 seconds after a Cleveland police officer and a partner pulled up alongside the boy, based on surveillance video released by police Wednesday.

The officers were responding to a 911 call that someone was brandishing a gun at a park.

Tamir Rice died Sunday, one day after he was shot outside a recreation center.

Graphic video shows a driver plowing through a crowd of protesters in Minnesota and then dragging a woman â€” who appeared to be stuck beneath the vehicle's front left tire â€” several feet. 

The group was protesting the recent Ferguson grand jury decision not to charge officer Darren Wilson in the fatal shooting of unarmed teenager Michael Brown. 

The victim suffered minor injuries to her legs, but was expected to be OK.

Police in riot gear used pepper spray to disperse crowds as the vehicle burned. 

Earlier in the day, volunteers helped clean up vandalized stores and boarded up windows broken when violence erupted Monday night following the grand jury's decision not to charge police Officer Darren Wilson in the shooting death of unarmed teen Michael Brown.

Officers shoved some protesters who gathered outside LAPD headquarters after a Ferguson grand jury decided not to indict Darren Wilson, the police officer who fatally shot 18-year-old Michael Brown.

After displaying KTLA's call letters for more than 60 years, the iconic radio tower on the Sunset Bronson Studios lot in Hollywood is being dismantled Monday. 

Time lapse video shows a crane removing the top three sections of the tower, which has stood on the northeast corner of the lot since 1950. 

The tower is expected to be restored and then rebuilt in its original location, on the lot's northwest corner, in early 2015.

A hit-and-run driver may have killed a desert bighorn sheep who somehow escaped from the L.A. Zoo after  jumping over an 8-foot fence topped with barbed wire Saturday. 

The sheep was able to evade the zoo staff for hours before dying on a Los Feliz street. 

Witnesses told the Los Angeles Times that the animal had been struck by a driver who fled the scene, but officials could not confirm how it died.

An elementary school math assembly quickly transformed into an emotional and long-awaited reunion between a fourth-grader in South Carolina and her father, a returning soldier.

Staff Sergeant Joel Spector, who just wrapped up a nine-month tour of duty in Afghanistan, dressed up as the Piggly Wiggly Pig to surprise his daughter.

When he took off the mascot's head, the entire group of children erupted in cheers while his tearful daughter melted into his arms.

Two children, ages 2 and 6, died in a fire that broke out at their San Bernardino home while their mother was in labor at a local hospital.

She's been visiting notorious convicted killer Charles Manson in a California prison since she was 19. Her name is Afton Burton, but Manson calls her "Star."

In an interview, the 26-year-old says she and Manson, now 80, consider themselves husband and wife. Burton believes Manson is innocent of the 1969 Tate-LaBianca murders and wants to clear his name.

Police are searching for a man who smashed the front door of a drone-manufacturing business in Corona before using a wheelbarrow to steal 11 aerial vehicles worth about $500,000.

A church in Northern California is giving new meaning to the term "holy rollers" by offering drive-through prayer.

"You don't have to prepare, and you don't have to plan. And you can experience God's immense love in two or three minutes," said Father Mathew Vellenkal, who came up with the idea. 

Cars were lined up at the Holy Spirit Church in Fremont on the first night that drive-up worship was offered.

"I think it's kind of the world that we're living in," said driver-parishioner Monica Slivinsky. "Sometimes not everybody has the time to spend an hour in Mass on a daily basis."

Barbara Bowman has turned to the public once more with an allegation that Bill Cosby raped her when she was 18.

"I woke up out of a very confused state not in my clothes," Bowman said, adding that she knew her body had been touched without her permission. This occurred several times in the course of their contact, she said.

When asked about the allegations during an interview on NPR, Cosby did not respond -- instead shaking his head "no," according to the interviewer, Scott Simon.

"There are people who love you who might like to hear from you about this. I want to give you the chance," Simon said, to silence from Cosby. "All right."

A store clerk in San Luis Obispo was brutally assaulted in an unprovoked attack by a would-be customer that was caught on video.

The female clerk was alone with Justin Edmund Pard, 20, inside the Flip Flop Shop for several minutes as he wandered around the store. They spoke several times and she even told him to "have a good day" as he walked toward the front door.

But for some reason, Pard turned around, walked directly toward the clerk, began yelling obscenities and punched her square in the face.

Police found a 10-inch kitchen knife in his pocket when they arrested him.

After months of battling stage three breast cancer, Garth Brooks fan Teresa Shaw brought a sign to his Friday show in Minneapolis that read, "Chemo this morning, Garth tonight, enjoying 'The Dance.'"

The message struck a chord with the country singer, whose own mother and sister died of cancer, and he stopped the show to serenade Teresa and deliver a message of his own.

"You have all of my strength. You have everybody's strength in here and you go kick cancer's (butt)," Brooks said while holding her sign high for the entire audience to see.

Henry Needham thought his pet dachshund "Tinkerbell" was killed when a wall of mud came crashing through his Camarillo Springs home on Halloween night.

When a muddy, but otherwise healthy Tinkerbell finally emerged, dozens of neighbors who gathered outside the home began to cheer.  "It was such a fantastic time, you cannot believe it," Needham said as he fought back tears.

NASA captured this haunting image of the sun getting into the Halloween spirit last week. 

"Active regions on the sun combined to look something like a solar jack-o'-lantern's face," said Joe Witte of NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center.

The eerie photo was taken by NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory on Oct. 8. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1EYdMaI
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Incredible video captured what has been described as a real-life "sharknado." 

The footage shows more than 100 sharks on a feeding frenzy along the shore of a North Carolina beach. 

Some of the sharks thrashed about shallow waters, nearly beaching themselves as they attempted to feed on a school of blue fish last Thursday. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1sLUJg0

In just a few short weeks, you could be the lucky KTLA viewer behind the wheel of a brand-new 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA!

Enter our giveaway once a day through Oct. 27 to increase your chances of winning. And "share" this post to let your SoCal friends and family know.

Click here to enter: www.ktla.com/GLA

status_message:
A 12-year-old girl from Arizona has called out Dick's Sporting Goods for failing to include female athletes in its 2014 basketball catalog -- and she's getting plenty of backup on the Web.

McKenna Peterson's letter to the company, which her father later tweeted, drew attention to the lack of gender equality in the ads.

"I think that girls should be treated as equally as boys are treated," she wrote. "I, myself, enjoying playing and watching basketball, WOMENS basketball."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1qhHa1V

A woman was moved to a galley at the back of a JFK-to-LAX flight after exhibiting flu-like symptoms, but health officials later determined she and others on the plane were not at risk for Ebola.

Passengers were kept on the plane for some two hours after United Airlines Flight 703 landed in Los Angeles, as firefighters and staff from the county Department of Public Health assessed the situation.

To date, there have been no confirmed cases of Ebola in L.A. County, officials said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1v0MpbY

How would you like to drive your very own 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA? KTLA is giving one away!

Enter once a day through Oct. 27 to increase your chances of winning.

Click here to enter: www.ktla.com/GLA

Ebola is no laughing matter, especially not on commercial planes, as a passenger discovered when he reportedly joked about having the disease.

"I was just kidding," the man is heard saying in a video posted on social media. "I ain't from Africa," he continued, as four officials in hazmat suits escorted him off U.S. Airways Flight 845.

Before the men came aboard in their bubble-like suits, a flight attendant prepared passengers for what they were about to see. 

"It's going to look worse than it is," she said over the PA system. "I think the man that has said this is an idiot, and I'll say that straight out."

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1skB3zG

KTLA is giving one away to a lucky driver! 

Enter daily through Oct. 27 to increase your chances of winning our giveaway.

A child riding in the back of his mother's car caught a violent confrontation between a passenger and police officers who had pulled the vehicle over for a seat-belt violation in Indiana.

The boy's mother can be heard telling a 911 operator she and her male friend were afraid to get out of the car.

Police eventual broke the passenger-side window and used a Taser on the man. The couple filed a lawsuit this week accusing the officers of "malice" and "reckless indifference." 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1rg4Umu

A 5-year-old boy battling a potentially deadly disease lived out his dream when he suited up for his favorite NBA team, the Utah Jazz.

J.P. Gibson has been fighting acute lymphoblastic leukemia "longer than he has not been in his little life," Megan Gibson, the boy's mother said.

The Jazz hosted J.P. and his family as part of the "Anything Can Be Project," which helps families with children affected by cancer.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1EtGuA8

BREAKING: The first person diagnosed with Ebola in the United States has died. 

Thomas Eric Duncan died Wednesday morning at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas, the hospital announced.

He had been in critical condition after being diagnosed with the virus in mid-September. People who have had contact with him have been isolated and are being monitored for symptoms.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/10PVbOA

status_message:
Sky watchers were treated to a stunning sight early Wednesday, as a total lunar eclipse turned the moon a burnt reddish-orange color for an about hour. 

Did you see it? 

In case you missed it, or perhaps you want to watch it again, the rare "blood moon" was captured in this cool time lapse video from NASA. 

Check out KTLA's full video here: http://ktlane.ws/1qhb8SV
The fastest man alive arrives tonight. Don't miss The Flash extended series premiere at 8 p.m. on The CW.

BREAKING: New video released by ISIS Friday appears to show the beheading of British hostage Alan Henning.

In the same video, the terror group threatened the life of an American aid worker.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1rawNMD

status_message: Update: Thanks to everyone who entered our Mercedes-Benz GLA giveaway! Good luck, and stay tuned for updates.

status_message:
Update: Dramatic video captured the end of a wild pursuit in Rialto when a truck driver crashed over the side of the 210 Freeway. 

The driver was later identified by police as Stephen Richard Bartlett, 53, and was suspected of being a serial bank robber dubbed the "Hills Bandit."

Amazingly, he was able to walk away from the crash before being taken into custody. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1rQ4oAL

Video of a Florida police officer using a stun gun on a 62-year-old woman as she walked away from him has led to the officer being placed on leave. 

The video shows the woman falling face-first into the asphalt, eventually rolling over and flailing her arms on the ground. 

"Based on the video I have enough concerns to call for an internal investigation," the Tallahassee police chief said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/10ltcWQ

A knife-carrying White House intruder originally said to have been stopped just inside the front door actually went much further during what appears to have been a wild chase through the main floor earlier this month.

Omar Gonzalez, a 42-year-old Iraq war veteran, somehow penetrated "five rings of security" and even ran past the stairway that leads to the first family's residence. 

"It's clear that our security plan was not properly executed," Secret Service Director Julia Pierson said Tuesday morning. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1DTampg

A deer jumped a 7-foot fence, injured his leg and became tangled in a pool cover Saturday, all in an effort to swim in an Encino home's pool. 

Homeowners said the beautiful animal appeared nervous, and despite their efforts to corral him, the buck took off after his quick dip. 

Animal rescue officials later found the deer, and say they plan to release it back into the wild after his injury heals. 

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1viQTKQ

A Glendale police officer arrested for allegedly soliciting a prostitute will make more than $10,000 a month on paid leave until he retires at the end of 2015.

The paid leave is part of a settlement Sgt. Vahak Mardikian received after he and four other officers sued the department alleging discrimination, retaliation and harassment because they're Armenian.

Mardikian was arrested in August during a prostitution sting in Las Vegas after allegedly offering an undercover vice detective $250 -- plus $25 in gas money -- for sex.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1okVZ35
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
BREAKING: Workers are sandbagging hotels, restaurants and other businesses along the Sunset Strip following a major water main break in West Hollywood.

Motorists are advised to avoid the area near Sunset and La Cienega Boulevard, which remains flooded as LADWP crews work to shut off the water.

"Share" this to alert others.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1qDN4t8

Officers say they believe the spine-tingling image captured on surveillance video at a New Mexico police station is a ghost. 

"At first I thought it was... a fly or moth, then I saw the legs and it was a human... a ghost," said Officer Karl Romero, who was monitoring the station's surveillance cameras when he noticed the shadow-like object floating across the screen. 

Police have ruled out issues with lighting or it being a technical glitch. They also claim the area where the moving image was spotted was secure, and that there was no way in or out without an alarm sounding. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1vlE28L

Dashcam video captured a Highway Patrol trooper in South Carolina shooting an unarmed man he pulled over for a seatbelt violation.

The video shows motorist Levar Jones following the trooper's instructions to get his wallet out of the car. 

Then, without warning trooper Sean Groubert opened fire. Jones was wounded in the leg. Groubert was fired and faces criminal charges.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1t10v8s

Update: After surveillance video was released of a brazen grocery store robber who rode a handicap motorized scooter before putting a Food 4 Less manager in a headlock and stealing his car in order to escape, police say the man is in custody.

The video shows the man force the manager into an office, where he demanded a backpack he was carrying be filled with cash. 

With the help of community members, Santa Ana police identified the alleged robber as Antonio Delgado Juarez. He had been in custody since Monday on unrelated charges. 

Click here to read KTLA's story: http://ktlane.ws/1v3Xvwh

The woman who was captured on cellphone video being beaten by a California Highway Patrol officer on the side of a Los Angeles freeway has reached a $1.5 million settlement with the department, according to her attorney, Caree Harper.

The settlement includes a provision that the officer involved will resign.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/Ze3gMm
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Eleven years after being raped by a stranger in a supermarket parking lot, Jane Piper confronted him in court before he was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

"How much of what you did to me did you carry with you through the years?" she asked Gilbert Trejo. "Did you think that it would affect me as it did? Because it does."

While KTLA does not typically name victims in sexual assault cases, Piper asked to be identified, saying that it shows she's not ashamed of what happened to her and that other victims shouldn't be either. She also feels a responsibility as a victim, she said, to add her voice to a conversation often dominated by people several steps removed from the crime.

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1oh3nN4

With a coffee cup in hand, President Barack Obama offered a less-than-formal salute to a Marine standing guard as he exited the presidential helicopter, Marine One.

Some detractors quickly pounced on the president's coffee cup salute, while others described the criticism as much ado about nothing.

What do you think? Was the salute a sign of disrespect, or an innocent mistake?

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/XY6ty0

Disturbing cellphone video which captured a violent confrontation between a teenage boy and a transient at a skate park in Riverside prompted a police investigation after it was recently posted on Facebook. 

The man, named Shane, was immediately knocked out and could be seen lying on the ground with blood coming from his head after the 16-year-old punched him in the jaw. 

Despite being knocked unconscious, Shane said he would prefer charges not to be filed against the teen.

"I don't want no harm to come to him. I don't want him to be penalized for it," he said.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1rtdzXF

A Lake Elsinore man is accused of killing a 3-month-old puppy by dragging it with his truck before running it over.

Victor Perez-Guzman has been arrested on suspicion of animal cruelty, authorities said.

He was taken into custody several days after the alleged incident, which was reported by multiple callers to the Riverside County Sheriff's Department dispatch center.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1qohrDK
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
When a vehicle lost control, crashed through a fence and ended up submerged and overturned in a Utah river, a group of bystanders rushed into the water in a desperate bid to save the three teen occupants. 

It took some effort, but the good Samaritans managed to flip the vehicle back onto its wheels and prevent the teens from drowning in a dramatic rescue that was captured on cellphone video. 

"As far as I know, a couple of kids get to live because of my actions. I feel like I'm somebody," said Leo Montoya Jr., who was the first person to jump into the river. 

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1x0vnMZ

An Iraq war veteran suffering from PTSD has been arrested after allegedly jumping the White House fence and entering the building with a knife in his possession on Friday. 

Omar Gonzalez told a Secret Service agent "that he was concerned that the atmosphere was collapsing and needed to get the information to the president of the United States so that he could get the word out to the people," according to an affidavit. 

Cellphone and surveillance video show a man running across the White House lawn and entering an unlocked door. 

Read KTLA's story here:  http://ktlane.ws/1qYypit

Police are asking for the public's help in finding a hit-and-run driver who struck an 80-year-old pedestrian at an intersection in Glendale.

Lousine Ghazarian required several stitches in her right knee after being hit at Broadway and Columbus Avenue, police said.

The driver, described as a woman in her 20s, fled the scene in a small, black four-door sedan.

"Share" this to alert others.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/ZvW2Di

After a 24-year-old bride-to-be was killed in a car crash, her sisters celebrated her life by wearing their bridesmaids dresses in a mud run.

Shannon Hall died about a month before her Oct. 4 wedding date when the car in which she was riding collided with a school bus.

"She was such an amazing, amazing girl and a lot of fun," one of Hall's sisters said. "Since we won't be wearing [the dresses] on the 4th, we thought this would be a perfect way to honor her."

Watch KTLA's video here: http://ktlane.ws/1qkVN3g

Parents should use common sense â€” and a healthy dose of soap and water â€” to prevent serious illnesses from the enterovirus recently detected in California, experts say.

The respiratory virus has now been confirmed in four children in the state and is expected to appear in more.

To slow transmission of the enterovirus, the Department of Public Health recommends, Californians should:

â€¢ Wash hands frequently -- for at least 20 seconds, with soap and water.
â€¢ Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands or sharing utensils or cups or kissing and hugging people who are sick.
â€¢ Keep children home from school if they have active symptoms of an infection.

"Share" this to alert others.

Read KTLA's story here: http://ktlane.ws/1unRE2w
